7/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_cover.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_cover.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Principles Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover-1920x1080.png",1920,1080,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover.png",1920,1080,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_cover.png",760,428,false],"full": Leadership Handbook, your guide to becoming a strong design leader — DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Experience stories from experts, gain the confidence to transition to design leadership, and learn the skills to build a first-class design team.","keywords":"","fb-title":"Design Leadership Handbook—from DesignBetter.Co","fb-desc":"Your guide to becoming a strong design leader and building first-class design teams, featuring stories and insights from some of the world's most innovative design leaders.","fb-img":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/17-Design-Leadership-1200x630-V2.png","twtr-title":"Design Leadership Handbook—your guide to becoming a strong leader, from @InVisionApp","twtr-desc":"Your guide to becoming a design leader and building world-class teams, from DesignBetter.Co and @InVisionApp #DesignBetter","twtr-img":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/18-Design-Leadership-880x440-V3.png"},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook"},{"id":665,"pid":0,"title":"Becoming a design leader","type":"chapter","date":"665","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/andytlaw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAndy Law\u003c/a\u003e spotted an opportunity. As a designer at Netflix, he saw firsthand the need for someone to step up and bridge the gap between mobile design and the company’s engineering management. Things would be more efficient with some design leadership. Andy raised his hand and found himself in a new leadership position.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough he had a clear understanding of the product and his craft, the mechanics of leading a team was new territory with an intimidating learning curve. He approached leadership as he would any design challenge—with research.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe interviewed managers both at Netflix and tech companies in the Valley to better understand what it means to be a design leader. Andy also carefully observed leaders and spotted the gaps in the organization where leadership was needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1001]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost designers, when presented with a leadership opportunity, leap into the role enthusiastically, unaware of the challenges ahead. Not Andy Law; he wanted to be sure he knew what he was getting himself into.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/designbetter-website-sq-chapters_images_andy_law_books-700px.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. Andy Law had to plow through a stack of books to get his bearings as a design leader.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHe spoke with people who’d once been managers but returned to individual contributor (IC) roles, asking what about management didn’t work for them, and what should he look out for. He learned that in most cases people struggled with the new duties required of them. Their talents as an individual designer didn’t translate into management.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAndy pored over leadership books like Michael Porter’s \u003cem\u003eCompetitive Strategy\u003c/em\u003e and Dale Carnegie’s classic \u003cem\u003eHow to Win Friends and Influence People \u003c/em\u003eto fill gaps in his knowledge. At first skeptical that some of these books from decades past would still be relevant, he found that the principles—largely based on human interactions—were still quite relevant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAndy knew his new role would occasionally feel uncomfortable. Despite doing his homework, he would at times feel unprepared, and he would certainly make mistakes. But all great design leaders start their careers with doubts and misgivings. Andy once told his boss:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u0026#8220;I’m never going to be 100% prepared to be a design leader, but I’ll always be 100% committed\u003c/em\u003e.\u0026#8221;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis philosophy guided him through the transition as he found his footing. As a manager, Andy learned how to deal with all types of personalities, how to motivate people, and how to develop rapport to be effective.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAndy Law’s preparation for his new role as a design leader is exemplary, but for the rest of us, a little guidance can make the transition smoother. This guide will help you get your bearings. We’ll show you the essential skills you’ll need to cultivate, and we’ll provide you with practical methodologies to be more effective in your role.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere\u0026#8217;s how to become a design leader.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1005]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat it means to be a design leader\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe transition to a leadership role is hard for many designers because their love of craft runs deep—leading design means less designing. As a leader, you’ll spend most of your time managing the team. That doesn’t mean you’re no longer a designer; it just means someone else will be implementing the design. Your new position is an opportunity to provide vision and guidance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’re no longer just playing an instrument. Now, you’re conducting the orchestra.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a designer, you’re accustomed to thinking carefully about the customer experience, a skill that will also come in handy as you lead your team. You’ll be designing an environment and structure that brings out your employees\u0026#8217; best work to serve both the company and its users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/bbaxley\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA lot of the anxiety about moving into leadership is that the typical introverted, thoughtful traits associated with designers are not a natural fit at the executive level. Therefore, designers wanting to increase their scale and influence have to be fully aware of the emotional challenges that are likely to result.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/baxley_headshot1-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Bob Baxley\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBob Baxley\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformerly Apple, Pinterest, Yahoo\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “\u0026#8230;the typical introverted, thoughtful traits associated with designers are not a natural fit at the executive level.” @bbaxley    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are emotional challenges that come with a transition into a leadership role. As a leader among leaders, you’ll be working more often with people who don’t necessarily think like a designer, which is not bad—it’s just different. You’ll need to express ideas differently. To your design team, you might say, “This one feels like the right direction.” But to an executive, “This meets our business goals” will make more sense.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll be adapting to new cultures and speaking new languages, but soon foreign territory will become familiar and you’ll find ways to be effective in most any situation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://99u.com/articles/52189/how-to-be-a-designer-at-a-large-company-3m\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDriving the concept of creativity and design in large organizations comes with a long-term commitment, which will not be a sprint but more a marathon.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/eric-quint-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Eric Quint\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eEric Quint\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003e3M\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Driving the concept of creativity and design in large organizations comes with a long-term commitment…” @3M’s Eric Quint    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhat Got You Here Won’t Get You There\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll need to cultivate an entirely new set of skills to be an effective design leader. While Marshall Goldsmith’s book \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/What-Got-Here-Wont-There/dp/1401301304/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eWhat Got You Here Won’t Get You There\u003c/a\u003e isn’t about design, it is about making big career transitions, and will give you the guidance you need as you make the leap from an individual contributor to a leader in your organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"START YOUR DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-small_2x-760x760.png\" alt=\"Powering design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003ePowering design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInVision Enterprise powers design at more than 75% of the Fortune 100\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSTART YOUR DEMO\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-2009 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-2009:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat you’ll learn\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign leaders do more than spend their days giving thumbs up or down in design critiques. In this handbook we’ll help you get your bearings on these essential skills:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild your team\u003c/strong\u003e: Find people with the right balance of technical and soft skills for your team. \u003cem\u003eYou need to be searching for talent even when you don’t need it! \u003c/em\u003eFind the right organizational structure to make your team productive.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eManage\u003c/strong\u003e: Evaluate each team member’s performance, coach them so they can grow, and minimize conflicts.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOperationalize\u003c/strong\u003e: Keep your team moving efficiently by standardizing the design feedback process, managing projects, and coordinating with other teams.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eForge alliances\u003c/strong\u003e: Build connections with other team leaders and executives to make sure your team gets what it needs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eProvide vision\u003c/strong\u003e: Though you’re no longer pushing pixels, you still need to play a central role in crafting a vision for your product and brand.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a design leader, you’ll have a lot on your plate! Let’s take a look at each of your responsibilities in detail, starting with how you’ll build your team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHear IDEO and Stanford d.school founder David Kelley talk about creative confidence and much more\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast/david-kelley\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-2020 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLISTEN NOW\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-2020 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-2020:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eWhat does it mean to be an exceptional design leader? Transitioning to design leadership can be challenging for individual contributors. The skills that got you there often don’t translate into your new role. Insights from design leaders who have been in those shoes can help you gain confidence and tactical skills.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this book, you’ll learn how to grow as a leader and build a first-class design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":1,"fields":{"book":["597"],"chapter_num":"01","sub_title":"You'll never be 100% prepared","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eWhat does it mean to be an exceptional design leader? Transitioning to design leadership can be challenging for individual contributors. The skills that got you there often don’t translate into your new role. Insights from design leaders who have been in those shoes can help you gain confidence and tactical skills.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this book, you’ll learn how to grow as a leader and build a first-class design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"","related":[{"title":"What Got You Here Won’t Get You There","url":"https://www.amazon.com/What-Got-Here-Wont-There/dp/1401301304/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Manager Tools Basics (Podcasts)","url":"https://www.manager-tools.com/manager-tools-basics","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"We need design leaders now more than ever","url":"https://medium.com/leading-design/we-need-design-leaders-now-more-than-ever-d41cfd1c95d3#.p6n4uq9s0","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"What are the essential qualities of a good design leader?","url":"http://blog.invisionapp.com/qualities-of-a-good-design-leader/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Welcome to the Executive Team. It’s Messy Here.","url":"https://shift.newco.co/welcome-to-the-executive-team-its-messy-here-85571a6a04b9#.d774ewxhw","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"The brutal truth about becoming a design manager","url":"https://medium.com/@martynreding/the-brutal-truth-about-becoming-a-design-manager-1eca101b55e1#.58ivj8gk0","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"How Do You Measure Leadership?","url":"http://blog.ycombinator.com/how-do-you-measure-leadership/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Are you a creative leader or manager? ","url":"https://medium.com/@sdgates/are-you-a-creative-leader-or-manager-redux-22a38a12f6ec#.u4sluvrgh","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Aarron Walter","author_link":"\u003ca href=\"http://aarronwalter.com\" title=\"Visit Aarron Walter\u0026#8217;s website\" rel=\"author external\"\u003eAarron Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_intro.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Becoming a design leader - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Transitioning to design leadership can be challenging. Learn from experts and gain the confidence and tactical skills to build world-class design teams.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook/becoming-a-design-leader"},{"id":811,"pid":0,"title":"Building the team","type":"chapter","date":"811","content":"\u003cp\u003eYour team’s performance and culture will be influenced greatly by the people within it. As you build your design team, think not only of the talents of the individual, but how all the individuals will work together. Great teams are composed of individual contributors with complementary skills—they think we, not me. Chemistry is important—thoughtful leaders will choose people who unite, not divide.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eLook before you leap\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re stepping into a leadership role in an existing team, don’t rush to make changes. If you do, you’ll make enemies fast. Get to know each person in the team first.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn private conversations, ask each team member these three questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e1. What’s working?\u003cbr /\u003e\n2. What’s not working?\u003cbr /\u003e\n3. What should I focus on?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter you’ve gotten a good feel for the team, begin to enact the changes needed to make the team more effective.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefining your team’s values will help you shape team chemistry and think more carefully about how you hire.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDefining team values\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour team is unlike any other team in your company—though your team is part of the broader company culture, you have your own sub-culture too. The act of design is uniquely emotional, as it requires exploration of new and uncharted territory. Because design is a qualitative endeavor—operating on feel, not numbers—it introduces a level of vulnerability that is atypical of product management or engineering. It is a unique discipline with its own set of values.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd those values are important. They will shape your culture, hiring decisions, team member evaluations, productivity, and ultimately the happiness of each person on your team. As a design leader, you should work with your team to define the core values that will shape your culture and \u003ca href=\"http://blog.invisionapp.com/ux-team-core-values/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eestablish a motivational foundation for the work you do\u003c/a\u003e. When there’s buy-in from everybody, teams operate more cohesively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis process will help you identify your team’s values:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSeed the conversation. Before getting the team together, gather values from other design teams and jot down a few notes about the values you’d like to see your team consider. \u003ca href=\"https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lK_DAidn3eQ5Vr5GgV0UxKOdI04sBcJxDzX279d9MoI/edit?usp=sharing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eThis sample team values doc\u003c/a\u003e will give you and your team a starting point for your discussion and help you understand how values affect your work.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGather your team and share your thoughts with them. Have each team member write down 5 values on sticky notes privately, then post them on the wall for discussion.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLet each team member explain the values they identified.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGroup common values on the wall to narrow your options and identify trends.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAfter discussion, give each team member 5 \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Avery-Removable-Coding-Labels-Assorted/dp/B000BMBU9M/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003esmall dot stickers\u003c/a\u003e to cast their votes for the values they feel best represent the team.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFurther discussion may be required to trim the list to the essentials. Once you have a final list, create a shared document with a detailed description of each value.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/designbetter_website_designleadershiphandbook_images_valuesposter.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. When your team\u0026#8217;s values are visible they remain on everyone\u0026#8217;s mind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsider making your team values visible. A series of beautiful posters can help them sink into your team’s culture more effectively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePay close attention to these values over time. Do they remain an accurate representation of who you are as a team, or are they merely aspirational? If the latter, realign the values to better reflect the team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/to-build-great-products-build-this-strong-scalable-system-first/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHand out priorities, not tasks, and let your people be creative about their own execution.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/Kavin-Stewart-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Kavin Stewart\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eKavin Stewart\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eReddit\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Hand out priorities, not tasks, and let your people be creative about their own execution.” @kavinstewart @reddit    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Workshops-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Workshops-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"Expert workshops for your team\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eExpert workshops for your team\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBring DesignBetter.Co to your team with our design workshops—coming soon\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1660 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eREQUEST A WORKSHOP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1660 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1660:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHiring\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1075]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhether you’re at a startup that’s doing well or a more established enterprise, your team is probably growing (as Y-combinator founder Paul Graham writes, \u003ca href=\"http://www.paulgraham.com/growth.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003estartup = growth\u003c/a\u003e). To keep pace with your current and future growth, you’ll need to ensure hiring is ingrained in your workflow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHiring the right people is actually \u003cstrong\u003eyour most important job\u003c/strong\u003e. The people you hire will form the foundation of your team, and may in turn hire others as growth continues. They’re also your greatest legacy. Some will outlast your tenure and carry on the work you started. Think carefully and invest your time accordingly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’ve ever freelanced or run an agency, you know how critical it is to keep your project pipeline full. The same goes for hiring; if you wait until you have an open position to begin searching for talent, you’ve waited too long!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;329678193\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThink carefully about the needs of your team and the company as you consider candidates. You may be tempted to evaluate candidates based on their technical skills, and you may write them off if they’re missing one skill you think critical, even if they fit other requirements perfectly. The primary reasons for letting an employee go rarely relate to a lack of technical prowess; rather it’s a shortcoming in \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_skills\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003esoft skills\u003c/a\u003e. Missing technical skills can be remedied with coaching, but shortcomings in soft skills are much more difficult to correct.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://www.khoslaventures.com/ux-recruiting-toolkit-interviewing-ux-candidates-57\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe 1:1 interview is your chance to assess soft skills: self-awareness, social awareness, self-management, and relationship management. These are all ingredients for emotional intelligence, which are critical for design success.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/Irene_au-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Irene Au\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eIrene Au\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eKhosla Ventures\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The 1:1 interview is your chance to assess soft skills\u0026#8230;which are critical for design success.” @ireneau @khoslaventures    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAssessing soft skills can be difficult, especially in the constrained environment of an interview—the interviewee is likely anxious and trying to impress you. You want to set your interviewee up for success, so get to know the person before discussing technical stuff. Find out what they’re passionate about and how they see the world. It can sound like casual chatter, but it provides the clues needed to evaluate soft skills. Here’s what to look for when interviewing candidates:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBroad perspectives\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiverse backgrounds and interests introduce different perspectives to the team. You don’t want to hire a bunch of employees who are just like you; this is why it’s best to avoid hiring for “culture fit.” Instead, to really foster innovation, look for people who bring new dimensions to your company, and strive to build teams with a variety of voices and outlooks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://insights.som.yale.edu/insights/what-do-leaders-need-understand-about-diversity\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIf you want diversity of thought, you have to bring in people around you who have diverse experiences.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/brescoll-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Victoria L. Brescoll\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eVictoria L. Brescoll\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eYale School of Management\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “If you want diversity of thought, you have to bring in people around you who have diverse experiences.” @VBrescoll @YaleSOM    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAdaptation and grit\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eListen hard to your candidate’s life and work experiences. Stories of overcoming adversity, not fitting in, or moving to a new country, for instance, provide clues about how someone deals with challenges. Adaptation skills demonstrate that the candidate has the aptitude to overcome a tough problem, team change, or new project.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMacArthur Fellow and psychologist \u003ca href=\"http://www.ted.com/talks/angela_lee_duckworth_the_key_to_success_grit?language=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAngela Lee Duckworth calls this quality “grit.”\u003c/a\u003e Grit is more than just perseverance; Duckworth ties grit to a focus on long-term goals and a commitment to following through on them. Candidates who’ve overcome adversity over a long period of time because they can see the payoff are gritty, and usually make great hires.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA collaborative mindset\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFew skills are as important to a team as collaboration, but it can be hard to gauge during an interview how well a candidate will work with others. However, there are ways to pick up signals, like by asking the candidate about the dynamics of other teams they’ve worked on, and discovering how they like to collaborate. Look for red flags, like if the interviewee blames failures on other team members.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt might make sense to create a small, tightly scoped project to help you evaluate candidates. Here are 2 project ideas:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4 style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003eNew product ideation exercise\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAssemble your team and the candidate in a room with a whiteboard for a 1- to 2-hour ideation session. Identify a product idea to explore as a group—one that you and your team have no prior knowledge of so you’re on equal footing with the candidate. Work through a simplified \u003ca href=\"http://www.gv.com/sprint\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDesign Sprint\u003c/a\u003e process to explore design solutions to the presented problem. Sketch individually, present ideas, and discuss. Work through revisions of the ideas together and observe how the candidate works with your team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4 style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003eReimagining existing product exercise\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInvite the candidate to conduct a detailed evaluation of an existing product (it needn’t be yours), identifying flaws in the user experience. From those observations, have the candidate design an alternate solution and present it to the team for discussion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the design is presented, listen carefully to how the candidate responds to critical feedback from the team. Are they defensive or open-minded? Do they talk more than they listen? Do they seek credit? You’ll learn a lot in that short exchange.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“330221069”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSocial aptitude and energy\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond structured collaborative activities, social time with a candidate provides everyone a chance to get to know each other—invite candidates to lunch as part of the interview process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpending time together benefits both you and the candidate. You can determine if the candidate is still excited about the job opportunity. Do they gel with your team? Can they hold a conversation, or is there awkward silence? Discomfort in the interview process will be amplified if the candidate joins the team, so pay close attention. For the candidate, social time provides a preview of the working relationship.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLook for red flags and green lights, and be sure to listen to your gut. \u003ca href=\"http://qz.com/474523/is-your-gut-really-the-second-brain/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGut feelings can tell us a lot if we’re willing to listen\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“330221770”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHumility\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHumble people make great teammates, as they’re willing to listen to and learn from others. They don’t crave credit, so they’re natural collaborators, and they treat others fairly and with kindness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA candidate’s humility, or lack thereof, comes through in a longer interview process. When they checked in, how did they treat the people at the front desk? Did they ask a lot of questions of the people they met? Did they take the time to learn about the company, you, and your team before the interview? It’s hard to ask about humility directly in interview questions, but tune into the language your candidate uses and you might get an accurate reading. Listen for an abundance of self-congratulatory statements and a lack of shared credit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough humility is an attractive virtue in a candidate, be sure it’s balanced with confidence; confident designers act upon their judgements but are humble enough to know they could be wrong.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eGenius designers\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt can be alluring to hire a genius designer with an ego to match, but be sure to consider the costs to the team. A strong-willed designer can intimidate others—intentionally or unintentionally—and make people feel like there’s no place for their contribution. Thoughtful leaders will choose people who unite, not divide. There are, however, rare cases where a genius can be a great hire. When given the independence to experiment, a relatively isolated genius can produce innovative results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEasy to hire, hard to fire\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt can be tempting, as a project grows and existing team members are overburdened, to try to save the day by hiring the first halfway decent candidate that walks through the door. But it’s critical to take the time to make an informed decision—hiring too fast fills your company with people you don’t want to work with, who will derail your progress, and who will demoralize your best performers. Fast hiring often leads to slow, painful firings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDesign/UX recruiting resources\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://www.khoslaventures.com/resources/design-ux\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eKhosla Ventures has assembled a great series of resources\u003c/a\u003e that will help you recruit, review, and interview candidates for your design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemember, as a design leader there is nothing more important than hiring. Put in the time, get to know each candidate well, and choose people who bring new perspectives to your team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1087]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4 style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003eThe designer hiring process\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis hiring schedule will help you get a good read on design candidates and help you see how they’d fit into your team:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePhone screen\u003c/strong\u003e (30 minutes): You or someone in HR will have a casual conversation to see if the candidate has any immediate red flags and gauge their personality.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePhone screen\u003c/strong\u003e (1 hour): You and someone else on your team will speak with the candidate by phone to learn about their work history, interests, and views on design. Leave time for the candidate to ask questions, which will inform both you and the candidate!\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOn-site visit\u003c/strong\u003e (4 to 6 hours): You’ll invite the candidate to your office to present their work and field questions about their process. Include your team and representatives from other departments, and leave time for more casual conversations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDecision time:\u003c/strong\u003e Get each team member’s feedback individually, not as a group—people can talk themselves out of red flags. If the candidate didn’t make the cut, give honest and constructive feedback to make this is a learning opportunity.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow Facebook hires designers\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJulie Zhuo, VP of Product Design at Facebook, shares \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/An-Inside-Look-at-Facebooks-Method-for-Hiring-Designers/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea behind the scenes look at how Facebook hires designers\u003c/a\u003e. Bestselling author and Wharton professor Adam Grant has developed \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/adam-grant-on-interviewing-to-hire-trailblazers-nonconformists-and-originals/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea series of questions to help you hire Trailblazers, Nonconformists, and Originals\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFiring\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSometimes, even if you follow a great hiring process, things just don’t work out. Before the situation becomes unworkable, take the time to coach your employee, and communicate feedback clearly and often. If things aren’t headed in the right direction, the employee should know and have a chance to improve. A firing should never be a surprise.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://m.signalvnoise.com/how-to-make-firing-people-suck-less-for-them-and-suck-more-for-you-977afb9ad15d#.lfqoijhkm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThere’s never a great time to fire someone, but delaying the execution only makes it worse. Every interaction between when the final decision has been made and until it’s carried out is a painful charade.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/dhh-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"David Heinemeier Hansson\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDavid Heinemeier Hansson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBasecamp\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “There’s never a great time to fire someone, but delaying the execution only makes it worse.” @dhh @basecamp    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFiring is painful for all involved. It can cause you sleepless nights, and inspire doubt in your abilities as a manager. But the sooner you fire a bad employee, the quicker you and your team can right the ship than if you put off the painful task.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou may also inherit a team with mediocre players. Unfortunately, mediocrity begets more mediocrity—it’s hard to attract top talent to the “B” team. Make improvements to the team quickly or you will find yourself stuck with a second-rate team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA toxic team member can pollute the whole team and give other teams pause before collaborating on a project. If you have a bad apple, experiment with a temporary reassignment to see how the team dynamic shifts. A dramatic, positive change in your team with the problem team member absent will be a clear cue that stronger measures are needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/bbaxley\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIt can feel brutal to fire somebody, but in virtually every case you\u0026#8217;re doing them a favor since it frees them up to find another opportunity that is a better fit for them.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/baxley-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Bob Baxley\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBob Baxley\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformerly Apple, Pinterest, Yahoo\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “It can feel brutal to fire somebody, but in virtually every case you\u0026#8217;re doing them a favor…” @bbaxley    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you do get to the point where the employee needs to be let go, be respectful, and help them find a new opportunity. This transition will help them reflect on their career and could be the change they need to rekindle their passion for their work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYou should have fired them sooner\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCindy Alvarez, Director of UX at Yammer, shares a helpful list of \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/27/yammers-cindy-alvarez-five-types-of-people-i-should-have-fired-sooner/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e5 types of people she should have fired sooner\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTeam structure\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ve done the hard work of hiring the right people for the right roles, and now you need to organize your team so they can be most effective. What organizational model should you follow?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:976]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are many possible team structures, each with benefits and challenges. None are perfect; instead of searching for a single solution, consider what’s right for your company \u003cem\u003eright now\u003c/em\u003e and craft what’s right for you.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOptimize for today\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe team structure you choose today won\u0026#8217;t fit your organization in the future; no doubt you’ll have to change course at some point as the team and company evolve. Optimize for today, but be prepared to change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet’s take a look at 3 different models and explore what they have to offer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCentralized\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA centralized team structure keeps all designers in the same team in a shared space. Some refer to this as the “agency model” as other teams come to the centralized design team for their services—much like the way a client would approach an agency.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCentralized design teams can work in a shared studio space where work can be posted and discussed regularly, which can help designers grow in their craft more quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePros\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDesigners get frequent feedback from peers, helping them grow and stay engaged with their work\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen a centralized design team monitors all UIs on a single team, it’s easier to create a unified user experience across many products on multiple platforms\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInstead of focusing on incremental improvements, a centralized team can take a broader view and create a grand vision for a product.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA design culture is cultivated when all designers are together regularly\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCons\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDesigners leave important collaborators like engineers out of the ideation process in this structure, which can create political conflict\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDesigners are disconnected from technical requirements when they’re isolated from engineers\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDesigners must work harder to bring people into their process\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“330242608”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEmbedded\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn an embedded model, designers are positioned in cross-functional teams with engineers and product managers working on a specific product or feature. Cross-functional teams are a hallmark of \u003ca href=\"https://www.atlassian.com/agile\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ethe Agile process\u003c/a\u003e. This model is often referred to as \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/defining-product-design-a-dispatch-from-airbnbs-design-chief/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEPD—Engineering, Product, and Design\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlex Schleifer, VP of Design at Airbnb, likens EPD to a 3-legged stool: if the team was lacking a design role from the onset, or if the role was added after the engineering and product management team had already matured and grown, then the design leg ends up being shorter and the stool topples over.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt Airnnb, each EPD function “is involved and aligned from a product’s inception to its launch.” At least one member from each of the 3 teams is involved with working groups for new features, or in product marketing, or user feedback sessions. In Alex’s observations, companies that successfully grow these functions in parallel as the organization scales do 2 things: they hire and unleash a design lead from the start, and they grow the headcount of the design team in step with engineering and product hiring.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigners have the opportunity to learn from and build close relationships with colleagues from other domains in a cross-functional team, and can gain a better understanding of the technical and business requirements of a product. But designers are often outnumbered by engineers and can feel pressure to conform to engineering values.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/mikeindustries\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMike Davidson\u003c/a\u003e, former VP of Design at Twitter, says that “designers in product teams are vulnerable to ‘path of least resistance’ behavior—engineers will ask the designer to make things simpler so implementation is easier. You’re accountable to a different set of values when you’re working with other designers.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eStranded on an island\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNever leave a designer solo on a cross-functional team. Eventually they’ll feel lost and their growth will stagnate. Either place a minimum of 2 designers on each team or \u003ca href=\"https://www.fastcodesign.com/3060607/inside-the-organic-ux-design-process-at-slack\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003efollow Slack’s example and pair designers from different teams\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:583]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePros\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWorking closely, designers and engineers develop a strong understanding of their colleagues’ craft\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe rapport established within cross-functional teams fosters empathy and respect that make collaboration easier (and more \u003cem\u003efun\u003c/em\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCommunication is much faster. Designers are immediately made aware of the technical challenges their decisions create, and engineers learn when function diminishes form.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDiverse perspectives each step of the way lead to better product solutions\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eShared ownership dampens political fighting and builds trust\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCons\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDesigners can feel isolated and find that their growth has stagnated\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMaintaining a consistent user experience across multiple products and platforms becomes difficult\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCross-functional teams tend to work iteratively in sprints, which lend themselves well to iterative improvements, but not big leaps in innovation\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTeams that work on only one aspect of a product start to lose sight of the overarching customer experience\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“330243803”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are many ways to organize a cross-functional team. You can organize around:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePlatform:\u003c/strong\u003e Spotify has different teams for their desktop, Android, and iOS apps\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFeature:\u003c/strong\u003e Facebook has teams that work on News Feed, Messenger, and Profile\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCustomer experience:\u003c/strong\u003e Airbnb has separate teams for the host and guest experiences of their service\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHybrid\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can, of course, blend models as well to create a hybrid design organization. You can position designers in a temporary cross-functional team to work on a focused project with a clear deadline, as is common at MailChimp. When they’re done, they return to the centralized design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can distribute your designers in cross-functional teams, but pull them back together for design reviews, stand-ups, and fireside chats as Twitter does.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen a company has reached sufficient scale, a centralized team can manage a code design system that serves designers distributed in various cross-functional teams. This is Spotify’s approach—they bring designers together in a \u003ca href=\"https://ucvox.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/113617905-scaling-agile-spotify-11.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003edesign guild\u003c/a\u003e for design reviews, but with a focus on adhering to design systems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSometimes a change in your seating chart is all you need. Lendingtree has positioned their centralized design team among engineers and product managers to promote collaboration, but each designer still reports back to a design leader.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:578]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTeam structures evolve over time, especially as a company scales, and there’s no single path to building great design teams as a company grows. However, we can apply the problem solving skills and iterative approach that we use to build great products to also build great teams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePoint your team in the right direction\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt can be tempting, now that you have a team that can execute quickly, to dive in and start building. But as Laura Martini, product designer at Google, writes in her article \u003ca href=\"https://blog.prototypr.io/so-your-boss-doesn-t-believe-in-user-research-40d8128db08e#.bdsvkxyyl\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSo Your Boss Doesn’t Believe in Design Research\u003c/a\u003e, it’s critical that your team is headed to the \u003cem\u003eright\u003c/em\u003e finish line, and user research can help you get there. However, it’s not always easy to convince stakeholders that this is a pivotal step in the design process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“330244989\u0026amp;amp”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen your team is under the gun to produce results quickly, baking research into the design process can seem like a daunting challenge. Just mention of the word “research” seems to imply that it will be expensive and time consuming—something more suited to a particle physics lab than a product design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut research doesn’t have to be difficult or take a lot of time. Erika Hall, partner at Mule Design, outlines a wealth of techniques for low-effort user research in her book \u003ca href=\"https://abookapart.com/products/just-enough-research\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eJust Enough Research\u003c/a\u003e. And if you’re too constrained on time and resources to read the book, you can use her great technique—a \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/research-things/minimum-viable-ethnography-a047e9358df0#.50kl64lvh\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMinimum Viable Ethnography\u003c/a\u003e—to get invaluable insights for less than $300 over 3 days.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing an approach like this, you can often sneak research in under the radar. When you share the wins with stakeholders, you can show that a little research helped you get big results. This may give you more latitude to include research in your design process for future projects.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:980]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" collaboration\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn
