FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTRY FREEHAND\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1967 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1967:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eKey takeaways\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDefine your team’s values to help your team make great hires and keep your culture healthy\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHiring is your most important job—invest your time accordingly\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen vetting candidates, focus on soft skills. Technical skills can be coached, but soft skills are hard to change.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt’s easy to hire, hard to fire. Devote enough time to the hiring process so you and your team get to know the candidate.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eProvide honest and timely feedback (the kind that’s not easy to hear) to help change negative behaviors\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFiring is your last resort. Offer ample coaching and clear warnings before you consider termination.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConsider establishing cross-functional teams to improve collaboration and communication between design and development. The EPD structure—Engineering, Product, and Design—is becoming common in design-driven companies.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConduct regular design reviews or even a design guild to help designers embedded in product teams to remain connected to their peers\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eHiring humble, smart, complementary designers can be a daunting challenge as a new design leader. Defining your values, learning how to interview for hidden qualities, and giving yourself enough time to hire smart can help you build a first-class design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":2,"fields":{"book":["597"],"chapter_num":"02","sub_title":"Chemistry is key","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eHiring humble, smart, complementary designers can be a daunting challenge as a new design leader. Defining your values, learning how to interview for hidden qualities, and giving yourself enough time to make smart hires can help you build a first-class design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"","related":[{"title":"Designing the machine that designs the designs","url":"https://vimeo.com/166885565","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Building a Cohesive Design Team","url":"https://articles.uie.com/cohesive_design_teams/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"How to make firing people suck less for them and suck more for you","url":"https://m.signalvnoise.com/how-to-make-firing-people-suck-less-for-them-and-suck-more-for-you-977afb9ad15d#.lfqoijhkm","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"An Inside Look at Facebook's Method for Hiring Designers","url":"http://firstround.com/review/An-Inside-Look-at-Facebooks-Method-for-Hiring-Designers/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"The Power of the Elastic Product Team","url":"http://firstround.com/review/the-power-of-the-elastic-product-team-airbnbs-first-pm-on-how-to-build-your-own/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Defining Product Design: A Dispatch from Airbnb's Design Chief","url":"http://firstround.com/review/defining-product-design-a-dispatch-from-airbnbs-design-chief/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"DNA of Design","url":"https://medium.com/@daveixd/dna-of-design-e08e1a8a5543","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"The Imbalance of Culture Fit","url":"https://alistapart.com/article/the-imbalance-of-culture-fit","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Aarron Walter","author_link":"\u003ca href=\"http://aarronwalter.com\" title=\"Visit Aarron Walter\u0026#8217;s website\" rel=\"author external\"\u003eAarron Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_buildingtheteam.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Building the team - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Building a design team with chemistry and complementary skillsets should be one of your most important focuses as a design leader.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook/building-the-team"},{"id":905,"pid":0,"title":"Managing a design team","type":"chapter","date":"905","content":"\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1082]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe primary job of a manager is to manage the careers of others. Though management may not be your passion, it will be an important part of your work. As a design leader you’ll help people do great work and develop fulfilling careers, which can have a profound influence on your organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clayton_M._Christensen\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI used to think that if you cared for other people you need to study sociology or something like it. … I concluded if you want to help other people, be a manager. If done well, management is among the most noble of professions.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/christensen-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Clay Christensen\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eClay Christensen\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eHarvard Business School professor and author of The Innovator’s Dilemma\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “If done well, management is among the most noble of professions.” @claychristensen @HarvardHBS    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGreat managers are not bosses, they’re \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/servant-leadership\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eservant leaders\u003c/a\u003e who wield their power to help others. Your service will be an example to your entire team, and will encourage behaviors that will make your team strong. Your actions are a far more effective coaching tool than words alone!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@richarmstrong\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eRich Armstrong\u003c/a\u003e, the former COO of Trello, succinctly describes the responsibilities of a manager who serves his or her team and helps each person grow:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDiscover where their professional goals intersect with those of the organization.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRemove impediments to their achievement of those goals.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHold them accountable to move forward on those goals.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eShow them how far they’ve come from time to time.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eManagerial wisdom\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRich Armstrong, former COO of Trello, has written a series of brilliant articles on Medium that will help you become an effective manager. \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/servant-leadership/be-a-manager-3b0e39d87179#.pvg2ir79a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBe a manager\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/servant-leadership/how-to-be-a-manager-3400ca48de5e#.7j1nxvbns\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eHow to be a manager\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/servant-leadership/failure-as-a-service-937473b0c9b8#.65ykrnjvx\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFailure as Service.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe way to deliver on each of these responsibilities is to schedule 1-on-1 meetings with each team member.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e1-on-1 meetings\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e1-on-1 meetings are a great way for managers and their direct reports to connect individually on pressing issues, develop a strong relationship, and ensure that employees feel like they’re working toward \u003cem\u003etheir\u003c/em\u003e goals. These are not status update meetings; they’re an opportunity to give regular feedback and foster growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@richarmstrong\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe 1-on-1 is the only place where I get to connect with a person to help them and the company succeed. It’s where I get to find out what’s going on in the company without sticking my nose in and micromanaging.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/armstrong-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Rich Armstrong\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eRich Armstrong\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformer COO of Trello\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The 1-on-1 is the only place where I get to connect with a person to help them and the company succeed.” @richarmstrong    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeedback flows both ways. Smart managers ask team members for insight into how they could serve the team better. These honest conversations can help everyone improve.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e1-on-1s are also an important time to get to know each team member personally and build rapport. The complexities of life often follow us into work and can affect our performance. Making time for personal conversations can give you insight into a team member’s emotional state.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Horowitz\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhile it’s not the manager’s job to set the agenda or do the talking, the manager should try to draw the key issues out of the employee. The more introverted the employee the more important this becomes.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/horowitz-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Ben Horowitz\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBen Horowitz\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAndreessen Horowitz\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “\u0026#8230;the manager should try to draw the key issues out\u0026#8230;The more introverted the employee the more important this becomes.” @bhorowitz @a16z    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e15five\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can keep your 1-on-1s on track and make them more productive \u003ca href=\"https://www.15five.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eusing 15five.com\u003c/a\u003e. Each week, 15five.com emails team members a short survey that helps them reflect on their work. It takes them 15 minutes to complete, and you 5 minutes to review. Their responses will spark discussion in each 1-on-1 meeting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsk these sorts of questions in your 1-on-1s:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eShort term goals: \u003c/strong\u003eHow do you feel the project is going so far? Are there any projects you want to work on in the near future?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLong term goals:\u003c/strong\u003e What do you want to be doing in 5 years? What are your big dreams in life?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbout the company:\u003c/strong\u003e What is the company not doing today that we should do to better compete in the market? What’s 1 thing we’d be \u003cem\u003ecrazy\u003c/em\u003e not to do in the next quarter to improve our product?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSelf improvement: \u003c/strong\u003eDo you feel challenged at work? Are you learning new things? What area of the company would you like to learn more about?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eManager improvement:\u003c/strong\u003e What could I do as a manager to make your work easier? Would you like more or less direction from me on your work? How can I help you with your goals?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are so many important topics to cover. \u003ca href=\"https://jasonevanish.com/2014/05/29/101-questions-to-ask-in-1-on-1s/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eJason Evanish has published 101 questions for 1-on-1s\u003c/a\u003e, an invaluable source that will help you spark meaningful conversations with your team members.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSay thank you and celebrate\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith all of your responsibilities as a design leader, you’re going to be busy—very busy. As you focus on pushing projects forward and running your team, don’t forget that people need to be recognized for their contributions. Make a habit of saying “thank you” to each team member for their work. Everyone needs to hear it individually and as a team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter wrapping up a big project, take time to celebrate with your team. They need to feel a sense of accomplishment and recharge their batteries. If you move on to the next project without recognizing the team’s accomplishment, you risk them feeling empty and uninspired to climb the next mountain with you.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEtiquette tip:\u003c/strong\u003e Criticism during a celebration will just demoralize your team. Save your feedback about the project until after the celebration!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOn managing a UX team effectively\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/JosephDickerson\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eJoseph Dickerson\u003c/a\u003e, UX Pursuit Lead for Americas at Microsoft, echoes and expands on the design leadership guidance offered here in his Quora post entitled \u003ca href=\"https://www.quora.com/What-do-I-need-to-do-to-manage-a-UX-team-effectively\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eWhat Do I Need to do to Manage a UX Team Effectively\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-Report-2-450x340-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-Report-2-450x340-900x680.png\" alt=\"The business impact of design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe business impact of design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee how design impacts business and drives value at the world’s most innovative companies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1956 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSEE THE REPORT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1956 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1956:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eIntroducing new management layers\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs your team grows, you’ll need to introduce additional layers of management to keep the team and their projects on track. You’ll know it’s time when you no longer have enough hours for all of your 1-on-1 meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen you reach that point, you’ll be anxious to get extra help to relieve some stress, but fight the urge to take quick action. Putting the wrong person in a position of authority will only make your work harder.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen you’ve identified a prospective manager, assign them just 1 employee to manage and observe how they handle the shift in work. If they neglect their new management responsibilities in favor of design work, you know you’ve got the wrong person for the job.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the team member performs well, add additional direct reports and remove design tasks from their to-do list. Continue to monitor and coach them regularly to help them get their bearings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwitter has a unique approach to how they transition individual contributors into management. In other organizations, career growth is often closely connected to a company’s org chart—to make more money you have to become a manager, which incentivizes the wrong people into positions of power. In contrast, Twitter sees the transition into management as a lateral move, and there is no pay raise associated with it. Raises are performance-based, which incentivizes the right behavior—designers who want to further pursue their craft will develop their career without sacrificing their passions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/defining-product-design-a-dispatch-from-airbnbs-design-chief/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eManagement is not a promotion, but a separate track.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/schleifer-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Alex Schleifer\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAlex Schleifer\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAirbnb\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Management is not a promotion, but a separate track.” @alexoid @Airbnb    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRight person, right project\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are 2 very different types of designers: \u003cem\u003ehunters\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003efarmers\u003c/em\u003e. Each is essential to a design team, but—as Aarron Walter discovered while leading the UX team at MailChimp—when matched with the wrong project, chaos ensues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHunters and farmers\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe MailChimp UX team was shorthanded as it wrapped up a key project, and to help us meet a deadline I brought in another designer to help. The product workflow had been sorted out—we just needed some details polished. After reviewing the work in progress, the new designer immediately started redesigning everything. These were interesting ideas, but none of the work was in the project scope. In the end, the designer pushed the team further off course, making it even harder to hit the tight deadline.\u003cbr /\u003e\nI had sent a hunter to do a farmer’s work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLate 1 year, with some extra time on our hands, I asked 1 of my designers to begin exploring ideas for a major redesign of MailChimp. She created dozens of concepts, but I could see it wasn’t going well. Her stress was palpable. She continually sought guidance, but we had little to offer—we were venturing into new territory. After 2 months of exploration, she could take it no more—operating without constraints proved too stressful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI had sent a farmer to do a hunter’s work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePut your designers in a position to succeed by playing to their strengths, and look for traits in each of your designers to identify farmers and hunters:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFarmers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLove constraints, and feel lost without them\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEnjoy slogging through existing products to find a more refined design solution\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThrive on product iteration and refinement\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHunters\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExcited by freedom to wander—too many constraints deplete their energy\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eComfortable with uncertainty and unfamiliar territory\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThrive on new products and redesigns\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBob Dylan and Leonard Cohen\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll hear echoes of farmers and hunters in Malcolm Gladwell’s podcast \u003ca href=\"http://revisionisthistory.com/episodes/07-hallelujah\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eRevisionist History\u003c/a\u003e, in which he compares the creative processes of Dylan and Cohen, and Picasso and Cezanne. Turns out farmers and hunters exist in every creative medium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eResolving conflicts\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConflict is uncomfortable, but it’s inescapable as a design leader. When conflict arises in your team, confront it early to maintain the health of your team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach 1-on-1 meeting is an opportunity to listen for the stirrings of conflicts. Don’t wait until  deadlines are missed or the team seems ineffective. If a designer reports conflict between other team members, talk with everyone individually before taking action. Matters can be blown out of proportion when information is second hand, and you can make things worse if you act before you’re fully informed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen you’ve identified a conflict, get all parties in the same room to have an honest conversation. Let everyone have the opportunity to be heard, and don’t conclude the meeting until you’ve collectively identified a pathway to resolution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eKey takeaways\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConduct regular 1-on-1 meetings to establish rapport and foster career growth with each team member\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTake time to thank your team members and colleagues regularly. People need recognition to feel their work is valued.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen your team has reached a big milestone, celebrate. It’ll make your team closer and communicate your respect for their contributions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBefore moving someone into a management position, let them test the waters by managing 1 person. If they perform well, add additional direct reports.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAvoid pay increases when transitioning someone into management. It incentivizes the wrong people to seek positions of power.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePut your designers in a position to succeed by playing to their strengths. Pairing the right designer to the right project is key to keeping your team productive.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen conflict arises, do your research before you act. Trust, but verify the claims made by your team members.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eTo resolve conflict, get all parties in the same room to have an honest conversation. Let everyone have the opportunity to be heard.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"Team collaboration—in real time\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" collaboration\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1965 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTRY FREEHAND\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1965 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1965:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: servant leaders and coaches. Your best work will be in discovering your team’s talents and interests, and removing impediments to nurture personal and team growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":3,"fields":{"book":["597"],"chapter_num":"03","sub_title":"Serve and protect","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eManaging is a design manager’s primary job, but the best leaders aren’t bosses as much as servant leaders and coaches. Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam-1920x1080.png",1920,1080,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam.png",1920,1080,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_managingadesignteam.png",3840,2160,false]},"seo":{"title":"Managing a design team - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Successful design management springs from embracing servant leadership and coaching your team to uncover their greatest strengths.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook/managing-design-team"},{"id":896,"pid":0,"title":"Operationalizing design","type":"chapter","date":"896","content":"\u003cp\u003eTo do their best work and hit deadlines your team will need structure. They’ll need clarity on the work happening within the team, and regular feedback at each step of a project. By formalizing the feedback process, you’ll help your team operationalize their work without compromising on quality.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/dustin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYou know you have a healthy design culture when people are giving each other feedback.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/senos-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Dustin Senos v2\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDustin Senos\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformer head of design, Medium\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “You know you have a healthy design culture when people are giving each other feedback.” @DustinDustiniw    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding feedback into your design practice will help in so many ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYou’ll avoid spending too much time on a design that may have significant flaws\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYou’ll gain multiple perspectives on a single problem, helping the designer get closer to an effective solution faster\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePresenting work for feedback will keep your team synced on project progress, and hold everyone accountable to milestones and deadlines\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs designers get in the habit of presenting their work and giving feedback to others, they’ll learn to think more clearly about their design decisions, and become comfortable articulating their ideas\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRegular feedback processes will give junior designers the opportunity to learn from senior designers, helping your entire team level up\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first step to operationalizing feedback in your team is thinking carefully about how designs are shared.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-Report-2-450x340-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-Report-2-450x340-900x680.png\" alt=\"The business impact of design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe business impact of design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee how design impacts business and drives value at the world’s most innovative companies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1956 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSEE THE REPORT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1956 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1956:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSetting the stage for feedback\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy changing your space to create the right environment, you can set the stage for feedback and collaboration in your team. For distributed and remote teams, this is doubly important—establishing dedicated times and places for sharing works in progress keeps everyone connected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIn person\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe walls of your design studio are a sacred space. This is where your team’s ideas can be shared, debated, retooled, and celebrated. Make it clear to your team that the studio walls are not a gallery—this is work space!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you don’t already have one, invest in a large format printer and get the whole team connected. Print design work daily and post to your studio walls for scheduled design reviews and casual conversations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf your walls aren’t ideal for posting work, you can buy \u003ca href=\"http://www.uline.com/Product/Detail/S-19382/Foam-Board/Foamboard-48-x-96-Black-White\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e8-foot by 4-foot sheets of foam core\u003c/a\u003e and lean them against your walls. Get some \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00DKI9816/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003enice Washi tape\u003c/a\u003e to post your designs in style (and easily peel off later). Leave markers and sticky notes nearby so your team and anyone in the company can easily jot down a bit of feedback and post it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@george_aye/always-show-your-work-why-designers-write-on-the-walls-and-why-you-should-too-6725237b9765#.4ysk8o8ju\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOur work is plastered and posted all over the walls of the studio — not finished things, but notes, photos, and artifacts of what we’re working on. Over time, we see projects unfolding as they’re posted, and we can give each other feedback along the way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy sticking your work up on a wall, you invite an ongoing dialogue about making your project better. It makes your work tangible, shareable and visual, which gives it a much better chance of receiving feedback and critique.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/eye-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"George Aye\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGeorge Aye\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGreater Good Studio\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “By sticking your work up on a wall, you invite an ongoing dialogue about making your project better.” @georgeaye    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe design team at Greater Good Studio has gone so far as to create \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/greater-good-studio/always-show-your-work-why-designers-write-on-the-walls-and-why-you-should-too-6725237b9765#.rtt49k451\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eproject bays, a modular space to post work for critical discussion\u003c/a\u003e. Each new project they begin gets its own bay—a physical manifestation of their progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/designbetter_website_designleadershiphandbook_images_projectbay.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: A project bay at Greater Good Studio.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe fidelity of the work you post can influence the feedback you get. Pixel-perfect comps may lead others to believe the work is finished, which will inhibit feedback. Work that’s a little lower fidelity or with notes scribbled on it will make it clear to all that you’re still working through ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/RMBanfield\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBuilding a safe place for your team to be creative and do their best work might be the most useful thing a leader can do for culture in design focused organizations.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/banfield-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Richard Banfield\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eRichard Banfield\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eauthor of Design Leadership\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Building a safe place for your team to be creative\u0026#8230;might be the most useful thing a leader can do…” @RMBanfield    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDon\u0026#8217;t forget the screen\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBe sure to work through design ideas on the screen too. Interaction design, animation, and responsive design aren’t easily communicated on the printed page. Print brings more people into the conversation (which is important!) but ultimately you’ll need to solve for screen display.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRemote\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemote teams can also set the stage for feedback using tools like \u003ca href=\"https://slack.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSlack\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://trello.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTrello\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://google.com/hangouts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGoogle Hangouts\u003c/a\u003e, and of course, \u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com\"\u003eInVision\u003c/a\u003e. The entire design team at InVision is distributed and uses their own product to conduct design reviews. \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/1l32uaywf2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLiveShare\u003c/a\u003e, a design collaboration feature in InVision, lets the team present their work and get real-time feedback. Early ideas are explored with \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/ywsy00uhef\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBoards\u003c/a\u003e, later becoming \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/rawbkwpnr2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrototypes\u003c/a\u003e that are again shared with the team for feedback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith so many affordable tools at hand, remote teams can easily build feedback into their design process too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the stage set for feedback in your team, you’re ready to establish the format for each type of feedback your team will need.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eOperationalizing the feedback process\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigning out in the open is just the first step. Your team will also need to get feedback on their designs, sync with teammates to make sure progress is being made, and learn from mistakes so they can improve. This is a tall order, and calls for different types of feedback processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet’s take a look at a few ways to get your team the right feedback at the right time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1015]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesign reviews\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e All the time! They’ll keep your team moving forward\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there:\u003c/strong\u003e The designer plus no more than 7 people\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Designers get the feedback they need to refine their work\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign reviews are critiques that let designers get detailed feedback that’s framed by the project goals. Design reviews can happen at a number of different points in a project. It’s often helpful to do one early on so the designer can get fresh perspectives before investing too much time in an idea that may be misguided. The midway point and toward the end of a project are also natural times to get additional inputs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNever use a design review as a big reveal of project. If you wait until you have everything polished, you’ll be too invested to accept the feedback you’re given.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign reviews are a great opportunity to bring in experts from other teams to make the work better. Colleagues from support, engineering, product management, QA, legal, marketing, or even an executive may have a new perspective to help you see the problem differently. But try not to overload the guest list in these reviews—too many people and you’ll have a hard time guiding the conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDesign reviews at GV\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Google Ventures team has written \u003ca href=\"https://library.gv.com/guide-to-design-critique-86ebf499bed5#.9gdwtr7iv\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea nice guide to conducting design reviews\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesign standups\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e Daily for large or distributed teams, less often for small teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there: \u003c/strong\u003eEveryone on the design team\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Your team gets the chance to sync up on projects\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign standups are short, daily check-ins that help your team stay abreast of the work that’s being done. As the name suggests, everyone remains standing in these meetings so no one can get comfortable enough to launch into a soliloquy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a standup, each team member answers 3 questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat did you do yesterday?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat will you do today?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAre there any impediments, or blockers, in your way?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile most teams choose to conduct standups in the morning, you may want to consider doing them after lunch—the morning is when our minds are clearest and ready to focus on creative work. For remote teams, pick a time that accommodates multiple time zones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t let standups turn into impromptu design critiques. If someone needs immediate design feedback, ask that they hold the request until after the meeting—a standup should be short and focused on project progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRetrospectives\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e After a project is launched or a sprint is completed\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there:\u003c/strong\u003e Everyone who worked on the project\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Your team will internalize lessons from each project\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery project is a learning opportunity, but if you don’t pause to take stock, valuable lessons will slip away. When you’ve launched a project or completed a sprint, it’s a great time to reflect on what went well, what was confusing, and what \u003cem\u003edidn’t\u003c/em\u003e go so well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/thinmatt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMatt Spiel\u003c/a\u003e, Director of Design at \u003ca href=\"http://teamtreehouse.com\"\u003eTreehouse\u003c/a\u003e, conducts retrospective meetings regularly. He sends a pre-retrospective survey to the team before the meeting to capture each person’s perspective individually. This helps to eliminate the \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandwagon_effect\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ebandwagon effect\u003c/a\u003e, which happens when the views of the group conform to those of a few vocal people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/thinmatt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eRetrospectives are a valuable tool to use because they help teams identify strengths and weaknesses. They help provide the designers at Treehouse an opportunity to give feedback on our processes in order to grow and improve.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/speil-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Matt Spiel\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMatt Spiel\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eTreehouse\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Retrospectives are a valuable tool to use because they help teams identify strengths and weaknesses.” @thinmatt @treehouse    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMatt asks his team to rate their performance both as a group and as individuals on a scale from 1 to 5, where 5 is the highest. Ratings tend to cluster in a similar spot, but occasionally there are outliers. Team members who’ve given starkly different ratings are asked to share their views in the meeting to promote transparency and honesty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiscussion in Treehouse’s retrospective meetings is centered around 3 questions common to most Agile retrospectives:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat worked well for us?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat didn’t work well for us?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat can we do to improve our process?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese questions are sometimes referred to as Start, Stop, Keep—what should we start doing, stop doing, and keep doing?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHonest conversation about each of these questions becomes easier with the cultivation of trust and plenty of practice running retrospective meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePostmortems\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e After a project has gone poorly\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there:\u003c/strong\u003e Everyone who worked on the project and an impartial facilitator\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Your team will learn from their mistakes and find a way forward\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot all projects go well. Some go horribly wrong, requiring all teams involved in the project to come together to consider and learn from the mistakes they made.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough projects rarely go awry at Etsy, they’ve established a strong process to guide them through those that do. Their process follows many of the recommendations set forth in the Agile methodology.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s how to run a postmortem:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBefore the meeting: \u003c/strong\u003eSend an email asking the team to identify key points in the project timeline. This will be used to construct a master timeline of events, which will be discussed in the meeting. By focusing on events, you’ll avoid negative finger pointing, which can derail the process.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eModerator: \u003c/strong\u003eChoose a moderator who wasn’t on the project and can be impartial. This person should be guiding the conversation from the whiteboard, taking notes for all to see.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGround rules:\u003c/strong\u003e The moderator should first point out that this is not a blame session, but an opportunity to learn. It’s a conversation about the shortcomings of the team’s process, not the people involved.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFacts:\u003c/strong\u003e People recall events differently. The moderator can help the team agree upon what \u003cem\u003eactually\u003c/em\u003e happened so lessons can be extracted. Establishing a timeline of events can help pinpoint where things went wrong.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLessons and actions:\u003c/strong\u003e As key lessons are identified, they should be written on the whiteboard for all to see. The actions required to mitigate the problems stemming from the failed project also need to be identified, assigned an owner, and provided a clear deadline.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter the meeting:\u003c/strong\u003e The lessons learned from the postmortem should be emailed to the entire team, along with the action items that are to be completed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePostmortems can seem rough, but they’re far superior to repeating the same mistakes. They’re a powerful opportunity for your team to learn and improve your processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce your team’s operations are sound, you need to start thinking beyond your borders. How will you interact with other teams in the company? This challenge is less about operations, and more about just getting to know people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eKey takeaways\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBuild a culture of feedback help your team grow\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGet your team in the habit of posting their work for all to see. Feedback comes more naturally when you create the right environment.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf your team is remote, set the stage for feedback using tools like \u003ca href=\"https://slack.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSlack\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://trello.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTrello\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://google.com/hangouts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGoogle Hangouts\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConduct regular design reviews to give designers detailed feedback framed by the project goals\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConduct design standups regularly to help your team stay abreast of the work that’s being done\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAt the end of each project, hold a retrospective meeting to collect the lessons learned and continuously improve your team processes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen projects go poorly, run a postmortem meeting to learn from your mistakes without finger pointing\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: #e41d32;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Thinking-Book-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-thinking\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: transformation\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-thinking\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1616 creative while still hitting their deadlines. Building a structure for useful feedback and transparency fosters a healthy design team culture.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":4,"fields":{"book":["597"],"chapter_num":"04","sub_title":"Build the process","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eCreating clear, straightforward design structures frees your team to be their most creative while still hitting their deadlines. Building a structure for useful feedback and transparency fosters a healthy design team culture.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"","related":[{"title":"Design Doesn’t Scale","url":"https://medium.com/@hellostanley/design-doesnt-scale-4d81e12cbc3e#.mtmkn0hq7","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"To Build Great Products, Build This Strong, Scalable System
