design - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Free your team to do their best work by providing structure and tools for embedding design feedback into their work, including design reviews and standups.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook/operationalizing-design"},{"id":901,"pid":0,"title":"Forging alliances","type":"chapter","date":"901","content":"\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ericquint3mcdo/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eFirst and foremost, a design leader needs to be empathetic, driven by curiosity to observe people beyond just dialogue. This will support design leaders to better understand the needs of customers to initiate relevant innovations, drive great design leadership amongst their creative talent, and enable cross-functional collaboration with colleagues.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/quint-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Eric Quint (2)\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eEric Quint\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003e3M\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “First and foremost, a design leader needs to be empathetic, driven by curiosity to observe people beyond just dialogue.” @3M CDO Eric Quint    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGreat design leaders recognize that their team’s work is but one piece of the broader ecosystem of their organization. Engineering, Product management, Research, Support and many other teams play important roles in creating a great user experience. You’ll need to build social capital across your organization by developing rapport with your colleagues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1033]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGet in the habit of stepping away from your computer to get to know people. Grab lunch with a developer who may build out your team’s next design. No need for an agenda—just get to know each other. Spend time with researchers who have their finger on the pulse of your customers, sales people who hear frequent requests, product managers who understand schedules and scope, and customer service agents who know where users struggle the most. All have valuable context to offer you and your team. Each one influences the success of your team’s work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/mopland\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYour legs are your most effective design tool. Get out and connect with people.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/opland-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Mark Opland\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMark Opland\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFacebook\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Your legs are your most effective design tool. Get out and connect with people.” @mopland @facebook    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDesign leadership: How top design leaders build and grow successful organizations\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Design-Leadership-Leaders-Successful-Organizations/dp/1491929200/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIn this handy little book\u003c/a\u003e, Richard Banfield shares findings from interviews with a number of veteran design leaders, exploring a wide range of topics from shaping culture to leadership styles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd don’t just network laterally—spend time with different stakeholders and executives to understand their roles and expectations. Ask questions about the broader strategy of the company. You’ll need to understand the big picture to design products that fit into the company vision.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/helloryanpage\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWe see our greatest successes when we involve the right people along the way.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/page-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Ryan Page\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eRyan Page\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eCapital One\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “We see our greatest successes when we involve the right people along the way.” @helloryanpage @CapitalOne    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you become connected to colleagues on other teams, not only will your team’s designs be more informed, you’ll also put design on everyone’s radar, which is critically important. Your conversations will educate the rest of the company about design as a function, profession, and mindset. Your outreach to colleagues over time can change your company\u0026#8217;s culture, making it  more compatible with the needs of designers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Subscribe-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/subscribe\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET ON THE LIST\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Subscribe-small_2x-760x760.png\" alt=\"Get insider access\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/subscribe\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET ON THE LIST\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGet insider access\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBe the first to get content from design innovators like Automattic\u0026#8217;s John Maeda\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/subscribe\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1668 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET ON THE LIST\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGET ON THE LIST\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1668 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1668:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMaking inroads\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1811]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign is often protected—intentionally or not—from those who are perceived to be outside the process. That’s a shame, as often there are experts that are excluded simply because they don’t move in the same social circles at work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s important to bring stakeholders into the design process early and often to get feedback and fresh perspectives. Sharing your work digitally makes it easy to gather feedback from specific people, but there’s value in setting the stage for unsolicited feedback too. As mentioned in the previous section, surprising things happen when you print screens and post them in a space where passersby can catch a glimpse. Leave Post-it notes and pens nearby and see what happens—you’ll get surprising feedback from unexpected sources with this approach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike digital, print is persistent and casual. It invites spontaneous participation even when you’re not around, which is perhaps its greatest strength. Take note of who leaves useful feedback so you can include them when you share your team’s next prototype.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen design is accessible to all, the process feels inclusive.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRegularly scheduled design reviews can be a great way to not only keep your design team synced, but to forge connections with other teams. At the health tech company \u003ca href=\"http://counsyl.com\"\u003eCounsyl\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/martinibot\"\u003eLaura Martini\u003c/a\u003e (now at Google) made a habit of inviting engineers and execs to design reviews to get new perspective for her team, but also to put design on people’s minds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/martinibot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI often invited influential people in the company to my team’s design reviews so our work remained visible. My team was a little nervous about showing their early work to company leaders, but I knew it was important to do.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/martini-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Laura Martini\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eLaura Martini\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGoogle \u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “I often invited influential people in the company to my team’s design reviews so our work remained visible.” @martinibot    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eEmpathy at scale\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn his article for 99U, \u003ca href=\"http://99u.com/articles/52189/how-to-be-a-designer-at-a-large-company-3m\"\u003eThe Subtle Art of Being a Designer at a Massive Company\u003c/a\u003e,  3M’s global head of design Eric Quint talks about how he translates empathy for customers to empathy for his colleagues, helping him build inroads into design within a massive organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to design reviews, you can make colleagues aware of the work happening inside the design team by delivering presentations as a coffee hour or a lunch and learn. You can present your work on an important project, or deliver \u003ca href=\"http://dschool.stanford.edu/dgift/\"\u003ea crash course in Design Thinking\u003c/a\u003e. Create a design Slack channel to share books and articles with those who want to learn more about your discipline, and share updates on your work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1040]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe more visible your team is in your company, the easier it will be to connect and collaborate with other teams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-medium-v1_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-medium-v1_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Power your design workflow\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003ePower your design workflow\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiscover seamless collaboration with InVision—the product design platform powering the world’s best teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1996 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGET STARTED NOW\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1996 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1996:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEducating your company about design\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1803]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven if your team is already visible within the company, it can be challenging to find ways to focus the company culture on design without hiring more design resources. One method is to find alternate means of educating non-design colleagues about how designers solve problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt Netflix, Andy Law approaches this in several different ways. Once a quarter, Netflix holds a “UX Progressive,” where engineers and others can visit a designer’s desk to get a demo of current work in progress. Andy has also used screenings of InVision’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.designdisruptors.com?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDESIGN DISRUPTORS\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e film as a way to educate colleagues about design: “There are a lot of people interested in how designers approach and solve a problem, and \u003cem\u003eDESIGN DISRUPTORS\u003c/em\u003e does a really good job of synthesizing what that is.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother approach is to host one-on-one sessions with colleagues who are interested in learning more about design, or who seek design help with a project. When Irene Au was at Google, the design team held weekly “office hours” where colleagues could come with questions and get feedback on their projects.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo matter the approach, educating colleagues about design and empowering them to use elements of the design process offer opportunities to increase the visibility and influence of design within your company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/product-design-industry-report-2016?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDesign plays a key role in 38% of the world\u0026#8217;s largest organizations\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eKey takeaways\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet design review days on your team’s calendar and invite specific people to participate\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYour org chart is not a list of names; it’s a group of potential allies. Get to know them.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePost your work in an accessible space. Present your work at company coffee hours. Talk about your work and answer questions in a company Slack channel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSolicit feedback every step of the way. This isn’t design by committee, but good ideas—and constructive criticism—can come from anywhere.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFind opportunities to educate your company about design (UX progressives, film screenings, office hours).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eThere’s no room for design leaders to be lone wolves. Just as design work benefits from collaboration, you’ll enhance the conversation around design by gathering allies and building relationships with Engineering, Product, Support, and more. \u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":5,"fields":{"book":["597"],"chapter_num":"05","sub_title":"Design is a team sport","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThere’s no room for design leaders to be lone wolves. Just as design work benefits from collaboration, you’ll enhance the conversation around design by gathering allies and building relationships with engineering, product, support, and more. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"","related":[{"title":"Fast Path to a Great UX — Increased Exposure Hours","url":"https://medium.com/@jmspool/fast-path-to-a-great-ux-increased-exposure-hours-afde796f2e43#.z3lia29dr","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"3 lessons learned from leading design at a high-growth startup","url":"http://blog.invisionapp.com/leading-design-high-growth-startup/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances-1920x1080.png",1920,1080,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances.png",1920,1080,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designleadershiphandbook_forgealliances.png",3840,2160,false]},"seo":{"title":"Forging alliances - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Changing the culture around design at an organization takes a coalition and relationship-building. Learn how to educate your company about design.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook/forging-alliances"},{"id":908,"pid":0,"title":"Shaping design vision","type":"chapter","date":"908","content":"\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1045]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat is it about reading a good story that makes it seem so effortless? In \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/The-Storytelling-Animal-Stories-Human/dp/0544002342\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Storytelling Animal: How Stories Make Us Human\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, \u003c/em\u003eJonathan Gottschall writes:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“\u0026#8230;authors trick us into doing most of the imaginative work. Reading is often seen as a passive act: we lie back and let writers pipe joy into our brains. But this is wrong. When we experience a story, our minds are churning, working hard.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe evolved as storytelling creatures, and the power of story has never left us. As companies scale and teams sprint through product iterations, it’s easy to lose sight of how your product should fit into the lives of your customers. The best way to keep everyone pointed in the right direction is with a clear, compelling story—a story that will unite and guide teams toward success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI think what’s most important is you have to have a North Star or vision set. If people don’t have that, the mess builds up.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/wood-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Stanley Wood\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eStanley Wood\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eSpotify\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “\u0026#8230;you have to have a North Star or vision set. If people don’t have that, the mess builds up.” @hellostanley @spotify    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/blog/secrets-design-leadership?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSecrets of design leadership—from Stanley Wood of Spotify\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct roadmaps guide team milestones, but they only show us \u003cem\u003ewhat\u003c/em\u003e to build and \u003cem\u003ewhen\u003c/em\u003e. They don’t show us \u003cem\u003ewhy\u003c/em\u003e we’re building a product. Stories, however, are great at explaining why. In \u003cem\u003eStart with Why\u003c/em\u003e, author Simon Sinek proclaims that, “People don\u0026#8217;t buy what you do; they buy why you do it. And what you do simply proves what you believe.” Similarly, the best product teams don’t merely \u003cem\u003efollow\u003c/em\u003e a process; they march toward a shared destination—a vision of the future presented as a story that answers, “Why are we building this?”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTalking about the why\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@joulee\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhat I’m starting to gain a greater appreciation for is that the best results are achieved not by talking about the how, but by talking about the why.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/zhuo-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Julie Zhuo (2)\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJulie Zhuo\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFacebook\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The best results are achieved not by talking about the how, but by talking about the why.” @joulee @facebook    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign leaders need to craft the vision for a product and communicate how it fits into the lives of others. There are many mediums for conveying this story; some design teams create large boards that show design style or tell the story of how their product will fit into the lives of their customers. Others create short videos to illustrate to all how the product will fit into the customer’s lifestyle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eStart with why\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.startwithwhy.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eStart With Why: How great leaders inspire everyone to take action\u003c/a\u003e is a manifesto for those who want to inspire others and for those who want to find someone to inspire them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile preparing for a major app redesign, the UX team Aarron Walter led at MailChimp produced \u003ca href=\"https://vimeo.com/97337160\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea vision video to guide the company\u003c/a\u003e on what was to be a 4-month project.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe research team had noticed after a number of customer visits that people were doing work differently. Persistent internet connections on phones and tablets let people work anywhere and all the time, ducking in and out of small tasks. This created a sense of found time that was quickly being filled up with more to-dos.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs people became overwhelmed with their work, they needed to hand things off to others. Seeing these behavioral patterns, the UX team realized they needed to rethink how MailChimp handled collaboration across many devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe project required the collaboration of many teams. They wrote a short script and worked with their in-house videographer to produce a brief vision video in about 10 days.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1053]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe production was inexpensive and relatively fast, but the outcome was of high enough fidelity to guide designers, developers, marketers, and other stakeholders around the company as they worked to realize the vision set forth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSketches and storyboards are another great medium for conveying stories. \u003ca href=\"http://www.fastcompany.com/3002813/how-snow-white-helped-airbnbs-mobile-mission\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAirbnb worked with Pixar illustrators to create storyboards\u003c/a\u003e that showed how their products would fit into the lives of their customers. Their storyboard gave everyone a vision of the product experience they wanted while still giving each team the freedom to solve the problems as they saw fit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;284128829\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe storytelling mechanism you choose is less important than the story you tell. The act of creating a product story before you begin the design process not only helps you mobilize your teams, it also forces you to clarify your intentions for your product. You’ll step out of the maker’s mindset and consider how your product will fit into the lives of others.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVision—whether presented through a video, storyboard, or some other means—gives purpose and clarity to our work. Without it teams often lose sight of their mission.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1056]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWhen you come to a fork in the road, take it\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs design leaders, we are often thinking and communicating in terms of how design ties into company strategy, and we become less focused on craft. This is just a normal part of how a role evolves as responsibilities grow. As a company scales, CTOs don’t often do much coding, and CMOs rarely have time to write a blog post or draft an email campaign.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut as designers, we are in a somewhat unique position where our craft can inform our thinking. Don Norman, Director of the Design Lab at University of California, San Diego, writes about the tension between craft and design thinking in his essay \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/future-design-when-you-come-fork-road-take-don-norman\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Future of Design: When You Come to a Fork in the Road, Take It\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe fork in the road does not have to be a choice between two options: this is an opportunity to pursue both. Design as a craft has a long history of providing great value to humankind. Design thinking is as yet unproven, but it has the potential to provide a different kind of value to the world. Both are essential, so let us take the fork in both directions.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Don’s view, we don’t necessarily have to give up the craft of design to become leaders, or to convey the vision for a product. In fact, this vision could be stronger if we “learn and think by drawing and doing.” So sharpen your pencils, dust off your sketchbook, and start telling better stories to guide your team to success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"START YOUR DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-medium_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Powering enterprise design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003ePowering enterprise design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTransform your organization with InVision Enterprise—trusted by more than 75% of the Fortune communicate how it fits into the lives of others. This will serve as the North Star guiding all teams.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse story to communicate a design vision. Video, storyboards, and comics are all great mediums to show colleagues the future you’re creating for your customers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003eConclusion\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eOur hope is that, after combing through this guide and the readings we’ve recommended, you feel better equipped to lead your team. You now know how to build and manage a team, you have a plan to operationalize design, you recognize that you’ll need to forge alliances to be effective, and you know how to shape a cohesive design vision so everyone in your organization has a North Star to guide their work.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThough your learning curve as a design leader is steep, the rewards are great. You’re in a position to influence the trajectory of your team and your entire organization—that’s exciting.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eDesign leaders like you will reshape teams, companies, and ultimately our industry. Your wisdom will grow with practice, and as it does we hope you’ll share what you’ve learned with others. Leaders teach, and in doing so the depths of their wisdom deepens.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThank you for being a leader! design vision - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Guide your design team toward success with a clear, compelling story. As a design leader, you shape your team and organization's shared design vision.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-leadership-handbook/shaping-design-vision"},{"id":565,"pid":0,"title":"Why we need design thinking","type":"chapter","date":"565","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn 1958, 4 months after Sputnik launched and President Eisenhower created NASA, a Stanford engineering professor named John Arnold proposed that \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_Joint_Program_in_Design\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003edesign engineering should be human-centered\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThis was a strange thing for Arnold to introduce. This was an era in which engineers were largely focused on twin Cold War driven goals: the space race and the optimization of the hydrogen bomb. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eInspired by Arnold’s work, engineering professor Bob McKim, with the help of art professor Matt Kahn, created an engineering program called Product Design. Within this program, McKim and others helped create a \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003edesign thinking\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e process that became the foundation for Stanford’s d.school, as well as the guiding framework for design-driven companies like IDEO. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eJust as the space race resulted in the invention of Velcro and satellite communications, design thinking plays a large role in how we interact with computers (the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ideo.com/case-study/creating-the-first-usable-mouse\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003emouse\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e and \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ideo.com/case-study/the-first-notebook-style-computer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003enotebook\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e), how we \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://kpinnovation.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003edeliver our healthcare\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e, and how we \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://futureofwork.nobl.io/future-of-work/how-capital-one-convinced-teams-to-use-design-thinking\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003edo our banking now and in the future\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://www.ideo.com/about\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDesign thinking is a human-centered approach to innovation that draws from the designer\u0026#8217;s toolkit to integrate the needs of people, the possibilities of technology, and the requirements for business success.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/brown-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Tim Brown\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eTim Brown\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eIDEO\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Design thinking is a human-centered approach to innovation…” @tceb62 @IDEO    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhy has design thinking been embraced not only by forward-thinking innovators like IDEO but large enterprises like IBM? For one, it brings everyone into the process, not just designers; using the design process helps companies solve \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wicked_problem\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ewicked problems\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e with clear eyes.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eDesign thinking also helps scale the design process through large organizations.  Business leaders who use the shared vocabulary and toolset of design thinking can confidently create better, human-centered user experiences and disruptive products.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:792]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: team\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBring DesignBetter.Co to your team with our design workshops—coming soon\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1661 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eREQUEST A WORKSHOP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1661 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1661:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eFinally, design thinking helps to instill a bias towards action, balanced with a user-centered perspective that guides the team towards the right outcome.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe design thinking process is not necessarily linear, nor is there one canonical way to approach it; it is an iterative system with many variations. However, \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://dschool.stanford.edu/dgift/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eStanford’s d.school teaches a framework\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e that can help jump-start the process for almost any problem:\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/design_thinking_framework-04-03_700px.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStanford d.school\u0026#8217;s design thinking framework.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWe’ll walk you through the 5 steps of this design thinking framework, which will provide a toolkit for design challenges large and small in your organization.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe core of the design thinking approach is a focus on \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/empathize/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eempathy\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e, or using a beginner’s mindset and immersing yourself in the user’s experience to uncover deep needs and insights. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/define/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eDefining\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e the problem with a point of view (POV) is a key part of the process: \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ewho \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eis your user (with as many specific details as possible); \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ewhat \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eis their deep, unmet need; \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ewhy \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eis this insightful (what insights did you glean from your empathetic needfinding process?). Often, reframing the problem using a unique POV will lead to more innovative solution spaces.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe design thinking process goes through a cycle of generative flaring and selective focusing. In the definition phase, we narrowed down to a specific Point of View; now, in the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/ideate/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eideation\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e phase, we flare out and generate as many ideas as possible.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eFor many designers, \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/prototype/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eprototyping\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e is where the fun begins. Sometimes the key to good empathy is sharing or co-creating a prototype with your users and getting feedback. Prototyping helps us learn, solve disagreements, and test hypotheses quickly and with minimal repercussions.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eBy \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/test/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003etesting\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e our prototypes with real users and getting feedback, we can refine our POV, learn more about our users, and make the next iteration of the product that much better. As they say at Stanford’s d.school: \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e“Prototype as if you know you’re right, but test as if you know you’re wrong.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThese steps should be considered a way to get started with design thinking. Over time, you will adapt them to your working style and make them your own. With this flexible toolkit, you’ll be prepared to tackle any project, from a new app to—perhaps—new NASA moonshots.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWith thanks to \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/wburnett\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eBill Burnett\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e, executive director of the Design Program at Stanford, for giving the lecture that inspired this introduction.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/STS-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.switchtosketchapp.com/?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LEARN SKETCH\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/STS-small_2x-760x760.png\" alt=\"Switch to Sketch\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.switchtosketchapp.com/?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LEARN SKETCH\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSwitch to Sketch\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLearn the basics of Sketch to accelerate your design workflow\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.switchtosketchapp.com/?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1987 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LEARN SKETCH\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLEARN SKETCH\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1987 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1987:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eIn 1958, 4 months after Sputnik launched and President Eisenhower created NASA, a Stanford engineering professor named John Arnold proposed that design engineering should be human-centered. This was a strange thing for Arnold to introduce. This was an era in which engineers were largely focused on twin Cold War driven goals: the space race and [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":6,"fields":{"book":["562"],"chapter_num":"01","sub_title":"Tackle complex challenges","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhat is design thinking? More than a methodology or framework, design thinking combines the problem-solving roots of design with deep empathy for the user. The design thinking-based framework popularized by the Stanford d.school can help your team take on the thorniest challenges with insightful solutions. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn this guide, you’ll learn how to put design thinking into practice in your organization.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":""},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_why.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Why we need design thinking - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"What is design thinking? More than a methodology or framework, design thinking combines the problem-solving roots of design with deep empathy for the user.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-thinking/why-we-need-design-thinking"},{"id":606,"pid":0,"title":"Empathize","type":"chapter","date":"606","content":"\u003cp\u003eImagine that you live in a remote village in Nepal. It’s winter and freezing sleet pounds the nearby roads, making them nearly impassable. You’ve just had your first baby, a little girl, and she’s premature and severely underweight. The room that you’re in, while warm to you, feels like an ice-bath to the baby. Without help soon, she will almost certainly die from hypothermia. What do you do?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWorldwide, about 15 million premature babies are born every year and the most common preventable cause of infant mortality is hypothermia. As designers, we solve the problems of others, and solving the problem of infant mortality due to hypothermia seems like an extremely worthy design challenge. This is exactly what a team from Stanford’s d.school set out to accomplish as a project for the class Design for Extreme Affordability (often known just as “Extreme”).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe team ended up with a novel, innovative solution—but they never would’ve arrived there if they remained within the bubble of Stanford’s campus. They needed empathy to see the problem clearly from the perspective of hospital staff, doctors, and most importantly, parents of the child in danger.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInitially, the design team thought redesigning existing hospital incubators to be simpler and more cost effective would be the easiest solution. But when team member \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/liang_linus\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLinus Liang\u003c/a\u003e toured a hospital in Nepal, he noticed something strange—the incubators were sitting empty. After interviewing a doctor about this, he learned that many homes where these babies were born were 30 or more miles away on rough rural roads, and that the parents faced the fight for their babies’ lives at home, without much hope of making it to a hospital.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Extreme team used this insight to inform their decisions about the product’s direction. Instead of a cheaper incubator (the initial concept, but likely ineffective given the evidence) they decided to design something to help babies at home: a portable incubator, much like a tiny, heated sleeping bag, which they named \u003ca href=\"http://embraceglobal.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEmbrace\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tceb62\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEmpathy is at the heart of design\u003c/strong\u003e. Without the understanding of what others see, feel, and experience, design is a pointless task.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/brown-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Tim Brown\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eTim Brown\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eIDEO\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Empathy is the heart of design.” @tceb62 @IDEO    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile prototyping the Embrace, the team interviewed many moms, healthcare workers, and shopkeepers who helped them iterate on solutions. By showing prototypes, they learned about critical barriers to adoption:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn a village in India, a mother explained they believe Western medicines are very powerful, so villagers often halve doses. The warmer on the Embrace had a temperature indicator, and this mother indicated that other mothers would only heat it halfway to the ideal temperature. This information led the team to iterate on the design, removing the temperature strip and changing the design to showcase an “OK” indicator.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe team also learned that in many communities, electricity is unavailable or unreliable. So they designed a version of the warmer that could be heated using hot water.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/WarmerPage_EmbraceWarmer_v5.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: The Embrace infant warmer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith these insights, the team was able to create a product that was easy to use correctly in the locations it was designed for. They formed a company based on this product, grew it to 90 people, and have helped over 3,000 babies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy using empathy and focusing on the people who would use the product—in this team’s case, a literal journey that exposed them to the feelings and challenges of their users—the Embrace team came up with a product that saves lives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Podcast-Featured-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast/david-kelley\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Podcast-Featured-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"David Kelley on the DesignBetter.Co Podcast\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast/david-kelley\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eDavid Kelley on the DesignBetter.Co Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHear IDEO and Stanford d.school founder David Kelley talk about creative confidence and much more\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast/david-kelley\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-2019 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLISTEN NOW\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-2019 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-2019:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePracticing empathy\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmpathy is the foundation of the whole design thinking process. Using a \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/salesforce-ux/beginner-s-mind-62a28d144a5c#.6kwfmlqwk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ebeginner’s mindset\u003c/a\u003e and immersing yourself in the user’s experience is a great way to uncover deep needs and insights. It also ties directly to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/guess-less/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGuess less\u003c/a\u003e principle of product design. In this Empathize section of our course, we’ll dive into a case study where empathy helped create an innovative product for Bank of America. We’ll then walk through some exercises you can employ to gain more empathy for, and insights from, your own users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow can empathy help us design better products? To find out, try this exercise, adapted from the \u003ca href=\"https://dschool.stanford.edu/groups/designresources/wiki/4dbb2/The_Wallet_Project.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eWallet Project \u003c/a\u003eexercise taught at Stanford’s d.school. It should only take about 15 minutes. (Go ahead, we’ll wait for you.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-exercise:642]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCase study: \u003c/strong\u003eIDEO and Bank of America’s Keep the Change program\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://www.christianmarcschmidt.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUltimately, people want to feel that they are in control … managing money is not generally something people like to deal with … [this project] was about helping people build better habits, but also relate to their money in more positive ways.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/marc_schmidt-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Christian Marc Schmidt\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eChristian Marc Schmidt\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eInteraction at IDEO during the Keep the Change project\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Ultimately, people want to feel that they are in control … managing money is not something people like to deal with.” @cms_     \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet’s try a thought experiment. Put yourself in the state of mind of someone living paycheck to paycheck. For some of us who as designers spent time freelancing and waiting … and waiting … to get paid by clients, this might not be a hard thing to imagine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat are some of your biggest fears? Getting your water or heat shut off because you can’t pay bills on time? Maybe things are bad enough that you worry you won’t make rent and could get evicted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou probably don’t have time (or the means) to worry about setting up a savings plan. A \u003ca href=\"https://www.princeton.edu/main/news/archive/S37/75/69M50/index.xml?section=topstories\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e2013 study at Princeton\u003c/a\u003e showed that being in this state of mind actually impairs the brainpower needed to navigate other areas of life.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo how do you go about designing a banking product for someone stuck in this vicious cycle? In 2004, the design firm IDEO tackled exactly this challenge for Bank of America. Their target users were not restricted to people in this demographic, but the insights that lead to Bank of America’s innovative “Keep the Change” program came in part from \u003ca href=\"http://www.fastcodesign.com/1669452/want-breakthrough-ideas-first-listen-to-the-freaks-and-geeks\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eextreme users\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuch users had unconventional ways of solving banking problems, which gave the IDEO team ideas for a banking service that would help address the needs of people having a difficult time achieving a sense of control over their finances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThere was an almost unexpected and very emotional effect from this new service … people who previously never had savings suddenly did … and it wasn’t the amount that mattered; even a small amount of money in their savings account gave them a sense of power and control over their finances.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/tucker-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Faith Tucker\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFaith Tucker\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003e Senior Vice President \u0026#038; Product Developer at Bank of America during the Keep the Change Project\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “There was an unexpected and very emotional effect from this new service…” Faith Tucker @BankofAmerica    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIDEO was given the challenge by Bank of America to find novel ways to entice people to open accounts. The bank was hoping that IDEO’s human-centered, ethnographic-based approach to design would bring innovation to an industry that’s typically very conservative and reluctant to change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284309792”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo accomplish this, IDEO embedded themselves into the Bank of America team and conducted observations in several cities across America. They spoke to families and individuals, learning about spending and banking habits. As IDEO synthesized their observations, they began to notice some interesting patterns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOften, mothers were in charge of the finances. This was during the early 2000s, before online banking and mobile devices had more or less replaced the idea of a balanced checkbook. Some moms had a practice of rounding up the number in their checkbooks; this made addition easier, but it also gave a small buffer in spending.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eArmed with this insight and the knowledge that many of these families had difficulty saving what money they had, IDEO came up with a service idea. People could enroll in a savings account that would round up purchases made with debit cards. Then, the overage would be transferred to a savings account automatically. In addition, the bank would match the money transferred to savings to a certain dollar amount.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you might imagine, this program became very popular—and not only with people who had trouble saving money. Ever since the program launched in September of 2005, more than 12.3 million customers have enrolled, saving a total of more than 2 billion dollars. Of all new customers, 60% enroll in the program.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen we interviewed Faith Tucker, the former Senior Vice President \u0026amp; Product Developer at Bank of America, she was clearly proud of the emotional impact this service had on people who found saving money difficult. The amount was largely inconsequential—it was more about the change in mental state and feeling of empowerment that these customers gained.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo a certain degree, it removed the feeling of shame that came along with being unable to save money, which was replaced with pride at taking more control over finances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:706]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the film \u003ca href=\"https://www.designdisruptors.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDESIGN DISRUPTORS\u003c/a\u003e, Julia Zhou (VP Product Design, Facebook) and Mia Blume (Product Design Manager, Pinterest), talk about the importance of having empathy for your user.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"START YOUR DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-medium_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Powering enterprise design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"START YOUR DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003ePowering enterprise design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTransform your organization with InVision Enterprise—trusted by more than 75% of the Fortune 100\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/trial/enterprise?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-2008 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"START YOUR DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSTART YOUR DEMO\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-2008 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-2008:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEstablishing empathy remotely: the camera study\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct teams need to move fast, and they’re often working on a strict timeline. It can be hard to convince stakeholders that user research—in the form of an ethnography—can be completed quickly and still have an impact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, there are some great techniques available to do exactly that. If you’re highly constrained on time and budget, try a Minimum Viable Ethnography, pioneered by user research expert Erika Hall of Mule Design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284311664”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://www.aardvarkdesignlabs.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA camera study can be a great substitute for rapid empathy work, but getting buy-in from the participants is an essential, and not always easy piece.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/Bobby_Hughes-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Bobby Hughes\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBobby Hughes\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAardvark Design Labs\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “A camera study can be a great substitute for rapid empathy work…” -Bobby Hughes, Aardvark Design Labs    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have a little more time, try a user camera study. The advantage of this approach is that you get a semi-unfiltered view into the day-to-day environment of your users and you gain insights that may not be available via a phone or video interview.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s a step-by-step guide for the study:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-exercise:713]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEmpathy as the heart of design\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmpathy is a journey into the feelings of others. Sometimes it’s a physical journey, like the one the Embrace team took to Nepal. Other times, it’s a virtual journey, where users share their screens with you or collect pictures of their environment in a camera study. Whatever your methods include, a good empathy study will give you new perspectives on the lives of your users—including the challenges they face, the things that keep them up at night, and the moments that delight them. Having this empathy can give you the insights you need to solve hard, worthwhile problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWithout empathy, IDEO would not have been able to help Bank of America create a product that helped their financially strained customers feel empowered about saving money. Embrace wouldn’t have been able to create a product that’s saved the lives of thousands of premature babies. Empathy connects designers to the people who will use our products, empowering us to create products that ultimately meet real human needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs humans, we \u003ca href=\"http://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/the_evolution_of_empathy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eevolved to have a powerful sense of empathy\u003c/a\u003e. The primatologist Frans de Waal writes that the power of empathy to help people collaborate is one of the reasons we became so successful as a species. Wield this power as a designer and you’ll have the foundation, and the heart, to create great products for humans everywhere.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:715]\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eDesigners work to solve others’ problems but the most insightful and innovative design work begins with empathy. Slip on your users’ shoes and seek to gain understanding with an open mind. You’ll be surprised what deep needs and insights you can uncover.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":7,"fields":{"book":["562"],"chapter_num":"02","sub_title":"The heart of design","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eDesigners work to solve others’ problems but the most insightful and innovative design work begins with empathy. Slip on your users’ shoes and seek to gain understanding with an open mind. You’ll be surprised what deep needs and insights you can uncover.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292578371","related":[{"title":"Interviews aren’t the only way to gain empathy","url":"https://blog.prototypr.io/2-design-thinking-dont-conflate-interviews-with-empathy-1a99ed06af1","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"D.school Wallet Project","url":"https://dschool.stanford.edu/groups/designresources/wiki/4dbb2/The_Wallet_Project.html","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Just Enough Research","url":"https://abookapart.com/products/just-enough-research","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Creative Confidence","url":"http://www.creativeconfidence.com/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Wired to Care","url":"","target":{"_self":"Same Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_empathize.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Empathize - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Use empathy to seek out and fully understand your users’ environment and experience to uncover deep needs and insights.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-thinking/empathize"},{"id":631,"pid":0,"title":"Define","type":"chapter","date":"631","content":"\u003cp\u003eIn 1968, when Apollo 8 became the first spacecraft to circumnavigate the moon, the crew had one photographic mission: to capture detailed images of the moon’s surface. As the astronauts rounded the dark side, Earth became visible—a brilliant blue and white marble. Earth was remarkable not only for its serene beauty from this perspective but also for its apparent fragility. The only life-sustaining planet in our solar system is dwarfed by the vast emptiness of space.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the photograph from this event, which became known as “Earthrise,” the Apollo 8 astronauts inadvertently sparked a spontaneous reframing of the environmental problems threatening our planet. No longer were we on a vast planet with seemingly endless resources, but rather a small, very finite lifeboat in an infinite universe.  This change in perspective helped charge the modern environmental movement, inspiring the creation of Earth Day in 1970.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/earthrise_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: Earthrise: image of Earth from NASA\u0026#8217;s Apollo 8 mission.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReframing the way that a problem is viewed can inspire a movement, as it did in this case. It can also be a powerful way to create innovative design solutions to challenging problems and even create new and disruptive business models. During the \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/empathize/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEmpathize\u003c/a\u003e phase of the Design Thinking process, you collected stories and insights from your users. This Define phase will give you an opportunity to synthesize these findings and come up with a problem statement, called a point of view (POV), that can help you reframe the problem and open new and innovative solution spaces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDeveloping a point of view (POV)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA POV is composed of 3 elements:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWho \u003c/em\u003eis your user? (Note as many specific details as possible.)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhat \u003c/em\u003eis their deep, unmet need?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhy \u003c/em\u003eis this insightful?
