(List the insights you gleaned from your empathetic needfinding process.)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs an example, below is a POV from the founders of \u003ca href=\"https://www.awesomebox.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAwesomeBox\u003c/a\u003e, a gift-giving platform, used in the early days of developing their product. They were trying to design for people who have a hard time giving thoughtful gifts. They interviewed and observed hundreds of potential customers, from which they created POVs like the following.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/Awesomebox_POV_mod_v3.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2: An early POV from the founders of the gift-giving platform AwesomeBox.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet’s create some hypothetical POVs using Netflix, as they’re a good example of a company that disrupted an existing business model by reframing the problem for users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the early days, Netflix might have framed their POV like this:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“Caroline is a 26-year-old single mom who loves sci-fi movies. She needs a way to rent DVDs that doesn’t clutter her already-busy schedule, while making her feel relaxed after a long day of work and taking care of her daughter.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing this point of view, Netflix certainly could have come up with a solution that only delivers DVDs by mail—but the solution space would have been constrained and they might’ve missed a larger opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow consider how Netflix could have reframed the problem with a different POV.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCaroline is a 26-year-old single mom who loves sci-fi movies. She needs a way to access new and entertaining content in a way that allows her to consume it at her own pace, while making her feel excited about discovering new shows to share with her friends\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the problem statement rewritten, Netflix opened up all kinds of opportunities for innovation. Let’s unpack them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“She needs a way to access new and entertaining content … ”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis doesn’t even mention DVDs! In the early days, a mail delivery solution may have worked, but over time Netflix developed the streaming services that helped make them so popular. Also, “new and entertaining” doesn’t necessarily limit them to licensing content. Netflix could also develop and distribute their own shows.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“ … in a way that allows her to consume it at her own pace … ”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgain, mail delivery of DVDs would be a partial solution to this constraint, but with streaming as an option, there’s an even bigger opportunity. Add in original content, and now Caroline can binge-watch \u003cem\u003eHouse of Cards\u003c/em\u003e while her daughter sleeps. (We never said that innovative solutions always have a positive social impact.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“ … while making her feel excited about discovering new shows … ”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNetflix famously developed a “recommendation algorithm” that helps viewers discover new content based on the shows they already watch—and the ratings they give to each. This feature wouldn’t have necessarily stemmed from the previous POV.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“ … \u003cem\u003ewhich she can share with her friends.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis last insight, while minor on its surface, is a huge reason for the viral growth of Netflix—especially after the company began developing original content. Once rave reviews about shows began to surface—with the only way to access them being Netflix—the continued growth was almost assured.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284351017”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eClearly, there would have been a lot of value left on the table had Netflix used the first POV to guide their designs. In addition to helping you reframe a problem, a good POV can \u003ca href=\"http://us5.campaign-archive1.com/?u=7e093c5cf4\u0026amp;id=cfe9dbcac8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ealign your team\u003c/a\u003e, provide a way to compare competing ideas, and help fuel brainstorms. In fact, the d.school at Stanford came up with a great checklist of all the things that a good POV should help you accomplish:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScY-5fW8NK7zoWJWLB1lrB7ZSCw8hD1nZmodvDdm9y8kA66ew/viewform?c=0\u0026amp;w=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePoint of view (POV) checklist\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour POV should:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eProvide focus and frame the problem\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInspire your team\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eProvide a reference for evaluating competing ideas\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEmpower team members to make decisions in response to the high level goals of the team\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFuel brainstorms by suggesting “how might we” statements\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCapture the hearts and minds of people you meet\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSave you from the impossible task of developing solution concepts that are all things to all people\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAllow you to revisit and reformulate the POV as you learn by doing\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGuide your innovation efforts\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the remaining sections of this chapter, we will dive into a case study where developing a POV provided inspiration for a healthcare project with a lot of impact. Then, we’ll share an exercise to help you quickly generate POVs of your own.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284352174”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Subscribe-medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/subscribe\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET ON THE LIST\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Subscribe-medium_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Get insider access to DesignBetter.Co\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/subscribe\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET ON THE LIST\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGet insider access to DesignBetter.Co\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBe the first to get content from design innovators like Automattic’s John Maeda and more\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/subscribe\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1667 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET ON THE LIST\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGET ON THE LIST\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1667 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1667:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCase study: \u003c/strong\u003eGE Healthcare MRI redesign\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe first met Doug Dietz when doing the research for this chapter. Over the phone, Doug is a kind, affable midwesterner—the sort of guy you imagine it would be fun to go to a Milwaukee Brewers game with. But beneath his unassuming presence is a formidable design mind with over 25 years of experience at GE Healthcare. First as a principal designer and now Innovation Architect, Doug has helped develop medical equipment such as MRI and CT scanners for one of the world’s largest corporations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jajduxPD6H4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIn 2008, Doug ran into a problem\u003c/a\u003e. He was at a hospital where one of his new MRI machines had recently been installed. The machine had won a prestigious industrial design award and Doug was eager to see the machine in situ.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore he had much of a chance to ask the technician about the machine, he was asked to step outside of the room, as a patient was scheduled to come in for an appointment. What he witnessed in the hallway changed the course of his career and helped him reframe the MRI user experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA young family walked in, their 7-year-old daughter obviously distressed. As the family got closer, Doug could see that she was weeping. The father leaned over and said, “Remember, we talked about this, you can be brave.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDoug peered into the room where the young girl was about to enter the scanner. Crouching down, he had a new perspective on the room—and on the machine that he had so proudly designed. He could immediately understand why the girl was terrified: warning stickers plastered the machine and yellow and black tape marked the floor like a crash-test scene. The machine itself looked like a beige “brick with a hole in it.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven this new perspective, it’s no mystery why many children have to be sedated to get MRI or CT scans. Everything about the experience can be frightening, from the room and the machine to the claustrophobia and loud noises. Doug came away with a new mission: to understand how GE might redesign this experience for children so that it’s a positive experience and not something to be dreaded.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDoug’s boss recommended he attend an executive education workshop at the d.school at Stanford to get the Design Thinking toolkit and help him solve this big, emotionally-charged problem. The workshop helped him frame the problem as a POV, in the form of a \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.com/?exercise=using-madlibs-generate-povs-15-minutes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMadlib\u003c/a\u003e which was structured in the following way:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“We met … ”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“We were amazed to realize that … ”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“It would change the world if … ”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing this framework, Doug and his team were able to iterate on their POV until they came up with a statement more aligned with the goal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“We met scared families trying not to fall apart during the hospital visit.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe were amazed to realize that they have to sedate 80% of children between 3 and 8 years old, in order to have them scanned.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIt would change the world if we could capitalize on the child’s amazing imagination to transform the radiology experience into a positive, memorable adventure.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy reframing the problem using this POV, Doug and his team realized that the beginning of the user experience started at home, when the parents were trying to figure out what the procedure was like and how to explain it to their children. They were able to outline the whole user journey for the family and determine the different touchpoints that they could influence or redesign.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284352695”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe team didn’t have the budget to do a full redesign of the machines, so once they had identified a few promising opportunities, they decided to implement a low-fidelity \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/prototype/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eprototype\u003c/a\u003e. By applying decals to the exterior of the machine and the walls of the scanning room, they were able to transform the dull, monotone experience into a colorful pirate adventure, where the captain\u0026#8217;s helm led to the inside of the “ship” (this feature had the added benefit of making the opening seem much larger and less claustrophobic). They created a script for the operator, who led the children through the pirate adventure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/piratey4_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3: By reframing the problem, Doug Dietz created a positive experience for children facing stressful MRI and CAT scans. Photo courtesy Children\u0026#8217;s Hospital of Pittsburgh.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe results from this redesign and from others like it were no less than amazing. Sedation rates dropped from 80% to fractions of one percent. But to Doug, the human stories behind the numbers are just as important.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile visiting the pirate-themed scanner, Doug talked to the parents of a little girl about the room’s piña colada scented aroma, something they were getting a kick out of. The little girl came up to the mom and tugged at her shirt. “Can we come back tomorrow?” she asked.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor at least one family, Doug and his team had transformed the experience from something terrifying to something to look forward to. By using their POV as a way to reframe the problem, his team was able to change the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-exercise:639]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"The business impact of design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe business impact of design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee how design impacts business and drives value at the world’s most innovative companies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1955 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSEE THE REPORT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1955 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1955:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe exponential power of reframing\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn their wonderful \u003ca href=\"http://www.eamesoffice.com/the-work/powers-of-ten/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e1977 film for IBM\u003c/a\u003e, designers Charles and Ray Eames explored how perspectives change by looking at the relative scale of objects. For example, the film zooms out from a man and woman on a picnic blanket to the grass surrounding them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:726]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe film quickly progresses through Earth to the edge of the universe, then zooms back into the nucleus of a carbon atom. In the process, viewers get a wonderful understanding of extremes at both ends of the scale, but also of how reframing your viewpoint can create a new perspective on something familiar and ordinary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs designers, \u003ca href=\"http://www.fastcodesign.com/1672354/how-reframing-a-problem-unlocks-innovation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ewe can leverage the power of reframing\u003c/a\u003e to help us innovate and solve wicked problems. We can create POVs to help guide our product design process and connect us to our users. And if we’re lucky, we might just see the world in a new light along the way.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eIn 1968, when Apollo 8 became the first spacecraft to circumnavigate the moon, the crew had one photographic mission: to capture detailed images of the moon’s surface. As the astronauts rounded the dark side, Earth became visible—a brilliant blue and white marble. Earth was remarkable not only for its serene beauty from this perspective but [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":8,"fields":{"book":["562"],"chapter_num":"03","sub_title":"Reframe the problem","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eA single image of the earth from the moon shifted the course of environmental history. A new point of view on a design problem can shift your perspective just as much. Learning to reframe your point of view based on insights from your users can be a powerful design tool.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292586839","related":[{"title":"How Reframing A Problem Unlocks Innovation","url":"http://www.fastcodesign.com/1672354/how-reframing-a-problem-unlocks-innovation","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Three Ways to Reframe a Problem to Find an Innovative Solution","url":"https://www.fastcompany.com/3050265/hit-the-ground-running/three-ways-to-reframe-a-problem-to-find-innovative-solution","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Reframe: Shift the Way You Work, Innovate, and Think","url":"http://www.readytoreframe.com/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Designing features using Job Stories","url":"https://blog.intercom.io/using-job-stories-design-features-ui-ux/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Don’t Make a Journey Map: 9 archetypes","url":"https://medium.com/@shahrsays/dont-make-a-journey-map-9-archetypes-of-good-bad-and-how-to-decide-what-to-use-d65abd30ec6f","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_define.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Define - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Reframing the way you look at a problem opens up a wealth of new perspectives—and fertile ground for innovation.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-thinking/define"},{"id":634,"pid":0,"title":"Ideate","type":"chapter","date":"634","content":"\u003cp\u003eThe Apollo 13 Mission Control team faced a huge number of seemingly insurmountable obstacles after an oxygen tank exploded on board the 1970 mission to the moon. They needed to find a new route that would get the astronauts back to Earth quickly with a limited supply of life-supporting fuel and power.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe most pressing problem was a buildup of carbon dioxide in the ship. Without a replacement scrubber, stored out of reach in a different module in the craft, the crew would soon asphyxiate from their own exhalations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/Apollo_13_Mailbox_at_Mission_Control_V3-min.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: The NASA Houston mission control team discusses the emergency filter prototype \u0026#8216;mailbox.\u0026#8217;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the 1995 movie version of this dramatic event, \u003cem\u003eApollo 13\u003c/em\u003e, Flight Director Gene Kranz (played by Ed Harris) assembles the top engineers and scientists in a room for a brainstorming session. He tells the group to forget the flight plan, and that they would be “improvising a new mission.” Standing in front of a chalkboard, he quickly sketches the original route of the ship. Then, when one of the engineers suggests a new route, Kranz alters the original route to show a slingshot approach that would use the moon’s gravity to whip the astronauts back toward Earth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a later scene, a group of engineers tasked with devising a new filtration system dumps the same items aboard Apollo 13 onto a table. They proceed to prototype a fix that the crew can build from the objects at hand, ending up with a literal “\u003ca href=\"http://abcnews.go.com/Health/challenge-design-90-percent/story?id=12425103\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003educt-tape solution\u003c/a\u003e.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/Apollo_13_LM_with_Mailbox_retouched_V4-min.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2: The \u0026#8216;mailbox\u0026#8217; filter as created by the astronauts on board the Apollo 13 mission.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn each case, the route to resolving the problems seemed relatively straightforward, if fraught with urgency: get a bunch of smart people in a room, and have them collectively come up with ideas until the best solution was found. We can assume that the film was faithful to what happened in the real life control room in Houston, but what conditions created such a successful environment for brainstorming?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe term “brainstorm” was popularized by the ad agency executive Alex Osborn in his 1953 book \u003cem\u003eApplied Imagination\u003c/em\u003e (though he had outlined his method in a 1948 book, \u003cem\u003eYour Creative Power\u003c/em\u003e). Osborn claimed that by organizing a group to attack a creative problem “commando fashion, with each stormer attacking the same objective,” creative output could be doubled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOsborn created 2 main rules for a successful brainstorm:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDefer judgement\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReach for quantity\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeferring judgement reduced social inhibitions in the group—no one would be stigmatized for shouting out a crazy idea. By reaching for quantity, participants would boost their overall creative output and increase the likelihood of coming up with innovative solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs we discussed in \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/pencils-before-pixels/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePencils before pixels\u003c/a\u003e, brainstorming in a group might not work as well for original ideas, as compared to individuals working independently.  However, brainstorming adds value to the creative process in ways that don’t just involve coming up with ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBrainstorming isn’t about new ideas, really\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tsheiner\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI don\u0026#8217;t believe the value of brainstorming is the ideas generated; I believe it is the shared value/evaluation context created. The experience of brainstorming creates a group of people with a shared perspective, and an understanding of each other\u0026#8217;s communication styles, who are then capable of providing a useful and powerful critique of future work on the topic.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/shiener-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Tim Sheiner\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eTim Sheiner\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eSalesforce\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The experience of brainstorming creates a group of people with shared perspective\u0026#8230;” @tsheiner @salesforce    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt turns out that the power of brainstorming doesn’t really come from spontaneously generating \u003cem\u003enew\u003c/em\u003e ideas. Rather, the real strength in brainstorming stems from the process’s ability to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuickly generate \u003cem\u003elots\u003c/em\u003e of ideas\u003c/strong\u003e, to help get an overview of the conceptual landscape. These are not necessarily new ideas (or good ideas). They may have been brewing for a while as individuals considered the problem beforehand. These ideas can become the seeds for solutions, to be investigated with prototypes.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGather a team into a physical space\u003c/strong\u003e where everyone can share perspectives on the problem and become aware of the potential solution spaces as they are surfaced. Done well, it can energize a team (and done poorly, it can deflate one).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGet clients or stakeholders to buy into the design process\u003c/strong\u003e, and also learn what is important to these decision makers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://www.vital-innovation.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e[Brainstorms are] excellent at helping clients buy into the creative process…they get to join in on the brainstorms, they see lots of ideas, they get to vote for their favorites and a dialogue happens during the voting process that is crucial.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome kind of sorting always follows a brainstorm, and it\u0026#8217;s during this process that one can learn from the client. What have they already done or are currently doing? What can\u0026#8217;t they do? Won\u0026#8217;t they do? And most importantly, what are they excited about?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/belfort-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Yona Belfort\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eYona Belfort\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eVital Innovation\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “[Brainstorms are] excellent at helping clients buy into the creative process…” Yona Belfort, Vital Innovation    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGenerating ideas, sharing perspectives, and gaining stakeholder buy-in are lofty goals. To achieve them via brainstorming requires careful planning. In the next few sections, we’ll cover how to properly set the stage for success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/art-sandoval-07a6ba3/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e[The] goal is to give you a mass quantity of ideas quickly … not solutions, but the seeds to possible solutions. Solutions take real hard work. Brainstorming gets you the lay of the land quickly for possible solution areas to investigate. But good solutions are like body building, there’s no way to cheat the hours of the gym you got to put in.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/sandoval-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Art Sandoval\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eArt Sandoval\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eLUNAR Design\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Good solutions are like body building—there’s no way to cheat the hours of the gym you got to put in.” Art Sandoval @LUNARdesign    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Principles-of-Design-Book-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/principles-of-product-design\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Principles-of-Design-Book-small_2x-760x760.png\" alt=\"Level up your product design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/principles-of-product-design\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLevel up your product design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDive into \u003cem\u003ePrinciples of Product Design\u003c/em\u003e—essential practices to produce great products\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/principles-of-product-design\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1643 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eREAD THE BOOK\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1643 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #000000;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1643:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: #000000;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrepare for brainstorming success\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore we dive into suggestions for making your brainstorms more successful, a caveat—just like any other creative tool, there are a lot of ways to run a brainstorm, some of which might work better for certain types of problems. The only way you’ll learn which technique works best for you is to experiment with a few.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll remember from our introduction that Alex Osborn sets 2 guidelines for a successful brainstorm:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDefer judgement\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eReach for quantity\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile these are fundamentally important, there are a few additional guidelines that will make your brainstorm more successful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBefore the brainstorm\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA key part of the brainstorming process is the facilitator—someone who will lead the session, keep track of time, and set up the space for the group. This facilitator can also make sure that the group comes prepared with a mission framed by problem statements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284352899”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSet a mission\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour brainstorming session should have a clear goal. What problem(s) are you surfacing ideas for? What is the best method for coming up with this goal?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecall that Stanford’s d.school design thinking framework (below) alternates between generative (flaring) and selective (focusing) phases. As you \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/empathize/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEmpathize\u003c/a\u003e, you gather data and stories from your users, generating insights and flaring out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you begin to synthesize that information and come closer to \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/define/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDefining\u003c/a\u003e your point of view (POV), you become selective about the solution space you will pursue, and you focus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/123fb_v4.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3: An illustration of the design thinking process, showing flaring and focusing phases, from the Stanford d.school’s visual resource guide.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the current Ideate phase, you flare out again as you generate a multitude of ideas and select promising solutions for \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/prototype/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrototyping\u003c/a\u003e. Doing this helps your team step beyond obvious solutions, harness the collective creativity of the team, and discover new and unexpected areas to explore.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow do you go about generating those ideas? The POV that you generated in the Define phase is a great platform to help start the process. Using your POV problem statement, come up with “How might we … ?” topics that are subsets of the entire problem. If your POV is well constructed, these topics should fall naturally out of it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, let’s go back to Doug Dietz’s POV.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“We met scared families trying not to fall apart during the hospital visit. We were amazed to realize that they have to sedate 80% of the children between 3 and 8 years old, in order to have them be scanned. It would change the world if we could capitalize on the child’s amazing imagination to transform the radiology experience into a positive, memorable adventure.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith that POV, you can pretty easily come up with problem statements like “How might we make the MRI scanner a more imaginative space?” or “How can we reduce anxiety before appointments by sparking children’s imaginations?” With these topics, you can then set up brainstorming sessions to surface a lot of ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSet up the space\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor a good brainstorm to happen, the energy in the room needs to be right. First, pick a space that has large whiteboards or room on a wall to set up poster-sized \u003ca href=\"http://www.post-it.com/3M/en_US/post-it/products/~/Post-it-Products/Easel-Pads/?N=4327+5927574+3294529207+3294857497\u0026amp;rt=r3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEasel Pads\u003c/a\u003e. The room should also be somewhat enclosed if there is a worry about bothering other teams (brainstorming can get boisterous)—but there are alternate techniques for a quiet brainstorm, which we’ll get to a little later.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGet into the right headspace\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re coming into a brainstorming session from individual work, it can be a little jarring to adopt a collaborative mindset—and hard to ramp up your energy level accordingly. The facilitator should spend a few minutes getting everyone acclimated. There are quick, improv-based techniques for this, like \u003ca href=\"http://www.bbbpress.com/2015/11/drama-game-sound-ball/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSound Ball\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href=\"http://improvencyclopedia.org/games//Knife_Baby_Angry_Cat.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eKnife, Baby, and Angry Cat\u003c/a\u003e. You can also use the 30 Circles Exercise that we outline later in this article.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLimit the time\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA brainstorm can quickly run out of steam if the facilitator doesn’t establish time limits and keep the conversation moving. Setting a time limit for each topic is a good idea (15–20 minutes works well, depending on how many topics you need to cover). You can also set a goal for the number of ideas per topic (e.g., 100 ideas in 20 minutes). Use a \u003ca href=\"http://www.timetimer.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTime Timer\u003c/a\u003e so everyone has a visual indicator and benefits from adrenaline-powered sprints as the time begins to run short.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuring the brainstorm\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the brainstorm kicks off, the moderator’s job is to keep the momentum going, stay on topic, and make sure all ideas are captured.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAlways say yes\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo keep the energy high and the ideas flowing, a good brainstorm shares a lot in common with the improv technique of “Yes, and … ” When an idea is put forth, participants should be encouraged to build on it, putting a positive spin on the contribution. Critical energy can be diverted into productive ideation in this way. For example, “\u003cem\u003eYes\u003c/em\u003e, I like that idea, \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e we could go even further by … ”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStay on topic\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the heated environment of a brainstorm, it’s easy to get sidetracked and start diving down rabbit holes that have no relation to the problem statement at hand. It’s important for the facilitator to gently guide participants back to the current topic. Sometimes this is best done by noting adjacent topics and mentioning that the group can come back to it later or during a future session.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBe visual and headline\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne way to run a brainstorm is to have the facilitator serve as scribe, logging all the ideas as they come. Another is to arm the group with sticky notes and sharpies, so that they can walk up to the board, verbally share an idea, and put a summary of the idea on the board.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEither way, it’s important to be visual. Encourage quick sketches— these will help to clarify and group ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso, ideas should be headlined as they are produced. A participant can say, “We could create a way for the user to leave feedback for us directly via a comment form,” which someone would then summarize as “Feedback comment form.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhatever method you choose, ideas should be shared one at a time. This allows the scribe to write them, or the participant to be heard as they post their idea to the board.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter the brainstorm\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the brainstorm is finished and there are a hundred ideas on the board, it’s easy enough to give high fives all around and walk away without really having accomplished much. Leave a little time after the brainstorm to review and capture the ideas that were shared.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNarrow down, but not too fast\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’ve run a productive brainstorm, you’ll likely have a lot of different ideas on the board—some funny, some weird, perhaps some verging on insane. It can be tempting to cut any idea that isn’t feasible, but by doing so you may be tripping up the ideation process. Sometimes good ideas can come from a place that initially seemed silly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInstead, give the participants a way to select ideas across multiple criteria. One way to do this is to use color-coded sticky dots or pieces of colored Post-its. Each color can signify a person’s top choices in each category, such as the lowest hanging fruit, most delightful, or the long shot.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCapture and move to prototyping\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce you’ve selected ideas in each category, carry them into prototyping, ensuring that you don’t walk away from the session with just the safest choice. Use a phone to photograph the whole board, and then extract the top ideas in a document which can be used to kick off the prototyping process (Google Docs is great for this).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrototyping is a flaring part of the design thinking process. Even if a selected idea is so crazy it doesn’t seem worthy of a test, figure out what’s attractive in that solution, and use that to inspire a prototype. The goal is to come into the \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/prototype/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrototype\u003c/a\u003e phase with multiple solutions to build and then test.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemember that brainstorming is just 1 step in the process of coming up with a solution. In all likelihood, you won’t come out of a brainstorming session armed with the exact idea that you’ll bring to your users. But you will hopefully compile an overview of the conceptual landscape, gain a shared perspective on the problem with your team, or get key stakeholders to buy into the design process. All of these things will help seed the minds of your team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePro tip: brainstorming at IDEO\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePeter Macdonald has run countless brainstorms during his 23-year tenure at IDEO as a design lead. Peter says: “You can\u0026#8217;t have a good brainstorm without setting it up right—having everyone feeling safe and heard. A key element is trust, consistent with IDEO\u0026#8217;s culture of trust. Bullies and blowhards are not tolerated.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some more insights from Peter Macdonald on how brainstorming at IDEO has evolved over the years:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“Our favored approach today is to start with everyone working heads-down for 5 minutes to begin brainstorming around each key question. Then we have people share those ideas with the group and continue with a classic brainstorm process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“It ensures a diversity of ideas and prevents the first ideas from setting the direction of the entire brainstorm—it also helps the group build strong momentum.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“At IDEO we aren\u0026#8217;t dogmatic about creative techniques. You should use whatever process or format works for you. Sometimes different approaches work better for different problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“Our industrial designers often hold \u0026#8220;design-storms\u0026#8221; where everyone is sketching form or design ideas at the same time and sharing back as they finish each sketch. Instead of Post-its, they use 8.5” x 11” sheets or half sheets (8.5\u0026#8243; x 5.5\u0026#8243;) and a variety of pens, pencils, and markers so they can add more details.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“Our toy invention group does \u0026#8220;tinker-time\u0026#8221; where they build in 3D together. Every team is encouraged to experiment and create and evolve new techniques.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-exercise:746]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAlternatives to brainstorming\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou may have noticed that the “classic” brainstorming method we described requires a fair amount of coordination, and ultimately practice, to run well. It also relies, as Peter Macdonald from IDEO notes, on a “culture of trust.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut what if you don’t have the resources to pull this off, or are working with a new team or client and don’t have the time to build this culture from repeated brainstorming sessions? There are ways to get around this.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSketching\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003cem\u003eSprint\u003c/em\u003e, Jake Knapp outlines a method for \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/pencils-before-pixels/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003esketching\u003c/a\u003e and discussing ideas in a group (listen to Daniel Burka talk about this technique in the clip below). The GV team explicitly does not call this brainstorming (which they have some strong opinions about)—but the point is to find a process that functions within your workflow and organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerforming ideation with \u003cem\u003eindividual\u003c/em\u003e sketches—which are reviewed by the group silently, voted on, and not discussed until the end of the session—is a way to address situations where a strong collaborative culture may not yet be established.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284353612”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMindmapping\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat if you’re on your own, with no one to run a brainstorming session with? In that case, mindmaps are your friend! The concept is simple, but mindmaps can be a powerful way to move from conventional ideas to unpredictable, innovative ones. The following version of this technique is adapted from David and Tom Kelley’s \u003cem\u003eCreative Confidence\u003c/em\u003e. You can start with a problem statement like, “A better birthday party for a 1-year-old.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWrite your topic or problem statement in the middle of a piece of paper, and circle it. Make connections to that central node, and write them down. In this example, you might write down “cupcakes to devour” and “make it for the adults” as 2 directions to investigate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/mindmap_v4.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 4: Mindmapping a birthday party for a 1 year old.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach connection should spur new ideas (“make it for the adults” could inspire “baby birthday adult beverages,” for example). If an idea becomes a new cluster, circle it to indicate that it is a new node in the map. Be visual where possible; simple sketches can inspire new directions. You’re done when the page is full, but you can always continue the mindmap by reframing the topic and starting a new map.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMindmapping will help you get the early, obvious ideas out of your head. It can help you look for patterns, reveal the structure of a subject, and—once you have an opportunity to move beyond a solo mission—communicate the ideas and process to others.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/craft#freehand?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIdeate with Craft Freehand\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSowing the seeds of innovation\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 1869, the Russian chemist Dmitry Mendeleev fell asleep at his desk. He was in the midst of a 3-day working sprint, during which he was trying to arrange the elements in a logical manner. He was stuck.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsleep, Mendeleev dreamt of a solution. “I saw … a table where all the elements fell into place as required. Awakening, I immediately wrote it down on a piece of paper.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/mendeleev_table_v3.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 5: Mendeleev’s 1869 handwritten sketch of the periodic table.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDreaming helps our brains organize and consolidate the information that we are exposed to throughout our working day. Much like taking a shower or a long walk, it’s a time during which solutions to the problem at hand come to mind.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut these solutions only appear after the hard work of exposing your mind to a lot of diverse ideas. Ideating, whether through brainstorming, sketching, or mind mapping, can help you and your team seed this field of ideas—which you can carry into the prototyping process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-Medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-Medium_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Team collaboration—in real time\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTeam collaboration—in real time\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInVision Freehand is your team’s infinite space for fast, flexible collaboration\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1966 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTRY FREEHAND\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1966 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1966:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eThe Apollo 13 Mission Control team faced a huge number of seemingly insurmountable obstacles after an oxygen tank exploded on board the 1970 mission to the moon. They needed to find a new route that would get the astronauts back to Earth quickly with a limited supply of life-supporting fuel and power. The most pressing [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":9,"fields":{"book":["562"],"chapter_num":"04","sub_title":"Beyond basic brainstorms","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIdeation early in the design process helps teams get aligned and find potential solutions to investigate. While most teams use some form of ideation, design thinking can lend new structure and spark the brainstorming process.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"294297264","related":[{"title":"When brainstorming fails, throw an imaginary cat","url":"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/when-brainstorming-fails-throw-imaginary-cat-gabriel-aldaz","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Graphic Design Thinking: Beyond Brainstorming","url":"https://www.papress.com/html/book.details.page.tpl?isbn=9781568989792","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"How IBM brings forward ideas from its teams","url":"http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/07/jobs/how-ibm-brings-ideas-forward-from-its-teams.html","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"How to Fly a Horse","url":"http://www.howtoflyahorse.com/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking","url":"http://www.quietrev.com/quiet-the-book/","target":{"_self":"Same Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_ideate.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Ideate - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Discover the trick to generating out-of-the-box ideas inside a framework—and get the best brainstorming from yourself or your team.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-thinking/ideate"},{"id":654,"pid":0,"title":"Prototype","type":"chapter","date":"654","content":"\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYou must not fool yourself, and you are the easiest person to fool.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/feynman-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Richard Feynman\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eRichard Feynman\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003e\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “You must not fool yourself, and you are the easiest person to fool.” -Richard Feynman    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne day in the early 1980s, the computer scientist Danny Hillis was having lunch with the Nobel-prize winning physicist Richard Feynman. Hillis mentioned that he was going to create a startup, with the goal of building a parallel computer that had a million processors. In typical Feynman fashion, the physicist responded that it was “positively the dopiest idea I ever heard.” But he was intrigued, and by the end of lunch had agreed to spend the summer working at the company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring the first few months on the job, Feynman worked on the router circuits. These would allow the processors to communicate and were far more complex than the processors themselves. The routers—tasked with ferrying information from point to point—had to find a free path through a 20-dimensional traffic jam between the processors, or hold the message in a buffer until the path was clear. A critical question was whether the design had allowed for enough buffering to operate efficiently.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeynman began studying the circuit diagrams and was willing to listen to explanations of why things worked. But he far preferred to use pencil and paper to simulate the action of each circuit and figure out things for himself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeynman’s work on the routers helped the team discover the potential of the computer—which they had dubbed the Connection Machine—for complex numerical computing and physical simulation. This was useful for modeling things like the behavior of fluids and the simulation of artificial life, programs which other computers of that era were not designed to perform efficiently.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe team had initially assumed that their machine would not be capable of these types of number-crunching calculations, but Feynman argued that the assumption was worth challenging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo settle the argument and find out how well these computations would work in practice, Feynman had to create a prototype program to run. He was only really familiar with the programming language Basic, so he made up his own version of Basic that would run on the parallel processors. He would write the program, and then simulate it by hand to estimate how fast the Connection Machine could run it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeynman treated these challenges like a game, starting with very basic questions like, “What is the simplest example?” He would then continue to ask questions until he had boiled the problem down to something he thought he could solve—which he would attack with pencil on paper.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeynman’s contributions eventually helped the company become a leader in parallel computing, generating tens of millions of dollars in revenue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/CM-1_r_700w_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: A production version of the CM-1 Connection Machine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen Hillis reminisced about his work with Feynman, he realized that in almost everything they collaborated on, they were amateurs. From neural networks to parallel computing, they didn’t know what they were doing—but these things were so new that \u003cem\u003eno one else did either\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy distilling complex problems down into simple ones and using prototypes to answer critical questions, they were able to drive innovation that even they themselves didn’t know was possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Podcast-450x340-medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Podcast-450x340-medium_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"The DesignBetter.Co Podcast\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe DesignBetter.Co Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJoin the world’s best designers to learn what it means to be a product-driven company\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1655 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLISTEN AND LEARN\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1655 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1655:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrototype like a physicist\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough Richard Feynman was a physicist and not a product designer, he intuitively understood the power of prototyping. Prototyping helps us learn, solve disagreements, and test ideas quickly and cheaply. Feynman began the design process with \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/pencils-before-pixels/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003esketches\u003c/a\u003e, which helped him understand the problem and identify critical questions that the prototype needed to answer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding a prototype gave Feynman a chance to settle the argument he made for the capability of the Connection Machine to solve complex calculations. Without it, he and his colleagues might have sat in front of a chalkboard, endlessly throwing equations at each other and citing research papers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, instead of taking the time to teach himself a more complex language, he used familiar tools to quickly build a program which simulated the efficiency of the machine. If he had failed at this point, it only would have cost days or weeks instead of months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFramed in this way, it’s clear why design-driven companies prototype early and often, throughout the design process, to create better products. In the remainder of this article, we’ll look at a case study where Uber prototyped to help them build better products for multilingual use, and we’ll run through some techniques that can help you and your team instill a bias towards prototyping from the beginning of the product design process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCase study: \u003c/strong\u003eUber goes international\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://mollynix.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe reason that these prototypes are really useful is that when we don’t have a live product built, but we need to get feedback, we can send them to researchers on the ground … it allows us to get feedback not just from drivers in San Francisco, but from all around the world.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/nix-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Molly Nix (1)\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMolly Nix\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eUber\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “[Prototyping] allows us to get feedback not just from drivers in San Francisco, but from all around the world.” @mollycnix @Uber    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUber, the increasingly ubiquitous ride-sharing service, boasts some impressive statistics. As of the writing of this article, 1+ million Uber drivers—or “driver partners,” as Uber prefers to call them—had given more than 2 billion rides to more than 8 million users. No matter what destination you travel to, you’re likely to find an Uber driver—they’re present in more than 400 cities in 70 countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigning Uber’s app to work seamlessly for the drivers and riders in this multitude of countries offered a unique set of challenges. There are differences in language, of course, as well as with symbology and wireless access speeds. All of these variables had to be taken into account as Uber worked on a ground-up redesign of its driver app in 2015.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe team began with lightweight prototypes of the app in English, using Sketch and \u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision\u003c/a\u003e. As they worked through these flows, the team had to also take into account their global audience, so they would go back into the Sketch files and update the languages to reflect Hindi or Chinese versions of the InVision prototypes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith prototypes in hand, the team could \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/test/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003etest with users\u003c/a\u003e in each country and begin to answer critical questions about where the app might be confusing or fall short of an excellent user experience for the drivers. They began with the navigational structure. What were the important functions to drivers, and how should they organize the content of the app? In the evaluation phase, they asked whether terms like “earnings” and “ratings” would translate appropriately into the other languages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://mollynix.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA good prototype is a prototype that facilitates answering the questions you have.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/nix-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Molly Nix (2)\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMolly Nix\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eUber\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “A good prototype is a prototype that facilitates answering the questions you have.” @mollycnix @Uber    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong the way, they made some interesting discoveries. For example, one of the icons for Earnings was a bar chart, which represented what the Earnings screen looked like when you tapped into it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, when they tested the prototype in India, drivers there thought the icon would take them to network settings. High latency and slow speeds kept the network at top-of-mind for Indian drivers—and the Earnings icon closely resembled common signal-strength icons you might see in the status bar of a smartphone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis discovery allowed Uber designers to alter course and create an icon more representative of cash, which solved the problem before it had a chance to crop up in a live product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/uber_earnings.gif\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2: The original Earnings icon for the Uber driver app was confusing for drivers in India. Via Molly Nix on Medium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother discovery, also related to the low speed networks, was the scenario in which a driver was starting their shift and going online to begin accepting trips. At this point, the team had moved from \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/prototype/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003elow-fidelity prototypes\u003c/a\u003e, through higher-fidelity interactive and animated prototypes, to early functional builds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn these initial builds, there was no feedback to the driver after tapping the button to go online—just a delay while the app called to the server to verify that the driver could accept trips in their current area.  To the driver, the app appeared frozen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/uber_go_online.gif\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3: An animated transition helped Uber drivers understand the app wasn\u0026#8217;t frozen when going online. Via Molly Nix on Medium.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this case, adding an animated transition, which normally might be considered non-critical “polish” of the app, was critical to its function. The animation resolved this problem and improved the user experience for drivers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne important thing the Uber team did throughout the design process was match the fidelity of their prototypes to the questions that they had to answer. Early in the process, low-fidelity prototypes were used to get a better handle on how the product translated into other languages. As the product direction solidified, higher-resolution, functional prototypes ironed out some of the potential user experience roadblocks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:765]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrototyping earlier\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a designer, you’ve almost certainly built prototypes of a product before releasing it, but you may be looking for ways to insert prototyping earlier in your process. When considering the fidelity of a prototype, it’s always important to consider the kinds of questions that you’re trying to answer and to be cautious about interpreting the results of testing very low-fidelity prototypes with users (see Daniel Burka’s sidebar about prototype fidelity).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat said, if you are working out the flow of a new feature or trying to communicate ideas to team members, \u003cem\u003esketches and paper prototypes are completely valid ways of moving forward\u003c/em\u003e. Here, we’ll outline a number of techniques and ideas for moving prototypes to the beginning of your design process. Some can also be found in the Stanford d.school \u003ca href=\"https://dschool.stanford.edu/resources/the-bootcamp-bootleg\"\u003eBootcamp Bootleg.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe timeboxed prototype\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCreate a low resolution prototype of a feature that you’d like to test with your team, before investing the time to build a higher-fidelity version to test with users.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChallenge yourself to work quickly. Set aside an hour and create 2–3 variations of the prototype. Screens can be sketched by hand, captured on a smartphone, and brought into InVision to be made interactive. Alternately, you can use the \u003ca href=\"https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2014/03/building-clickthrough-prototypes-to-support-participatory-design/#sketch-based-clickthrough-prototypes-with-pop\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrototype on Paper (POP) app\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/STS-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.switchtosketchapp.com/?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LEARN SKETCH\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/STS-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"Switch to Sketch\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.switchtosketchapp.com/?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LEARN SKETCH\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSwitch to Sketch\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLearn the basics of Sketch, plus advanced tips and tricks from the pros to accelerate your design workflow\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.switchtosketchapp.com/?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1985 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LEARN SKETCH\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLEARN SKETCH\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1985 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1985:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrototype to decide\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSettle an argument amongst your team about what direction to take a product or feature.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust like Richard Feynman and Danny Hillis, your team might have differing points of view around the direction a product may take. To make a decision, build prototypes of the competing solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf your users are going to judge, try to get to a level of fidelity that will elicit a genuine observable reaction from them—but don’t spend any more time than necessary.
