Distill the problem down as much as possible and isolate the variable you’re testing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1553]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWizard of Oz prototyping\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBuild a prototype faster by using humans on the back-end to save time and resources.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe music-streaming service Pandora has an almost magical ability to create playlists of the songs you like, just by rating a track or two with a thumbs up or down. The company likes to give credit to its Music Genome Project, which attempts to categorize all music by attributes (tempo, vocals, etc.) and then sort them using a complex algorithm.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEarly on, however, the company realized it needed a human touch to make the playlists resonate with human ears. Much like the Wizard of Oz, there’s a human behind the curtain, categorizing and describing each song as part of the “algorithm.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can take advantage of this technique, too. If you’re building a chat-bot, for example, have a human on the other end supplying the replies until you better understand the needs of the user. Or if you’re trying to build an on-demand service (let’s say Uber for dog walkers), you and your team walk the dogs yourselves before you build out the infrastructure to summon actual dog walkers on demand. Tools like \u003ca href=\"https://ifttt.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIFTTT\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://zapier.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eZapier\u003c/a\u003e can connect the services needed to build prototypes like this—pushing a button can simply send a text right to your product team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWizard of Oz prototyping allows you to learn a lot about how your users communicate before the commitment of writing any back-end code.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/craft#prototype?source=designbetter\"\u003ePrototyping in Sketch with Craft Prototype\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePrototype to teach\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 1986, 7 astronauts lost their lives when the space shuttle \u003cem\u003eChallenger\u003c/em\u003e broke apart 73 seconds into its flight. In the aftermath of this tragedy, Richard Feynman participated in a Congressional hearing investigating the cause of the disaster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn what has become a famous anecdote, he sat in front of the congressional panel and \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Rwcbsn19c0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003edemonstrated what happened to the shuttle’s O-rings\u003c/a\u003e in the colder-than-normal launch day temperature. Using a glass of water and dropping a clamped O-ring into the glass, he showed how O-rings become brittle and inflexible when exposed to the cold.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eContrast this simple demonstration with the complex charts produced by engineers in an attempt to warn about the dangers of O-ring exposure to cold temperatures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/oring_damage_v3.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 4: Complex charts, filled with \u0026#8216;chartjunk,\u0026#8217; proved to be more confusing than enlightening to those investigating the \u003cem\u003eChallenger\u003c/em\u003e disaster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce again, Feynman’s ability to distill a problem down to its essence, and to create a prototype which tested his hypothesis, was critical to his ability to share this experiment. We prototype to learn—but we can also prototype to teach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChallenge yourself to find new ways to insert prototyping into your design process—it might teach your team a fresh approach to a challenging idea. Sometimes the act of building is the best way to raise energy and surmount a problem. Just be clear about the questions you’re trying to answer and the level of fidelity you need to do so.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor many hands-on designers, prototyping is where the fun begins. And even though it’s the 4th phase of this Design Thinking framework, it can just as easily be a starting point (remember, the process is not always linear). Sometimes the key to good \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/empathize/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEmpathy\u003c/a\u003e is sharing or co-creating a prototype with your users and getting feedback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the next chapter, we’ll talk about how to use these prototypes to test your hypotheses so you can channel your inner Feynman to overcome the problem at hand.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e[inv-quote:752] One day in the early 1980s, the computer scientist Danny Hillis was having lunch with the Nobel-prize winning physicist Richard Feynman. Hillis mentioned that he was going to create a startup, with the goal of building a parallel computer that had a million processors. In typical Feynman fashion, the physicist responded that it was [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":10,"fields":{"book":["562"],"chapter_num":"05","sub_title":"Get smarter, faster","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe smartest design teams build prototypes throughout the design process. Rather than discover issues after the expense and time spent on building a complete product, challenge assumptions and solve disagreements through iterative prototyping.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292582672","related":[{"title":"Prototyping Lessons from a BMX backflip","url":"http://whiteboard.stanford.edu/blog/2014/10/16/5-prototyping-lessons-from-a-bmx-backflip","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"The Lean Product Playbook","url":"http://leanproductplaybook.com/book/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"The Skeptic’s Guide To Low-Fidelity Prototyping","url":"https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2014/10/the-skeptics-guide-to-low-fidelity-prototyping/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"10 Tips on Prototyping UIs with Sketch","url":"http://blog.invisionapp.com/10-tips-on-prototyping-uis-with-sketch/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"How I Built This (NPR): Fidelity","url":"http://sixrevisions.com/user-interface/design-mockup-fidelity/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_prototype.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Prototype - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Prototype in any fidelity for a cheaper, easier way to test your assumptions and learn what you don’t know about your idea.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-thinking/prototype"},{"id":657,"pid":0,"title":"Test","type":"chapter","date":"657","content":"\u003cp\u003eIf you’ve ever been to a spin class, you may think there isn’t much variability in the experience: a dark room, music with a beat, an instructor yelling to change the level to 8 and keep pushing. SoulCycle offers something different.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom the minute you walk in the door, SoulCycle fosters a sense of community. Heading into class, you pass by the lockers where the previous class is exiting—giving a chance for serendipitous encounters. The instructors shout inspirational quotes as you pump up a hill and hover above your saddle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith this emphasis on the whole user experience, it’s no wonder that SoulCycle has garnered something of a cult following, even at 34 bucks a class—which sell out quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e“On Mondays at noon—when the upcoming week’s schedule for SoulCycle is released—if you’re not on the computer hitting the keys right then like an eBay addict on the hunt for porcelain figurines, you’re often out of luck.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2012/09/soul-cycle-celebrity-cult-following\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e–From a Vanity Fair article on SoulCycle\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eObviously, this part of the experience doesn’t seem to be in line with the brand. SoulCycle decided to create a mobile app so riders wouldn’t have to be glued to their desktops in anticipation of booking a class.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://prolificinteractive.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eProlific Interactive\u003c/a\u003e, the agency that SoulCycle hired to create the app, went through the entire design thinking process, from empathy-based user research to testing—using InVision along the way for testing prototypes and getting feedback from stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Prolific team worked out at SoulCycle twice a week, manned the front desk at the studio, and “interviewed the founders, staff, and frequent riders to understand the inner workings of the company.” Getting insights from these observations and interviews guided them as they began working on early solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBeginner’s mind\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/zen_mind_beginners_mind_v3-min.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: \u003cem\u003eZen Mind, Beginner’s Mind\u003c/em\u003e by Shunryu Suzuki (image via Meditation Los Angeles).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdopting a beginner’s mind is valuable at every step of the design process. To test early solutions and not be blinded by assumptions, the Prolific team needed to tackle their challenge with fresh eyes. The Zen teacher Shunryu Suzuki writes that, \u0026#8220;\u003cem\u003eIn the beginner\u0026#8217;s mind there are many possibilities, in the expert\u0026#8217;s mind there are few.”\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/empathize/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEmpathize\u003c/a\u003e, it allows you to be open to the experiences of people from different backgrounds and see things from their perspectives. When you \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/define/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDefine\u003c/a\u003e, it helps you reframe your point of view to see a problem from a different angle. As you \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/ideate/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIdeate\u003c/a\u003e, a beginner’s mind prevents you from being judgmental about ideas that seem trivial or silly, but which may spur new approaches to a problem.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding your \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/prototype/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrototype\u003c/a\u003e, a beginner’s mindset helps remind you that the purpose of a prototype is to answer critical questions quickly—not to highlight your mastery as a designer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd when you \u003cem\u003etest\u003c/em\u003e your prototype, a beginner’s mindset opens you to both the many possible directions of your design and to the ways it might address real human needs. Each step along the way affords an opportunity to rethink, relearn, and reboot as needed. The design process is rarely linear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTest early, test often\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf prototyping is where the fun begins for many designers, testing is where it can get a little scary. Getting your product ideas in front of real users for feedback can be daunting. But the whole basis for prototyping early and often is intended to keep us from forming attachments to ideas that may or may not be worthwhile.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy testing our prototypes with real users in context, observing their reactions, and getting feedback, we can refine our POV, learn more about our users, and make the next iteration of the product that much better. As they say at Stanford’s d.school, “Prototype as if you know you’re right, but test as if you know you’re wrong.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s important to test prototypes early in the design process so you can quickly correct course if your product hypotheses are incorrect. As we discussed in \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/fast-feedback/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFast feedback\u003c/a\u003e, testing these assumptions early will help you build better products faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/xtine1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhile testing the app prototype, we ultimately realized that speed was critical; some of the bikes get booked in 30 seconds, so designing the flow in such a way that people wouldn’t get caught up at any step was really important.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/lee-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Christine Lee (1)\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eChristine Lee\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eProlific Interactive\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “While testing the app prototype, we ultimately realized that speed was critical…” @weareprolific’s Christine Lee    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce the Prolific team started building prototypes, they tested them on site. The great thing about this situation was they didn’t have to do any user recruiting. SoulCycle welcomed the team to run prototypes by their riders as often as they liked (while being respectful of their time, of course). This also had the benefit of mirroring the context where users were booking a class.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/invision_lofiwireframes_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2: Early wireframes of the SoulCycle app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere was already some anxiety about getting into class on time, so users were forced to go through the app test in a hurry, which quickly revealed speed bumps in the flow. The team eventually moved on to more formal user testing sessions, observing users in a conference room as they went through a few scenarios while thinking aloud.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/xtine1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWe started out by testing our prototypes in SoulCycle studios with riders. That gave us a sense of the real constraints: distractions, unstable internet connections, and time crunches. User testing challenged our assumptions and we got to get out of our own design-focused heads to see how our designs fared in the real world.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/lee-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Christine Lee (2)\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eChristine Lee\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eProlific Interactive\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “User testing challenged our assumptions, and we got to\u0026#8230;see how our designs fared in the real world.” @weareprolific’s Christine Lee    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThroughout the process, the Prolific team relied on a rapid prototyping and testing cycle and kept the SoulCycle stakeholders updated with new insights and observations, rather than “keeping the research and design process hidden behind a curtain for weeks before revealing it in a comprehensive research report that no one would end up reading.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe app is a huge hit with riders, and it’s largely thanks to the collaborative effort between Prolific, SoulCycle, and users who helped test the prototypes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKeeping a beginner’s mindset\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/dburka\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe older you get as a designer, the more you realize that you just don’t know anything … if you can embrace that you don’t know, but you know how to go find out, that makes you very effective.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/burka-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Daniel Burka\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDaniel Burka\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGoogle Ventures\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The older you get as a designer, the more you realize that you just don’t know anything…” @dburka @GVTeam    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://robotic.media.mit.edu/portfolio/tega/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eThe Tega\u003c/a\u003e is a cuddly, expressive robot that MIT researchers developed as a personalized educational assistant for young children. Designed to act as a peer in digital learning environments, Tega’s facial expression recognition allows it to mimic a child’s demeanor, which the MIT team hoped would help the robot and child bond during learning sessions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey could have tried to test this hypothesis in the lab, but they would have had no clue whether young kids would actually find the robot charming, scary, or boring. So they brought a Tega prototype to a classroom to test in context with preschoolers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe results were fantastic. Team member Goren Gordon said, “After a while the students started hugging it, touching it, making the expression it was making and playing independently with almost no intervention or encouragement.\u0026#8221; And even more crucially, Tega was able to increase the children’s positive feelings toward it with its physical behaviors—leaning over like it was interested or making happy noises.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“283992877”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese parameters are critical. They were testing the prototype in context (at a preschool, with kids in the target demographic), and were able to \u003cem\u003eobserve \u003c/em\u003ethe reactions of the users in real-time. They didn’t rely on a survey or focus group about the experience (which with children at this age wouldn’t have worked anyway). Observing these gut reactions is what makes testing with a prototype so powerful; it’s hard for people to fake enthusiasm or hide frustrations when interacting with a product, and so the signal is clear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith these tests, the MIT team was able to determine that Tega was a promising platform for other educational contexts, such as helping students with learning disabilities. And they never would have discovered this if they hadn’t brought the prototype out into the real world, embracing the fact that they didn’t know what the results would be.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHaving a beginner’s mindset and testing assumptions early in the design process will help you design better products faster. It can be just as important to carry this mindset to later tests, when a product is more developed, to answer questions about critical scenarios. This is exactly what the Google Ventures team did to help robotics company \u003ca href=\"http://www.savioke.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSavioke\u003c/a\u003e (see the interview with Daniel Burka below).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=“284354295”]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt takes a lot of effort to round up participants for in-person, one-on-one tests, but the results are compelling. Below we outline some testing techniques and suggestions for a variety of timeline and budgetary considerations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSetting up your test\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSet objectives\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat specifically are you testing, and what do you want to know? This drives everything that comes next: the questions you ask, the people you recruit, and how you determine success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRecruiting users\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs we’ve seen in the examples above, running user tests in person is the ideal situation, but recruiting users to come to your office (or better yet, to visit in-situ where they will be using the product) isn’t always feasible. In the \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/fast-feedback/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFast feedback\u003c/a\u003e section of \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrinciples of Product Design\u003c/a\u003e, we run through some ideas for recruiting both in-person and remote users.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eErika Hall’s \u003ca href=\"https://abookapart.com/products/just-enough-research\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJust Enough Research\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e also has some fantastic tips for recruiting users. She highlights the importance of setting the parameters for a good research participant (e.g., “shares the concerns and goals of your target users” and “can articulate their thoughts clearly”). She also outlines how to create a screener, so you can “weed out the ax murderers and the fatally inarticulate.” And she gives some great tips on places to post a link to the screener—friends and family can be a great resource for sharing (assuming they are likely to reach your target demographic), and Craigslist (along with social media) is your friend.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re constrained to remote testing, services like \u003ca href=\"https://ethn.io/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eethn.io\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://www.usertesting.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eUserTesting\u003c/a\u003e can provide you with users in fairly targeted demographics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTesting the prototype\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce you’ve recruited your users, create an experience for them that puts the prototype into a context as close to real life use as possible, whether it’s before a workout like SoulCycle or testing in a hotel like Savioke. You want your users to react to the \u003cem\u003eexperience\u003c/em\u003e, not to an explanation of the prototype. The more real-life it feels, the more natural these reactions will be.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s also important to show, not tell. Once your user is set up with the experience, prototype in hand, don’t explain everything right away. Give them a chance to figure things out, and observe how they use the product. Is it intuitive, or are your users confused or frustrated? What kind of questions do they have? Look for smiles or frowns as they work with the prototype.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, remember in the \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/ideate/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIdeate\u003c/a\u003e phase where you came up with several ideas to test? It can be helpful to bring multiple prototypes to a testing session. This will give users more fodder to react to and compare against (e.g. “the version of the SoulCycle app that introduced the trainer with a video was great, but I really just need to book my session as quickly as possible, so I’m more inclined to use the version without it because it’s faster.”)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCapturing video and audio of your users in action with the prototype will be helpful in the next step. You don’t need anything fancy—just use the equipment you have at hand (smartphones and screen recording software will work just fine). Michael Margolis at Google Ventures outlines a \u003ca href=\"https://library.gv.com/the-gv-research-sprint-interview-participants-and-summarize-findings-day-4-3d34792baa3f#.79dmmxamn\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eslightly more elaborate setup\u003c/a\u003e, which can be handy if you’re testing mobile prototypes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReviewing and synthesizing observations\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter you’re done with testing sessions, it’s important to take the time to review and synthesize your findings. Again, \u003ca href=\"https://abookapart.com/products/just-enough-research\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eJust Enough Research\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e is a great resource for this. In her section on analyzing the data from user research, Erika Hall outlines how to structure the session (summarize goals, pull quotes and observations), the space and supplies you’ll need (sticky notes and sharpies!), and the types of data to look for (user goals and priorities).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother great resource for debriefing and synthesizing is from Brendan Mulligan at Cluster. \u003ca href=\"https://library.launchkit.io/how-to-run-live-user-testing-part-3-the-debrief-d057dbe3a979#.sm6e6vfb3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMulligan outlines some great tips and techniques\u003c/a\u003e for holding a viewing party and capturing insights from your team, and identifying and bucketing patterns as a group.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce you’ve had a chance to synthesize the data and group patterns, take a look at how they support or contradict your original POVs. This is an iterative process. Testing your prototypes should give you a chance to refine your original hypotheses and make the product that much better in the next round.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEmpathy and compassion\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe beginner’s mind is the mind of compassion. When our mind is compassionate, it is boundless.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/suzuki-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Shunryu Suzuki\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eShunryu Suzuki\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eZen Mind, Beginner’s Mind\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The beginner’s mind is the mind of compassion. When our mind is compassionate, it is boundless.” -Shunryu Suzuki, “Zen Mind, Beginner’s Mind”    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmpathy is the heart of design, as it allows us to experience the situations our users find themselves in. Empathy lets us discover opportunities to make those experiences less frightening—like \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/design-thinking/define/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDoug Dietz\u003c/a\u003e did for children needing MRIs—or more delightful, like the Savioke team did with Relay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompassion in tandem with a beginner’s mind helps us translate empathy into action. If we instill a sense of duty toward users in our designs, we can align our products with the humans who use them—and perhaps improve their lives along the way. We can remain open to the possibility that our first ideas weren’t our best ideas, and that by taking an iterative approach and gaining insights from our users as we test prototypes, we can make better products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs designers, we have a real impact on how our products take shape, how users experience them, and the consequences of their use. We hope that you have a chance to use these opportunities with empathy and compassion, and design products that you’re proud to bring into the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-xlarge full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: #782aa0;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Leadership-Book-xl_2x-1920x1102.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-leadership-handbook\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Leadership-Book-xl_2x-1920x1102.png\" alt=\"Build a first-class design team\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: team\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eDesign Leadership Handbook\u003c/em\u003e is your guide to transitioning to design leadership and building strong teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-leadership-handbook\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1578 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener #782aa0;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1578:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #782aa0;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #782aa0;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eIf you’ve ever been to a spin class, you may think there isn’t much variability in the experience: a dark room, music with a beat, an instructor yelling to change the level to 8 and keep pushing. SoulCycle offers something different. From the minute you walk in the door, SoulCycle fosters a sense of community. [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":11,"fields":{"book":["562"],"chapter_num":"06","sub_title":"Early and often","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003ePrototyping forms a key step in solid product design, but the best design teams go a step further and test their products with real users. Observing how your end user approaches your product gives you the most important feedback of all.\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"294297780","related":[{"title":"Just Enough Research","url":"https://abookapart.com/products/just-enough-research","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"How to run live user testing Part 3: the debrief","url":"https://library.launchkit.io/how-to-run-live-user-testing-part-3-the-debrief-d057dbe3a979#.sm6e6vfb3","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"The GV Research Sprint: Interview participants and summarize findings","url":"https://library.launchkit.io/how-to-run-live-user-testing-part-3-the-debrief-d057dbe3a979#.sm6e6vfb3","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Remote User Testing at Vox","url":"http://product.voxmedia.com/2016/5/26/11787530/remote-user-testing-at-vox","target":{"_self":"Same Window"}}]},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_designthinking_test.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Test - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"After you’ve put in all the blood, sweat, and tears—it’s time to put your product in front of real users for testing and feedback.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"design-thinking/test"},{"id":126,"pid":0,"title":"Guess less","type":"chapter","date":"126","content":"\u003cp\u003eHave you ever bought a lottery ticket? I admit, I’ve played a few times. You won’t be surprised to learn I never did win the big jackpot. Seeing winners on the evening news gives the false impression that anyone could win, but the odds of winning are long—\u003cem\u003every\u003c/em\u003e long.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRod Wolfe knows a thing or 2 about long odds. His friends call him \u003ca href=\"http://time.com/3937179/lightning-strikes-man-twice-rod-wolfe-survivor/\"\u003e“Lightning Rod”\u003c/a\u003e because he’s been struck by lightning not once, but \u003cem\u003etwice\u003c/em\u003e. What are the chances? Well, you’re more likely to be the next Rod Wolfe than you are the next lottery winner.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe software industry has a lot in common with the lottery. We see big winners in the news everyday—Facebook, Uber, Airbnb. Their success bolsters our ambitions of making the next big product. Our ambitions are big and we act fast hoping to beat competitors to the market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSoftware success hinges on a lottery-like collection of variables: the right product with the right features for the right audience in the right market. If you’re even a little bit off in your planning, you can end up wasting time and resources, and potentially put your company in a very difficult situation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv id=\"daniel_burka_1\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:131]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOptimistic that they already understand how to design a winning product and eager to get to market, many companies dive straight into production without spending time learning about customers and their needs. They base their designs on guesses that make the odds of success long.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"//muledesign.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIf you’re going to solve a problem, you want sufficient information to solve it.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/hall.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Erika Hall\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eErika Hall\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMule Design\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “If you’re going to solve a problem, you want sufficient information to solve it.” @mulegirl    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cdiv id=\"erika_hall_1\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:320]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eGuesses make messes\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://buffer.com\"\u003eBuffer\u003c/a\u003e, a popular publishing platform for social networks, found itself in financial turmoil in part because they’d over-invested in products and features that weren’t relevant to their customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWe have a bias toward action at Buffer, and believe that moving fast and being bold are important. Optimism has seen us through a lot of mistakes at Buffer, like the countless new features and products we spent months building only to realize we need to scrap them. Content suggestions and our Daily iOS app are just a couple.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut after a certain point in a company, the mistakes we make don’t just affect the product features. They affect people’s lives.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/gasicogne-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Joel Gascoigne\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJoel Gascoigne\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eCEO at Buffer\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “But after a certain point in a company, the mistakes\u0026#8230;affect people’s lives.” @joelgascoigne @buffer    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuffer had to let 10 employees go and made painful budget cuts to recover. The good news is they’re starting to get back on track, but optimism and assumptions almost took them down. If you’ve spent time in the software industry you know Buffer’s story isn’t unique.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSo many companies base their strategies on optimistic guesses and get it wrong far too often.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eGuessing is expensive\u003c/em\u003e—if you’re wrong you could be out of business.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eGuessing puts you at a competitive disadvantage\u003c/em\u003e—when you know little about the customers you serve, you know little about how to succeed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eGuessing is arrogant\u003c/em\u003e—you’re lying if you think you understand your customers without studying them first.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere’s a way to tweak your odds of succeeding, though. Rather than making assumptions about customers, we can start to learn from them. Customer research is easy to do and can be folded into any workflow—Sprints, Agile, Lean, whatever! As you start to think about customer research, you’ll probably find you have a lot of data already on hand that can inform your work—you just need to bring it to the surface.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv id=\"laura_martini_1\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYou win a race at the finish line, not the starting block.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/martini-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Laura Martini\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eLaura Martini\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGoogle\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “You win a race at the finish line, not the starting block.” @martinibot    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:458]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGuessing makes your odds of success long. Let’s stop playing the product design lottery and start getting the insights we need to make great products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s how to do it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eResearch fast and make things\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomer research fits into every workflow, every role, and every company size. Whether you’re a designer, project manager, or director, the goal is to guess less and work from a position of being informed and confident.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhen designers don’t know which problems to solve, we spin our wheels. We make products prettier when we could be solving customer’s needs and generating real value. So any company that’s serious about design should get equally serious about listening to customers.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/kowitz-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Braden Kowitz\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBraden Kowitz\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGoogle Ventures\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “When designers don’t know which problems to solve, we spin our wheels.” @kowitz @GVTeam    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are 2 types of research you can do to learn about your customers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuantitative:\u003c/strong\u003e These are the things we can measure. Examples include analytics that communicate customer behavioral patterns and aggregate stats about customer cohorts.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQualitative:\u003c/strong\u003e These are things that tell us about the qualities of a product or experience. Customer interviews, for example, give us insights about how a customer feels, which can provide a lot of insight into what motivates their behavior.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThink of quantitative and qualitative research as the \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ktUx57i63e0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eWonder Twins\u003c/a\u003e. They each have incredible powers, but they’re much more useful when they work together. Relying on 1 can sometimes lead you down the wrong path.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor instance, a couple years ago the user research team at MailChimp stumbled upon an interesting piece of quantitative data: many customers connected their Facebook accounts to their MailChimp accounts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on the quantitative findings, the product team started to consider how to further the MailChimp-Facebook connection, but the qualitative findings from customer interviews told a different tale. Most customers only connected to Facebook because it seemed like something they \u003cem\u003eshould\u003c/em\u003e do given the social network’s popularity, \u003cem\u003ebut they never actually did anything meaningful with the integration\u003c/em\u003e. The product team changed course once the qualitative findings clarified the motivations behind the customer behavior.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eQuantitative and qualitative findings\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNumbers give the illusion of certainty, but they can be misleading if not verified with qualitative findings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;330244989\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSurveys that impact product design\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSurveys are a handy way to learn about your customers and can be conducted ad hoc or even automated. There is a host of different surveys you could run, but use them sparingly, as too many will alienate customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is an art to creating effective surveys, and the \u003ca href=\"https://library.gv.com/improve-your-startup-s-surveys-and-get-even-better-data-7b0272f74c23#.uxkcogqna\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGoogle Ventures team has a wonderful guide\u003c/a\u003e that will help you avoid rookie mistakes as you begin this practice.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTips for building effective surveys\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStart simple with clear goals about what you want to learn.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eKeep your surveys as short as possible to get better response rates. “Nice-to-know” questions should be cut, as they just increase the length of your survey.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNever ask respondents for information you could get yourself. For example, don’t ask when someone signed up for your service if you already have that info in your database.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRandomize answers to question to avoid \u003ca href=\"http://austinresearch.co.uk/avoiding-response-bias-due-to-answer-order/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eresponse order bias\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConclude with an open-ended question like, “Is there anything else you want to tell us?” to give respondents an opportunity to surface interesting issues that may surprise you. This is a great way to find good candidates for interviews.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRun a pilot test of your survey with a small sample of people before you send it to everyone. This will help you find questions that may be missing response options or identify places where things aren’t clear.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://blog.mailchimp.com/reducing-irrelevance/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSpend time carefully writing the email asking customers to take your survey\u003c/a\u003e, as it will greatly influence your response rate.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;284167285\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAutomated surveys\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho they help:\u003c/strong\u003e Everyone!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy they’re useful:\u003c/strong\u003e After you set up an automated survey, data keeps streaming in, giving you fresh insights regularly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eData kung fu\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse a tool like \u003ca href=\"https://zapier.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003eZapier\u003c/a\u003e to forward all survey responses into a shared Google Sheet, or even an Evernote account where your team can search through all responses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTypes of automated surveys you might send\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_Promoter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNet Promoter Score\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e:\u003c/strong\u003e Learn about your customers’ loyalty to your brand. \u003ca href=\"https://delighted.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDelighted\u003c/a\u003e is a lovely tool to run regular NPS surveys.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter sign up:\u003c/strong\u003e Find out why customers signed up, and from which competitor they’re switching. This is useful for marketing teams as it helps identify the language that motivates buying behavior. Send this within a few days of sign up while their memories are still fresh.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter account closing:\u003c/strong\u003e Find out why they’re leaving. Is it you or just circumstance? Are they switching to a competitor? Link to your survey on the page in your app confirming their account is closed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTopic specific:\u003c/strong\u003e Use a tool like \u003ca href=\"https://ethn.io/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEthnio\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href=\"https://qualaroo.com/product/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eQualaroo\u003c/a\u003e to deliver a micro-survey to specific customers. By placing a small code snippet on a carefully selected page in your Knowledge Base, you can find a customer with expertise on almost any topic.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/airbnb-ethnio_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1: Airbnb uses Ethnio to learn about customers and identify the right ones to interview.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAd hoc surveys\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho they help:\u003c/strong\u003e Teams doing a deep dive on a feature or topic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy they’re useful:\u003c/strong\u003e They can give you an aggregate view of customers’ thoughts on a topic, and help you find outliers who may make for good interviews.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eSmarter response filtering\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsk a question or 2 at the beginning of the survey to help you filter responses later. For example, a question like, “How old is your business?” or, “About how many people are in your organization?” can expose different responses from various customer cohorts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAd hoc surveys can be conducted in many ways. You can send \u003ca href=\"https://24ways.org/2013/data-driven-design-with-an-annual-survey/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ean annual survey\u003c/a\u003e to collect customer data to inform projects throughout the year. You could also send a survey to gather insights or guide development on a specific feature or new product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou needn’t survey \u003cem\u003eall\u003c/em\u003e of your customers to get the results you need. Surveying too many people will produce lower response rates and introduce unwanted noise into your data. Instead, use your customer data to target the right people for your study before you send.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, want to learn more about customers who sell things online? Find a segment of those customers who have a shopping cart platform, like Shopify, integrated with your app. Want to hear from customers who are highly engaged with your product? Segment by ‘times logged in this month.’\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNetflix, Airbnb, and Intuit have all used automated and ad hoc surveys to inform their work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCustomer interviews\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomer interviews deliver a \u003cem\u003ewealth\u003c/em\u003e of information that will help you design more successful products. They’ll give you a glimpse into the emotions that drive customer behavior, help you understand your customers’ workflows, and let you hear the language people use when describing your product. This is essential stuff!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eFinding your next product idea\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomer interviews are the best way to find the idea for your next product or the vision for the future version of your product. Getting a glimpse into the daily lives of your customers will show you where they struggle and the opportunities for designing products that will solve their problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut your time is limited and you probably can’t spend weeks talking to dozens of customers. How can you find the people with the most insight? The answer lies in your survey responses!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour survey generated data from a variety of customers who can help you better understand how to design your product. Drop your survey response data into Excel and filter to find any of these types of customers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePeople nearby you can visit in person\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePeople who just signed up\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePeople who just closed their account\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePeople with interesting traits, behaviors, or off-the-wall responses\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePeople who’ve said they would or would not recommend your product to a friend\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen you’ve found customers of interest, send them a short, personal email asking to learn more about them. Interviews by Skype or Google Hangouts can be conducted in a conference room where your whole team can listen in—they’ll comprehend the feedback more easily if they hear from the customer themselves. About 20-30 minutes is all that’s needed for a phone interview. It’s always a good idea to record interviews so you can reference them later.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVisiting customers in person takes a bit more time, but can be eye-opening. You’ll get to see the hardware they use, the distractions of their office, the flow of their day, and meet some of their colleagues. The entire experience will be a vivid reminder to you and your team that you’re designing products for real people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTips for conducting customer interviews\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCustomer interviews needn’t always be connected to a project. You can dedicate a day or 2 per month to talk to customers to keep your team in the habit of learning.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLimit the number of people conducting the interview so you don’t overwhelm your participant.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAssign a person to take notes so the person asking questions is free to drive the conversation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWatch for signs of an energy change from the subject, raised voice, the use of profanity to punctuate a story, leaning in to emphasize a point—these indicate what’s important to your customer, and directs you to ideas for refinement or even new products.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBring a voice recorder to capture the interview so you don’t feel compelled to furiously capture every word.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEach interview will yield 1 or 2 golden insights. Don’t get lost in the details—train your ears to listen for the meaningful insights.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse \u003ca href=\"https://jtbd.info/a-script-to-kickstart-your-jobs-to-be-done-interviews-2768164761d7#.cxcrllb2j\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ethe Switch Interview technique\u003c/a\u003e to learn from people who just bought or just left your product.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile at MailChimp, my team noticed a small trend of customers departing us for more complex and more expensive competitors. Using surveys, we recruited customers who had just recently closed an account and cited a competitor\u0026#8217;s platform as the reason. We set up 60-minute calls with a handful, and spent 2 days interviewing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe survey pointed us in the right direction, but the interviews provided the missing link: these customers weren\u0026#8217;t leaving because of the app\u0026#8217;s shortcomings; they were leaving because of a perception problem. They mistook the simplicity of the app for a lack of sophistication. These former customers were looking for a complex tool to make them feel like the accomplished professionals they are. It was eye-opening, and helped illuminate a new product direction for MailChimp.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Workshops-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Workshops-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"Expert workshops for your team\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eExpert workshops for your team\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBring DesignBetter.Co to your team with our design workshops—coming soon\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/workshops\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1660 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"REQUEST A WORKSHOP\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eREQUEST A WORKSHOP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1660 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1660:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eExisting data\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSometimes guessing less simply means becoming aware of the data you already have. That’s exactly what happened at \u003ca href=\"http://www.bambora.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBambora\u003c/a\u003e, a new global payments company based in Stockholm. Creative Director \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/andersfardigh/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAnders Färdigh\u003c/a\u003e and his design team craved more insight to guide their work, but the thought of building a dedicated research team felt premature. Maybe there was a simpler starting point?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/break-black-box/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDuring a meeting\u003c/a\u003e with their COO Patrik Göthlin, Anders discovered that much of the insight his team needed \u003cem\u003ewas already being gathered\u003c/em\u003e. Patrick’s operations team was doing extensive \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_Promoter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eNet Promoter Score\u003c/a\u003e research, surveying Bambora’s customers to determine their loyalty to the brand, and following up with detractors to learn where they were falling short. They’d even been visiting customers in person to capture feedback about their products. There was so much information already on hand to help the design and product teams prioritize their work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn large organizations, it’s hard to know what research is already siloed within other teams. That’s why it’s important to spend time talking with colleagues on other teams to learn about their work and the research already underway.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;284635494\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGet started by talking to people in these teams\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSales:\u003c/strong\u003e These folks talk with customers all day. They’re collecting insights about product shortcomings and data about every potential customer. You may find that the data the sales team tracks in Salesforce could help you identify interesting customers to interview.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMarketing:\u003c/strong\u003e Analytics often falls to the marketing team to track. They can give you access to Google Analytics and other tools that may help you understand customer pathways and raise questions about interesting customer behaviors. Marketers are often at events talking with customers, and may have insights to share with you.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCustomer service:\u003c/strong\u003e Few teams have as much actionable information for refining your product as the customer service team. They hear the struggles of your customer daily, and they know what themes are strongest. Make a habit of talking to many customer service agents to get the broadest perspective on your customers’ pain points.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eData science:\u003c/strong\u003e Your customer database is a goldmine of information. If you have a data science team then chances are they’re already querying that database to find customer cohorts. This team will be your most treasured ally as you dig deeper into customer research.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEngineering:\u003c/strong\u003e You’re probably already working closely with the engineering team on the product, but you should also be talking to them about the data they could be logging for you. Curious about which integrations customers connect first to your app, or failure rates of a particular workflow? Your engineering colleagues can probably log that data for you and have the app email you a report.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLearning in the background\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are a number of handy tools that can collect data for you behind the scenes, giving you yet another source of information to tap when you need it most.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFullstory\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHave you ever wished you could just watch your customers using your product to see where they stumble? \u003ca href=\"http://fullstory.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFullstory\u003c/a\u003e gives you that super power. It’s like a DVR for your app or website—it captures every session in your app and lets you play them back.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/fullstory_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2. Fullstory is like a DVR for customer sessions in your app. It’s a fast way to learn how you can improve your product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWant to see sessions of every customer who’s signed up in the past week and clicked the help button? Or maybe you want to see sessions where a specific error happened so you can diagnose the problem. Fullstory has incredible search options to help you filter sessions to find exactly what you’re looking for.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIntercom\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.intercom.io/customer-feedback\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIntercom’s customer feedback features\u003c/a\u003e can help you get in touch with customers who have taken specific actions, so you can then ask them about their experience. Once you’ve defined the rules for the customers you want to speak with, you can create automated messages to be sent via email or in-app. All of the feedback lands in a shared inbox, where your team can tag and organize messages to identify patterns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBuiltwith\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can learn a lot about your customers just by examining the tools they use, and \u003ca href=\"http://builtwith.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBuiltwith\u003c/a\u003e will help you discover every technology your customers use to power their website. When a new customer signs up for your product, pass their URL over to the Builtwith API to retrieve and store their tech stack data for your research.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKnowing that a customer is using Shopify, MailChimp, and Zendesk gives you clues about their business—they sell stuff online and have marketing and customer service teams; they’re using tools that are very design focused; and they’re using tools that are DIY, so they may not have developers on staff.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you look at the tech stacks of your customers you’ll begin to read them like tea leaves, giving you clues that can guide you to the right interviews and aggregate data to understand customer cohorts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch1\u003eAgainst all odds\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou know why the lottery is fun despite being a losing game? There\u0026#8217;s not much at stake. I know the odds are wildly against me, but when I lose I\u0026#8217;ll only be out a few bucks. Rent will still get paid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct design also has tough odds, but the stakes are much higher. If your product fails to get traction with your customers, you and your colleagues could be out of a job.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026#8220;Fail fast\u0026#8221; is the mantra of the software industry. The surest way to achieve that goal is by basing your product design on guesses. Successful, design-driven companies are doing just the opposite—they\u0026#8217;re \u003cem\u003esucceeding\u003c/em\u003e fast by guessing less. They\u0026#8217;re finding ways to inform their work each step of the way, tapping into existing data, setting up systems to continuously gather feedback, and they\u0026#8217;re talking to their customers all the time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResearch isn’t some monolithic, academic process. It can fit into every workflow, every role, and every company size. Whether you’re a designer, project manager, or director, the goal is to guess less and work from a position of strength by being informed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-small-v1_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGET STARTED NOW\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1997 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1997:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eHave you ever bought a lottery ticket? I admit, I’ve played a few times. You won’t be surprised to learn I never did win the big jackpot. Seeing winners on the evening news gives the false impression that anyone could win, but the odds of winning are long—very long. Rod Wolfe knows a thing or [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":13,"fields":{"book":["74"],"chapter_num":"01","sub_title":"Stop wasting time","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe software industry celebrates stories of lightning-strike success so much, you’d think hunches and risky bets could create unicorns. The best product design teams understand the reality—customer research forms the bedrock of successful products and companies.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292445922","related":[{"title":"The Complete Beginner's Guide to Design Research","url":"http://www.uxbooth.com/articles/complete-beginners-guide-to-design-research/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Minimum Viable Changing","url":"https://medium.com/@johnpcutler/10-ways-ux-research-is-changing-62fde944672","target":{"_blank":"New
