co-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_guessless.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_guessless.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Guess less - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Stop relying on hunches and waiting for lightning strikes—base your product design on customer research, not guesses.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"principles-of-product-design/guess-less"},{"id":150,"pid":0,"title":"Story first","type":"chapter","date":"150","content":"\u003cp\u003eStory is a profoundly important device to unite design teams around a shared product vision. This powerful communication tool helps us retain information and empathize with others. As companies scale and teams sprint through product iterations, it’s easy to lose sight of how your product should fit into the lives of your customers. The best way to keep everyone pointed in the right direction is with a \u003cstrong\u003eclear, compelling story\u003c/strong\u003e—a story that will unite and guide teams towards success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI think what’s most important is you have to have a North Star or vision set. If people don’t have that, the mess builds up.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/wood-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Stanley Wood\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eStanley Wood\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eSpotify\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “\u0026#8230;you have to have a North Star or vision set. If people don’t have that, the mess builds up.” @hellostanley @spotify    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct roadmaps guide team milestones, but they only show us \u003cem\u003ewhat\u003c/em\u003e to build and \u003cem\u003ewhen\u003c/em\u003e. They don’t show us \u003cem\u003ewhy\u003c/em\u003e we’re building a product. Stories, however, are great at explaining why.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1591842808/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eStart with Why\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, author Simon Sinek proclaims, “People don\u0026#8217;t buy what you do; they buy why you do it. And what you do simply proves what you believe.” Similarly, the best product teams don’t merely \u003cem\u003efollow\u003c/em\u003e a process; they march toward a shared destination—a vision of the future presented as a story that answers, “Why are we building this?”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’ve been using stories to answer big questions for thousands of years. Long before humans could write, we used stories to share our most important messages. Through story, \u003ca href=\"http://www.ancient-origins.net/human-origins-folklore/australian-aboriginals-creation-myth-00229\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAborigines passed down their origin through thousands of generations\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lascaux\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eancient cave painters depicted the movements of the constellations and the magic of the spirit world\u003c/a\u003e. Story is a tried-and-true methodology for collective understanding.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’ve been encoding information in stories for so long, our minds have evolved into story super-processors, easily plucking out important messages for long-term recall and helping us empathize with others. \u003ca href=\"https://people.stanford.edu/jaaker/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eJennifer Aaker\u003c/a\u003e, Professor of Marketing at the Stanford Graduate School of Business, has found “people remember information when it’s weaved into narratives up to 22 times more than facts alone.” \u003ca href=\"http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/11/the-psychological-comforts-of-storytelling/381964/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFindings from a study published in the journal \u003cem\u003eScience\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e suggest that literary fiction “uniquely engages the psychological processes needed to gain access to characters’ subjective experiences.” In other words, we can more keenly empathize with others when we learn about them through story.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike thousands of stories told through the ages, product stories connect people and ideas. There are many ways to tell a product story, but they all start with a little planning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-Report-2-450x340-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/ROI-Report-2-450x340-900x680.png\" alt=\"The business impact of design\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe business impact of design\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSee how design impacts business and drives value at the world’s most innovative companies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1956 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"SEE THE REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSEE THE REPORT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1956 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1956:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #0828cc;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePlanning a product story\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct stories find their origins \u003ca href=\"https://www.designbetter.co/principles-of-product-design/guess-less\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ein research\u003c/a\u003e, not genius. Customer interviews will expose important moments of frustration, aspiration, and triumph—all of which are potential plot points in your story. \u003ca href=\"http://blog.invisionapp.com/improving-ux-with-pixars-storytelling-rules/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePixar uses a simple narrative structure\u003c/a\u003e to capture the essence of a story.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA narrative framework from Pixar\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce upon a time there was ______. Every day_______. One day ______. Because of that, ______. Because of that, ______. Until finally ______.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePixar’s narrative shorthand makes it easy to flesh out a plot for a product story, and makes plain why your product is important to build. For example, let’s plug Airbnb’s product into this framework:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOnce upon a time there was\u003c/strong\u003e an artistic couple in Asheville, NC living in a charming home with a guest cottage out back. \u003cstrong\u003eEvery day\u003c/strong\u003e they left each other and their lovely home to earn the money to help them pay their mortgage. \u003cstrong\u003eOne day\u003c/strong\u003e they discovered a way to earn extra money by renting their guest cottage. \u003cstrong\u003eBecause of that\u003c/strong\u003e, they were able to pay off their mortgage more quickly and save a bit extra for retirement. \u003cstrong\u003eBecause of that\u003c/strong\u003e, they spent less time working and more time together. \u003cstrong\u003eUntil finally\u003c/strong\u003e they were able to retire and live the life they’d dreamed of.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike design comps and prototypes, product stories aren’t concerned with the UI of the product—just the people who will use it and in what context. A product story is very high level, answering a simple question: \u003cem\u003ehow will this product fit into the lives of others?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo answer this question, we can follow these principles\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA good product story demonstrates how a cast of characters—your customers—behaves in specific settings.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAn effective product story shows how your product creates value in your customers’ lives.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAn achievable product story takes place in the near future—freeing your team from the technical constraints of today. Show people the future that can be created if everyone works together.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA product story is a visual explanation. It should be shared as a storyboard, a map, a comic, a series of illustrations, or a video.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHumans are visual thinkers. We often need to \u003cem\u003esee\u003c/em\u003e something before we can comprehend it. Visuals will turn the abstract ideas of a product concept into a North Star that can guide teams to deliver on that vision.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA story map is not a mock up, it is a guide to make sure everyone is solving the same problem, building the same product and pointing at the same piece of paper while making decisions.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/buckhouse-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"James Buckhouse\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJames Buckhouse\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eSequoia Capital\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “A story map is not a mock up, it is a guide to make sure everyone is solving the same problem…” @buckhouse @Sequoia    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne thing to keep in mind is that a product story shouldn’t be overly prescriptive about how to realize that future. Every team involved—designers, developers, marketers, ops—will have to use their own domain expertise and judgment to deliver on their end of the work. The product story should inspire and inform but never dictate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:473]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCreating the product story\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct stories can take many forms: journey maps, storyboards, videos, even comics. Like any story, there’s an element of entertainment required to generate excitement among your teams and stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCrafting user journey maps\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href=\"http://rosenfeldmedia.com/books/storymapping/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eThe User’s Journey\u003c/a\u003e, Donna Lichaw points out stories tend to follow a common structure. We’re introduced to the characters, their goals, and the setting for the story in the exposition. Conflict ensues, rising to a climactic event, then the characters find a resolution to their problems. Pixar’s narrative structure seen earlier follows a very similar story arc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/asset-24_700px.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. The common structure stories follow as explained by Donna Lichaw in her book The User’s Journey.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFollowing this story structure we can create a user journey map—an exploration of the myriad ways in which users interact with your product or service over time and across different channels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/asset-23_700px.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2. Donna Lichaw uses the story arc to depict the user’s journey as she discovers and starts using Slack.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA user journey map can be done \u003ca href=\"https://www.usertesting.com/blog/2015/04/02/customer-journey-mapping/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ein many\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"http://uxmastery.com/how-to-create-a-customer-journey-map/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eways\u003c/a\u003e, but simple sketches like those presented in \u003cem\u003eThe User’s Journey\u003c/em\u003e are particularly powerful as they’re fast and more fun than formal documents.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuick tips to build your user journey map\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIdentify the main character’s goals and the problems they face.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBe specific where possible. Quotes from customers and specific findings from research will give your user journey map details that will bring it to life.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePoint out the hurdles the user must overcome to get to the resolution they desire.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInclude the devices and channels of communication involved in the user’s journey.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSpeech bubbles let you expose the customer’s thoughts and words along the way.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse a whiteboard or big paper on a wall to work as a team.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYour user journey map will reach more people if it’s informative \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e fun.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:487]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eStoryboarding for product design\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStoryboards—a collection of illustrated panels with short descriptions depicting key points in a story—are a tool often used by animation and film studios to work through narrative concepts. \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storyboard\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eThey were first developed at Walt Disney Studios\u003c/a\u003e during the production of \u003cem\u003eThree Little Pigs\u003c/em\u003e in 1933.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/disney-storyboard_toned.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3. Walt Disney and his team review a storyboard for their groundbreaking film Snow White and the Seven Dwarves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, storyboards have found their way into the product design process. According to \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/nathanblec\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eNate Blecharczyk\u003c/a\u003e, co-founder and CTO at Airbnb, the act of creating a storyboard was a “galvanizing event for the company.” Brian Chesky, CEO of Airbnb, was inspired by how Disney Studios made a huge leap from short animations to their first full-length film, \u003cem\u003eSnow White and the Seven Dwarves\u003c/em\u003e, using storyboarding to shape the narrative.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAirbnb’s quick initial success portended a large opportunity for growth, but Chesky struggled to see where they might best invest the company’s resources. Taking a cue from Disney, he worked with the design team to produce a storyboard showing the story of their 2 types of customers: guests and a hosts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:511]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs Brian Chesky explains, \u0026#8220;When you have to storyboard something, the more realistic it is, the more decisions you have to make.\u0026#8221; The act of drawing the frames of their storyboards forced the Airbnb team to consider the way their customers feel in each step of the process of renting or hosting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVisualizing the experience puts you and your team there in the scene, building empathy with users as you strategize the design solutions. Airbnb’s storyboard helped everyone in their rapidly growing company rally around a common cause to design the products that will best serve their customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough Airbnb’s storyboards are very high-fidelity, you don’t need to hire Pixar-quality illustrators to produce your company’s story.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuick tips to build your product design storyboard\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePost sticky notes in a grid on a conference room wall and sketch out each scene with Sharpies. Stick figures will suffice, but if you want to refine your drawing skills a bit check out \u003ca href=\"http://rosenfeldmedia.com/books/see-what-i-mean/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSee What I Mean\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, \u003c/em\u003eKevin Cheng’s guide to drawing product stories. The act of thinking through the characters and the context of how your product will be used is the most important part of this process.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate photo storyboards using your phone. Get a few people together to act out the product experience, and snap photos of each step. Having \u003ca href=\"http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00HK8V4NC/ref=psdc_172646_t1_B004SGF82M\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea cheap wireless printer\u003c/a\u003e on hand will make it easy to produce a high-fidelity storyboard in just a couple of hours. Drop your photos into Keynote or PowerPoint to create a quick presentation that can be shared in meetings or emails.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOnline tools like \u003ca href=\"https://boords.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBoards\u003c/a\u003e let you piece together a storyboard quickly and share with colleagues.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Podcast-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Podcast-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"The DesignBetter.Co Podcast\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe DesignBetter.Co Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJoin the world’s best designers on the DesignBetter.Co Podcast to explore product-driven companies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1654 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLISTEN AND LEARN\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1654 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1654:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eVideo product stories\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen the stakes are high and the timeline to completion is long, consider producing your product story as a video, which will help the people making a product connect with the customer experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVideo transports us to new places and makes us feel like we’re part of the story. Video’s immersive qualities also make it good at forming long-term memories—yet another important advantage when mobilizing large teams toward a common cause.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVideo is also easy to share. Once you upload your video to a service like Vimeo, your product vision will have a URL that can be dropped in an email or a Slack channel for all to view and reference.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne disadvantage to producing video product stories is the required time commitment: you’ll need to write a script, gather some people to serve as your actors, and maybe rent some basic video equipment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile preparing for a major app redesign, the UX team I led at MailChimp produced \u003ca href=\"https://vimeo.com/97337160\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea vision video to guide the company\u003c/a\u003e on what was to be a 4-month project. The research team noticed, after a number of customer visits, that people were doing work differently. Internet connections on phones and tablets let people work anywhere and all the time, ducking in and out of small tasks. This created a sense of found time quickly filled up with more to-dos. As people became overwhelmed with their work, they needed to hand things off to others. Seeing these behavioral patterns, we realized we needed to rethink how MailChimp handled collaboration across many devices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe project required the collaboration of many teams. We wrote a short script and worked with our in-house videographer to produce a brief vision video in about 10 days.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:617]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe production was inexpensive and relatively fast, but the outcome was of high enough fidelity to guide designers, developers, marketers, and other stakeholders around the company as they worked to realize the vision set forth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuick tips to build your video\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDetermine if the scope of the project warrants a video. New products, long projects, and cross-channel experiences are well served by video product stories.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePlan ahead—video shoots can take a bit more time.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAvoid specifics like a detailed UI—focus on how the product needs to fit into the lives of your customers, not how the product looks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eKeep things simple. Enlist colleagues and friends to act out the parts. Use a DSLR camera to shoot and simple editing software like iMovie to produce your video.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSkip the dialogue to speed up video production. Use speech bubble overlays instead.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eProduct story offshoots\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStories are always better with well developed characters. User personas and job stories can help you transform findings about customers into clear portraits of the people you’re designing for and their behavioral motivations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eUser personas\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUser Personas are archetypal representations of key customer segments. They give a name and a face to otherwise abstract customer data, inspiring empathy and informing design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePersonas can take many forms, from documents to posters, but they’re most effective when visible. \u003ca href=\"https://blog.mailchimp.com/new-mailchimp-user-persona-research/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eThe MailChimp UX team created a series of persona posters\u003c/a\u003e to guide their product. While pulling a shot from the espresso machine or lunching in the common space, the persona posters reminded everyone in the company of the people using their product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/mailchimp-personas_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3. MailChimp’s user persona posters reminded all teams of the people using their product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuick tips for creating user personas\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLine up interviews with customers in each key segment.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAnalyze the findings from your interviews to determine common traits and goals within each customer segment.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate a profile representative of the largest common groupings.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRefresh often, as personas are merely a snapshot in time and not built to last.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eJob stories\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJob stories come from the Jobs to Be Done framework developed by Clay Christensen, Harvard Business School professor and author of the influential book \u003ca href=\"http://www.amazon.com/Innovators-Dilemma-Revolutionary-Change-Business/dp/0062060244/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Innovator’s Dilemma\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. Core to Christensen’s Jobs to Be Done theory is that \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f84LymEs67Y\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ewe don’t buy products, we hire them to do a job\u003c/a\u003e. By discerning the job a product is hired to do, we can better understand the motivations of customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJob stories are based on customer interviews that employ \u003ca href=\"http://jobstobedone.org/radio/the-mattress-interview-part-one/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea very specific technique\u003c/a\u003e that takes the customer back to the moment of purchase to expose the \u003cem\u003esituations\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003emotivations\u003c/em\u003e that lead to their decision.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/alanklement\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eJob stories can only come from real customer interviews. Before designing a feature or new product, you must talk to real people and uncover all the anxieties and contexts which were in play when they used your or a competitor’s product.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/klement-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Alan Klement\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAlan Klement\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eProduct Designer\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Job stories can only come from real customer interviews.” @alanklement    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJob stories and user personas are very different. Personas represent specific segments of customers that have a shared set of characteristics, skills, and perspectives. Job stories are only concerned with a customer’s motivations within a specific context.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA job story follows a simple structure:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA job story framework\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen ___________ I want to ___________ so I can ___________.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBreaking down the job story\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach section of the job story reveals a specific piece of information:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSituation: When ___________\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMotivation: I want to ___________\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExpected outcome: so I can ___________.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor instance:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen\u003c/strong\u003e I commute to and from work for hours each day in my car \u003cstrong\u003eI want to\u003c/strong\u003e do something productive and stimulating \u003cstrong\u003eso I can\u003c/strong\u003e feel like I’m not wasting time and actually make my commute productive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA job story like this provides rich insight into the problem to be solved: this commuting time is ripe for the right product or service to make wasted time instead feel like a newfound opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuick tips to create your job story\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInterview customers following \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@marksweep/jobs-to-be-done-interview-script-d290c42b2b48#.md0yis1dd\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ethe Jobs To Be Done interview process\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIdentify the situation, motivations, and  desired outcomes related to the customer’s purchase\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate a job story for each customer interview\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCompare job stories for each interview to find patterns\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:502]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFitting into the lives of others\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe storytelling mechanism you choose is less important than the story you tell. The act of \u003cstrong\u003ecreating a product story before you begin the design process\u003c/strong\u003e not only helps you mobilize your teams, it also forces you to clarify your intentions for your product. You’ll step out of the maker’s mindset and consider how your product will fit into the lives of others.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePeering through the microscope at the details and execution of a project is important, but only after we’ve gotten the perspective from the Earth to our North Star, getting a glimpse at the future we can create. Story First is a simple principle to help you and your whole company work together on big ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;284128829\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eHumans have used stories to foster collective understanding since the beginning. The most powerful designs start with a story—the why—and where your designs fit into people’s lives. Using product stories, journey maps, storyboards, and user personas, teams can build empathy and understanding before designing.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":14,"fields":{"book":["74"],"chapter_num":"02","sub_title":"Find your North Star","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eHumans have used stories to foster collective understanding since the beginning. The most powerful designs start with a story—the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ewhy\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e—and where your designs fit into people’s lives. Using product stories, journey maps, storyboards, and user personas, teams can build empathy and understanding before designing.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292551820","related":{"5":{"title":"The 8 Steps to Creating A Great Window"}}}},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"dbco-admin","author_link":"dbco-admin","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_storyfirst.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Story first - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"It’s easy to get caught up in the process of product design. Take a step back and understand why you’re building what you’re building.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"principles-of-product-design/story-first"},{"id":166,"pid":0,"title":"Pencils before pixels","type":"chapter","date":"166","content":"\u003cp\u003eThe work of the modern designer lives in the abstract world of the computer, where every move we make is precise and effortless. Precision has its place, but not in the early stages of the creative process, when our ideas are still nebulous. There’s danger when creative exploration starts with perfection.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerfection can create the \u003cem\u003eillusion of certainty\u003c/em\u003e, something architect \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=34tJ7JAjSW0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFrank Gehry\u003c/a\u003e avoids as he begins a project. It’s discovery he craves. Craig Webb, Design Partner at \u003ca href=\"http://www.foga.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGehry Partners\u003c/a\u003e, has heard Gehry say many times, “If I knew where I was going, I wouldn’t go there.” To Gehry, peak creativity lies in the unknown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHis process begins with rough concepts. He and his team sketch, make models, then reflect. If the outcome isn’t right, they throw it out to begin again. Crude outputs early on make the work less precious and completely malleable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://www.foga.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI’ve worked out my language through the sketches and through the models.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/gehry-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Frank Gehry\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFrank Gehry\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGehry Partners\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “I’ve worked out my language through the sketches and through the models.” @FGehry    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe hundreds of models and sketches that cover the walls and surfaces of Frank Gehry’s studio are the artifacts of a creative process that starts wide, where there’s space for discovery of the best ideas before committing to a single direction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/gehry-studio_V2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. Frank Gehry’s studio is an explosion of sketches and models, artifacts of a creative process that values discovery.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough Gehry’s work is unique, his process is not. Many creative thinkers start wide and narrow down. Unfortunately, many software design teams take a different approach—they start narrow and refine too soon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSteve Jobs once famously likened the computer to \u003ca href=\"https://www.brainpickings.org/2011/12/21/steve-jobs-bicycle-for-the-mind-1990/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea bicycle for the human mind\u003c/a\u003e. Computers help us make short work of complicated tasks and connect us to vast amounts of data—superpowers indeed, but when misapplied they can hinder the creative process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eComputers let us jump straight to pixels—a space of precision where everything aligns to a grid, vividly colored and fully formed. Precise outputs are precious and hard to abandon. This narrows creative exploration to just a few ideas well rendered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find the best design solutions, we should follow Frank Gehry’s lead: crudely render \u003cem\u003emany\u003c/em\u003e ideas to find the solution worthy of a more precise investigation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe can make more space in our creative process for critical thinking and better design by putting pencils before pixels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:524]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe power of a pencil\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pencil is a humble tool that’s sparked millions of great ideas. It’s the inverse of a computer; it’s simple and limited in functionality, but its limitations make it effective.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://18f.gsa.gov/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI start everything important with pencil and paper.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/unger-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Russ Unger\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eRuss Unger\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003e18F\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “I start everything important with pencil and paper.” @russu    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePencils are important to the creative process because:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePencils are inclusive\u003c/em\u003e. They’re not just for designers—anyone can use a pencil to express their ideas clearly. The pencil is the great equalizer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePencils are low-fi\u003c/em\u003e. Quick sketches give no impression of a complete thought, signaling to all that it’s okay to offer feedback.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePencils aren’t fiddly\u003c/em\u003e. Instead of getting lost in software settings or style, you’ll focus on your \u003cem\u003eideas\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePencils are fast\u003c/em\u003e. You can explore vastly different solutions to the same problem in minutes, and you won’t feel bad throwing your sketches out because you invested so little time.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere’s a magic that happens when we put our ideas on paper. \u003ca href=\"http://www.xplane.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDave Gray, Founder of XPLANE\u003c/a\u003e and co-author of \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Gamestorming-Playbook-Innovators-Rulebreakers-Changemakers/dp/0596804172\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGamestorming\u003c/a\u003e, describes sketching as “a conversation with yourself.” Gabriela Goldschmidt, professor emeritus at Technion Israel Institute of Technology, made similar observations \u003ca href=\"http://www.academia.edu/11887815/The_dialectics_of_sketching\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ein a study of the sketching practices of architects published in the Creativity Research Journal\u003c/a\u003e. She discovered that although sketches start from ideas already within the mind, they can mutate into the unexpected—forming \u003cem\u003enew\u003c/em\u003e ideas. Sketching is a thinking activity!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eGamestorming together\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe bestselling book \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Gamestorming-Playbook-Innovators-Rulebreakers-Changemakers/dp/0596804172/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGamestorming: A Playbook for Innovators, Rulebreakers, and Changemakers\u003c/a\u003e by Dave Gray, Sunni Brown, and James Macanufo includes more than 80 games—many of which involve sketching—to help you get your whole team working together to generate new ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany product designers already know this intuitively. Stanley Wood, Design Director at \u003ca href=\"https://www.spotify.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSpotify\u003c/a\u003e, told us, “Many of our designers sketch, but just so they can think through various ideas. Most of the time they don’t show them to anyone.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd sketching, of course, is also a powerful communication device. The design team at Slack shares sketches with colleagues to invite conversation about concepts without getting distracted by style.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://slack.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWe all start on paper at Slack and then explore from there. It’s rare that people are so good with a tool that they can think within it. Having squiggly lines on paper keeps you focused on real problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can move through ideas much faster, and there’s also something about the fact that a sketch is so clearly not the final product. People don’t get confused by the style and instead focus on the concept.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/brito-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Diogenes Brito\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDiogenes Brito\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eSlack\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “We all start on paper at @slackhq \u0026#8230; It’s rare that people are so good with a tool that they can think within it.” @uxdiogenes    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud:284179843]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe MailChimp design team discovered that sketching is an important bridge to engineering colleagues. \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tdominey\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTodd Dominey\u003c/a\u003e, MailChimp’s Director of Design, noticed that “Pixels freak people out!” When engineers see a high fidelity design comp, they get the impression that the important decisions have been made without them, and now they’re expected to simply execute the design. But when a sketch is presented, it’s clear that the creative process is still wide open for their participation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/grammy_sketch_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Lullabot design team starts all of their projects with rough sketches on paper—even this project, a mobile app for The Grammy Awards.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eNo art degree required\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDepending on your background, the term “sketch” might conjure images of an artist in a Parisian cafe, leisurely capturing a scene with loose lines and precise shading. But you don’t need a beret or an art degree to sketch a quick UI or communicate an idea for a product (a cappuccino won’t hurt, though). If you can scribble some text and draw boxes, you’ve got all the skills you need to sketch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/ui-sketch_v2.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2. A quick, ugly sketch still has the power to communicate an idea or help you discover new ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSketching is something anyone can do—it’s not the sacred territory of designers. Inviting others to participate in the design process will help you produce a more diverse set of design solutions. Engineers, product managers, executives, lawyers—anyone with a stake in your product—can help you turn abstract ideas into concrete solutions by sketching.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/fred_beecher\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eSketching lets everyone participate. Business stakeholders can contribute to sketches, as can developers. This gives people beyond the design team buy-in on the final product.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/beecher-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Fred Beecher\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFred Beecher\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eThe Nerdery\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Sketching lets everyone participate\u0026#8230;This gives people beyond the design team buy-in on the final product.” @fred_beecher    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow to trick someone into sketching their idea\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHave you ever had someone try to describe an idea so abstract that you just can’t see it? You ask them to sketch it and they respond, “Oh, I can’t draw” No matter how you reassure them, they won’t risk looking a fool by making a simple sketch. \u003ca href=\"http://www.twitter.com/dkardys\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDennis Kardys\u003c/a\u003e, Design Director at \u003ca href=\"http://www.wsol.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eWSOL\u003c/a\u003e, has heard this from many a client and has a simple trick to get people over their fear of drawing. Dennis begins to draw his client’s idea for them but intentionally gets it wrong. “Is this what you mean?” he asks. The client tries to explain it once more, and again Dennis draws it the wrong way. Finally, frustration drives the client to snatch the pencil from his hand and draw it themselves. “Oh! I see!” Dennis responds. With the ice broken, Dennis finds that clients will let go of their reservations and continue to sketch additional ideas. For most people, sketching doesn’t come naturally. You’ll need an activity to spark creative thinking and get colleagues comfortable with exploring ideas on paper.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-small-v1_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-small-v1_2x-760x760.png\" alt=\"Power your design workflow\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003ePower your design workflow\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiscover InVision—the product design platform powering the world’s best teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1997 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGET STARTED NOW\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1997 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1997:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSketching ideas together\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA simple activity with tight constraints can be the catalyst you need to get your team comfortable. \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/zakiwarfel\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTodd Zaki Warfel\u003c/a\u003e, Senior Director of Design at Workday, created \u003ca href=\"http://gamestorming.com/games-for-fresh-thinking-and-ideas/6-8-5s/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea team sketching activity called 6-8-5\u003c/a\u003e: you and your colleagues will generate 6 to 8 design solutions per person in just 5 minutes. No one will have enough time to get lost in fancy renderings, and that’s important. After all, the idea is to focus on ideas and ditch misgivings that “I can’t draw!” In this exercise, \u003cem\u003eeveryone’s\u003c/em\u003e sketches will be messy!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHere’s how it works\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"list-style-type: none;\"\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGet your team together—designers, engineers, product managers, and experts with important domain knowledge. Limit the group to 8 or less to keep the discussion productive.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGive each person a sheet of A5 or 8.5” x 11” paper. The paper will be folded 3 times to create 6 boxes (for 6 sketches). If you want to generate more ideas, fold the paper into quarters and give everyone 2 sheets.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/6-8-5-grids.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n    \t\t\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003col start=\"3\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFrame the problem for everyone, and clearly state the desired outcomes of this project. “We want to help customers become active in this app more quickly. How might we achieve that?”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet a timer for 5 minutes, and instruct everyone to sketch solutions individually (and silently, to help everyone focus).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen the timer goes off, it’s time for each team member to present his or her ideas. Conversation about each idea is important here. Critical feedback will help you see what ideas are best. Every team member should be given the opportunity to share sketches.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf time permits, you can do additional rounds to go deeper into each idea. Working together to solve problems gives everyone shared ownership in the product vision and generates great results because so many diverse perspectives are present.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/aaroni\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eSketching is a big part of our process. We get everyone together to sketch so we have shared ownership and vision.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/irizarry-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Aaron Irizarry\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAaron Irizarry\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eNasdaq\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Sketching is a big part of our process. We get everyone together to sketch so we have shared ownership and vision.” @aaroni @nasdaq    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou might be wondering why everyone’s sketching separately in this exercise instead of together on a whiteboard. \u003ca href=\"http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/01/30/groupthink\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAccording to repeated studies on group brainstorming work\u003c/a\u003e, we produce fewer ideas and of lesser quality when we work in groups. \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/brainstorming-an-idea-past-its-prime/2012/04/19/gIQAhKT5TT_story.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eKeith Sawyer, a psychologist at Washington University, has summarized the science\u003c/a\u003e: “Decades of research have consistently shown that brainstorming groups think of far fewer ideas than the same number of people who work alone and later pool their ideas.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemember, early in the creative process we’re best served by covering as much territory as we can instead of going deep on 1 or 2 ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe right tools at the right time\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe tools you use to sketch can influence how fast and far your creative explorations proceed. With fine line pens and mechanical pencils, you’ll be prone to create detailed sketches, which are slower. To avoid slipping into detail early on, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jasonfried\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eJason Fried\u003c/a\u003e, co-founder of \u003ca href=\"https://basecamp.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBasecamp\u003c/a\u003e, uses \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Sharpie-1883338-Permanent-Marker-Chisel/dp/B0013CQ20Q/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003efat markers for sketching\u003c/a\u003e on \u003ca href=\"https://www.edwardtufte.com/tufte/posters#graphpaper\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003elarge format graph paper\u003c/a\u003e. With fat markers, it’s pretty hard to draw a detailed UI. Instead, you have to focus on the workflow and how people will use your product.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"position: relative; padding-top: 75%;\"\u003e\u003ciframe style=\"border: 0; position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%;\" src=\"//davegray.looplogic.com/jason-fried-on-design/embedded?layout=0\u0026amp;loop=false\u0026amp;autoplay=false\u0026amp;social=false\u0026amp;leadgen=false\" width=\"300\" height=\"150\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://xplaner.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDave Gray\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, founder of XPLANE, speaks with Jason Fried of Basecamp about how he explores ideas through sketching.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs ideas are refined, \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Sharpie-Permanent-Markers-Point-Black/dp/B00006IFHD/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea medium Sharpie\u003c/a\u003e or—my favorite—a \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Staedtler-Triplus-Fineliner-Black-0-3mm/dp/B009CQKL3Y/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eStaedtler Triplus Fineliner\u003c/a\u003e can help you explore your ideas with more precision. Loose paper works best for sketches, as they can be shared, posted on the walls, or mercifully recycled rather than lingering for posterity in your sketchbook. Designers who sketch UI concepts in detail find \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Copic-Markers-12-Piece-Toner-Gray/dp/B000MRSUN0/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eCopic gray markers\u003c/a\u003e add depth and clarity to sketches.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSketching with remote teams\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTeam sketching is an important part of the creative process at \u003ca href=\"https://www.lullabot.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLullabot\u003c/a\u003e, a creative agency that serves clients like SpaceX, The Grammys, GE, and Martha Stewart. Each new project they take on starts with a sketching session, but not of the sort described above—this design team is entirely remote.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCreative Director \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jponch\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eJared Ponchot\u003c/a\u003e has devised a simple and inexpensive way to sketch as a team despite the distance that separates them. He bought each designer \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/IPEVO-Point-View-USB-Camera/dp/B002UBPBTC/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea simple USB document camera, the IPEVO\u003c/a\u003e. At just $60 each, Jared even buys the cameras for engineers, clients, and other key collaborators in the company so they can participate in early sketching sessions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/ipevo_v2_700px.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3. The IPEVO  camera is perfect for sharing sketches with a remote design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike many remote teams, Lullabot runs their meetings via Google Hangouts. In their meetings, they share sketches by simply switching the camera source to the IPEVO. Each team member can walk others through their ideas, or sketch live to explain a new concept.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/sketch-hangout_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 4. Lullabot creative director Jared Ponchot sketches with his remote design team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/ipevo-sketchbook_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 5. The IPEVO cam can be used in a Google Hangout to show sketches with a remote team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePonchot’s solution is simple and effective. It keeps his team focused on a breadth of design solutions early in a project instead of jumping straight to pixels, where they would get lost in execution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/craft#freehand?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFreehand–a fast, flexible new way to collaborate in real time\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eIdeas before execution\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSketching before we jump to the computer has many benefits, the greatest of which is that sketching keeps us laser-focused on \u003cem\u003eideas\u003c/em\u003e instead of the charms of design \u003cem\u003eexecution\u003c/em\u003e. Design is often described as the act of solving problems for others. We cannot live up to that mandate if polish eclipses exploration in our creative process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jbrewer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThroughout my career, whenever I start at a lower fidelity it opens the door for more participation from others and makes me focus on identifying the core concerns. I always advocate exhausting exploration/discovery at the lowest possible fidelity and only when you can’t reasonably make progress, going to the next level.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/brewer-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Josh Brewer\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJosh Brewer\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAbstract\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “I always advocate exhausting exploration/discovery at the lowest possible fidelity…” @jbrewer    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePutting pencils before pixels can help you bring others into the design process and win you allies. Gaining the broad perspectives of your colleagues early on will also help your team produce better design solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHere’s your to-do list to put \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003epencils before pixels\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e into practice\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGenerate dozens of ideas on paper before designing on the computer; sketching is a thought process that will help you discover the unexpected.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGet engineers, product managers, and other key stakeholders to sketch with your team in the early phases of a project. This will clarify the project for all, and create a sense of shared ownership.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf your team or clients are remote, use USB cams to share sketches and ideate as a team.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConstraints like fat markers or time limits on sketching can help you avoid getting lost in detail too soon.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:531]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-Medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr collaboration\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTRY FREEHAND\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1966 {\n\t\t\tcolor: Sketching brings together designers and key stakeholders so they can collaboratively find the best solutions without getting lost in design details.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":15,"fields":{"book":["74"],"chapter_num":"03","sub_title":"Think divergently","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eEvery design begins somewhere, in imperfection.
