Window"}}}},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"dbco-admin","author_link":"dbco-admin","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_pencilsbeforepixels.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Pencils before pixels - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Exploring ideas on paper first will help your team find the best design solutions faster.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"principles-of-product-design/pencils-before-pixels"},{"id":410,"pid":0,"title":"Show and tell","type":"chapter","date":"410","content":"\u003cp\u003eFeedback is the lifeblood of a healthy design team. It informs the design process, leads to better products, and helps designers grow. Despite its essential role in design, it’s too often absent in our work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn most design programs, feedback is folded into virtually every aspect of learning. I was reminded of this fact a couple years ago when I was invited to the \u003ca href=\"http://dschool.stanford.edu/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eStanford d.school\u003c/a\u003e to speak to \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/enriqueallen\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eEnrique Allen’s\u003c/a\u003e class about design. Before meeting with students, Enrique provided a quick tour, pointing out works in progress. His colleague \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/scottdoorley\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eScott Doorley\u003c/a\u003e joined us to explain the thinking behind each workspace in the school.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/d-school_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. The Stanford d.school was very carefully designed to facilitate the chaos of creative thinking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn some ways the school was like many others I’d visited—the energy of overly caffeinated students laboring over projects was palpable. But there was something peculiar about it: every space was messy. Not unkempt, but messy with ideas in progress. There was a sense of urgency to the way work was posted on walls and scribbled upon. Work tables were strewn with exacto knives, rulers, tape and scraps of paper—instruments of creation. All the furniture—desks, couches, work tables, and whiteboards—was fitted with casters and either pushed into clusters for conversation or lined up against the walls to open up room to build. \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Make-Space-Stage-Creative-Collaboration/dp/1118143728/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eThe space was very carefully designed\u003c/a\u003e to facilitate the chaos of creative thinking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe energy was incredible, and I didn’t want to leave. It was an ecosystem of ideas, where projects sprouted and grew or died to make room for the next experiment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe d.school’s design studio is \u003ci\u003eso\u003c/i\u003e different from those in nearly every tech company, where the space is pristinely decorated and filled with desks for solitary work. The walls of most startups I’ve visited are reserved for clever posters or artsy murals, not the design concepts that will lead to the next product release. Those designs remain trapped in a legion of MacBooks, starved for critical discourse that could help them grow into something far greater.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_M._Kelley\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eConsciously or not, we feel and internalize what the space tells us about how to work. When you walk into most offices, the space tells you that it’s meant for a group of people to work alone.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/kelley-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"David Kelley\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDavid Kelley\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eStanford d.school, IDEO\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Consciously or not, we feel and internalize what the space tells us about how to work.” @kelleybros @IDEO    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHealthy feedback\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSomething’s lost when we transition into the professional design world. Work no longer happens out in the open. Creative chaos is traded in for tidy presentations of fully formed ideas. Things stop being messy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe d.school’s messy studio is an indicator of a healthy feedback process. Students are making things, showing what they’ve made, and getting feedback that helps them see their work differently. Then the process repeats, often quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealthy design teams have feedback built into their processes, so ideas can evolve and designers can grow. Work is shared with colleagues consistently and intentionally in design reviews, daily standups, and casual conversations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding feedback into our design practice helps in so many ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt helps us avoid spending too much time on a design that may have significant flaws.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt gives us multiple perspectives on a single problem, helping the designer get closer to an effective solution faster.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePresenting work for feedback keeps the team synced on project progress, and holds everyone accountable to milestones and deadlines.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs designers get in the habit of presenting their work and giving feedback to others, they learn to think more clearly about their design decisions and become comfortable articulating their ideas.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRegular feedback processes will give junior designers the opportunity to learn from senior designers, helping your entire team level up.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are many ways to create a culture of feedback in your team, but be patient—change won’t happen overnight.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/ecourses/making-a-product-designer?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eE-course: Making a product designer\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCreating a culture of feedback\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiving and receiving feedback is a skill that needs to be cultivated. Dropping a few design reviews on the team calendar creates the opportunity for your team to exchange feedback, but it doesn’t ensure that anyone will actually know how to participate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt can be a little scary to give feedback—we don’t want to create conflict by coming across as negative. And receiving feedback is even \u003ci\u003emore\u003c/i\u003e intimidating. No one wants their work to be criticized! With practice, your team will learn that these fears are misplaced. Design feedback, when properly delivered, is constructive, supportive, and helps designers grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://www.mikeindustries.com/blog/archive/2016/05/three-years-in-san-francisco\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePsychological safety, in an organizational sense, is the feeling that it’s ok to take risks and be vulnerable in front of each other.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/davidson-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Mike Davidson\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMike Davidson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformerly Twitter\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Psychological safety, in an organizational sense, is the feeling that it’s ok to take risks and be vulnerable in front of each other.” @mikeindustries    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs they talk about design, your team will develop the language they need to deliver constructive feedback, and their perspectives on the qualities of good design will mature. You’ll hear fewer vague observations and more constructive feedback that can improve the design. For instance, rather than hearing, “I like the type you’ve chosen,” you’ll begin to notice statements like, “The type selection feels trendy, which contradicts the project’s goal of inspiring trust in the content.” The former isn’t helpful, while the latter is instructive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTweaking the language used in critiques can help ensure designers don’t take criticism personally. Say “\u003cstrong\u003ethe design\u003c/strong\u003e doesn’t meet the goals of the project,” not “\u003cstrong\u003eyou\u003c/strong\u003e didn’t meet the goals of the project.” Always talk about the work, not the person who made it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/buzz-feed_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2. The design team at Buzzfeed discussing new design concepts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGood feedback develops with rapport. For that reason, you may want to temper overly critical feedback early on so people feel safe presenting their work. Designers need to hear where they\u0026#8217;re headed in the wrong direction, but deliver the message with encouragement. Work your way into more direct criticism once rapport and trust are established.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: #e41d32;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Thinking-Book-medium_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-thinking\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Thinking-Book-medium_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Learn design thinking\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-thinking\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLearn design thinking\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImmerse yourself in the \u003cem\u003eDesign Thinking Handbook\u003c/em\u003e—a primer to help you spark a design transformation\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-thinking\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1619 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eREAD THE BOOK\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1619 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #e41d32;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #e41d32;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1619:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #e41d32;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #e41d32;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSetting the stage\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeedback happens more naturally when you create the right environment. Does your design practice make affordances for creative chaos like the Stanford d.school does, or is it built for solitary work?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy simply changing your space, you can set the stage for feedback and collaboration in your team. For distributed and remote teams, this is doubly important. Establishing dedicated times and places for sharing works in progress keeps everyone connected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIn person\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe walls of your design studio are a sacred space. This is where your team’s ideas can be shared, debated, retooled, and celebrated. Make it clear to your team that the studio walls are not a gallery—this is work space!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you don’t already have one, invest in a large format printer and get the whole team connected. Print design work daily and post to your studio walls for scheduled design reviews and casual conversations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf your walls aren’t ideal for posting work, you can buy \u003ca href=\"http://www.uline.com/Product/Detail/S-19382/Foam-Board/Foamboard-48-x-96-Black-White\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e8-foot by 4-foot sheets of foam core\u003c/a\u003e and lean them against your walls. Get some \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00DKI9816/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003enice Washi tape\u003c/a\u003e to post your designs in style (and easily peel off later). Leave markers and sticky notes nearby so your team and anyone in the company can easily jot down feedback and post it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@george_aye/always-show-your-work-why-designers-write-on-the-walls-and-why-you-should-too-6725237b9765#.4ysk8o8ju\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOur work is plastered and posted all over the walls of the studio — not finished things, but notes, photos, and artifacts of what we’re working on. Over time, we see projects unfolding as they’re posted, and we can give each other feedback along the way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy sticking your work up on a wall, you invite an ongoing dialogue about making your project better. It makes your work tangible, shareable and visual, which gives it a much better chance of receiving feedback and critique.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/eye-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"George Aye\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGeorge Aye\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eGreater Good Studio\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “By sticking your work up on a wall, you invite an ongoing dialogue about making your project better.” @georgeaye    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe design team at \u003ca href=\"http://greatergoodstudio.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGreater Good Studio\u003c/a\u003e has gone so far as to create \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/greater-good-studio/always-show-your-work-why-designers-write-on-the-walls-and-why-you-should-too-6725237b9765#.rtt49k451\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eproject bays, a modular space to post work for critical discussion\u003c/a\u003e. Each new project they begin gets its own bay—a physical manifestation of their progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/greater-good_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3. At Greater Good Studio, every project gets a space for posting design concepts and conducting design reviews.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe fidelity of the work you post can influence the feedback you get. Pixel perfect comps may lead others to believe the work is finished, which will inhibit feedback. Work that’s lower fidelity or with notes scribbled on it will make it clear to all that you’re still working through ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRemote\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemotes teams can also set the stage for feedback using tools like \u003ca href=\"https://slack.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSlack\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://trello.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTrello\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://google.com/hangouts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGoogle Hangouts\u003c/a\u003e, and of course, \u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision\u003c/a\u003e. The entire design team at InVision is distributed and uses their own product to conduct design reviews. \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/1l32uaywf2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLiveShare\u003c/a\u003e, a design collaboration feature in InVision, lets the team present and get real-time feedback. Early ideas are explored with \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/3b3ncgc213\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eFreehand\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/ywsy00uhef\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBoards\u003c/a\u003e, later becoming \u003ca href=\"https://invisionapp.wistia.com/medias/rawbkwpnr2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePrototypes\u003c/a\u003e that are again shared with the team for feedback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith so many affordable tools at hand, remote teams can easily build feedback into their design process too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBringing everyone into the process\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce your space is set up and designs are being posted, pay attention to how people behave. In person, are more people stopping by, curious about your work? Are spontaneous conversations happening in front of design work? Do you see designers staring at the wall, head tilted, pondering what’s been posted? Online, are people commenting on work shared on Slack or InVision? Is your Trello board exploding with links to new ideas?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese are all positive signs that your culture is shifting for the better. You’re bringing everyone into the design process!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:538]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFormalizing the feedback process\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigning out in the open is just the first step. Your team will also need to get feedback on their designs, sync with teammates to make sure progress is being made, and learn from mistakes. This is a tall order and calls for different types of feedback processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet’s take a look at a few ways to get your team the right feedback at the right time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesign reviews\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e Early, midway, and at the end of a project\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there:\u003c/strong\u003e The designer plus no more than 7 people\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Designers get the feedback they need to refine their work\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign reviews are critiques that let designers get detailed feedback that’s framed by the project goals. Design reviews can happen at a number of different points in a project. It’s often helpful to do it early on so the designer can get fresh perspectives before investing too much time in an idea that may be misguided. The midway point and towards the end of a project are also natural times to get additional input.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/capone-design-review_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 4. The Capital One design team conducting a design review.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNever use a design review as a big reveal of project. If you wait until you have everything polished, you’ll be too invested to accept the feedback you’re given.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign reviews are a great opportunity to bring in experts from other teams. Colleagues from customer support, engineering, QA, legal, marketing, or even an executive may have a new perspective to help you see the problem differently. But try not to overload the guest list in these reviews—too many people and you’ll have a hard time guiding the conversation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign reviews are not a free-for-all. They should be run with these rules in mind:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUse a facilitator\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe designer is not the best person to facilitate a conversation about her work. She’ll have biases that could influence the feedback, and she needs to be free to listen to the conversation unencumbered. The facilitator will write down all of the feedback and share it with the design team after the review.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA facilitator will set the ground rules for the conversation:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eState the time limit for the design review\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIntroduce the designer and remind everyone that feedback should not turn into committee design. “Susan is the designer of the work we’re reviewing today. We’ll be helping her get fresh perspectives on her work, but let’s offer feedback—not design suggestions. She will use our feedback to inform her decisions.”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLet people know how they should give feedback. “Feedback should be specific and candid. Let’s point out what’s working well and what needs refinement. Remember, we’re critiquing the work, not the designer.”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t rush into the review. The facilitator should give everyone time to review the work and for their observations to take shape in silence before the conversation begins.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFrame the problem\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe facilitator should give the designer an opportunity to frame the problem at the beginning of the review, including any user and business goals. For example, \u0026#8220;Users want to save money more effectively, and we want to keep customers engaged by teaching them to manage their money better.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIdentify the constraints of the project: ”Due to legal constraints, we have to disclose this information \u003ci\u003ebefore\u003c/i\u003e the user can enroll in this new program.” If reviewers aren’t aware of the constraints and goals of the project, their feedback is unlikely to be helpful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSay what you need\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe designer should state what she needs from the design review: ”I’m trying to determine if this photo upload workflow is intuitive.” This will help keep the feedback focused, and prevent the group from wandering into unproductive conversations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/berkun\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIf there are 3 or 4 specific questions you want answered, define them. Without goals everyone will work from different assumptions, and it will be more of a brainstorm meeting than a critique.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/berkun-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Scott Berkun\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eScott Berkun\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eauthor of The Myths of Innovation\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Without goals everyone will work from different assumptions, and it will be more of a brainstorm meeting than a critique.” @berkun    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDon’t pitch, just listen\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe designer should \u003ci\u003enot\u003c/i\u003e pitch her idea or over-explain her designs. If she does, she robs everyone of the fresh eyes they bring to the design review. Once the designer has framed the problem and stated her needs, she should simply listen to the feedback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud:284191950]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDesign standups\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e Daily, if possible\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there: \u003c/strong\u003eEveryone on the design team\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Your team gets the chance to sync up on projects\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign standups are short, daily check-ins that help your team stay abreast of the work being done. As the name suggests, everyone remains standing in these meetings so no one can get comfortable enough to launch into a soliloquy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a standup, each team member answers 3 questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat did you do yesterday?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat will you do today?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAre there any impediments in your way?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile most teams choose to conduct standups in the morning, you may want to consider doing them after lunch—the morning is when our minds are clearest and ready to focus on creative work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDon’t let standups turn into impromptu design critiques. If someone needs immediate design feedback, ask that they hold the request until after the meeting. A standup should be short and focused on project progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:550]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRetrospectives\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e After a project is launched or a sprint is completed\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there:\u003c/strong\u003e Everyone who worked on the project\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Your team will internalize lessons from each project\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery project is a learning opportunity, but if you don’t pause to take stock, valuable lessons will slip by. When you’ve launched a project or completed a sprint, reflect on what went well, what was confusing, and what \u003ci\u003edidn’t\u003c/i\u003e go so well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/thinmatt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMatth Spiel\u003c/a\u003e, Director of Design at \u003ca href=\"http://teamtreehouse.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTreehouse\u003c/a\u003e, conducts retrospective meetings regularly. He sends a pre-retrospective survey to the team before the meeting to capture each person’s perspective individually. This helps to eliminate the \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandwagon_effect\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ebandwagon effect\u003c/a\u003e, which happens when the views of the group conform to those of a few vocal people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/thinmatt\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eRetrospectives are a valuable tool to use because they help teams identify strengths and weaknesses. They help provide the designers at Treehouse an opportunity to give feedback on our processes in order to grow and improve.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/speil-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Matt Spiel\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMatt Spiel\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eTreehouse\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Retrospectives are a valuable tool to use because they help teams identify strengths and weaknesses.” @thinmatt @treehouse    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMatt asks his team to rate their performance both as a group and as individuals on a scale from 1 to 5, where 5 is the highest. Ratings tend to cluster in a similar spot, but occasionally there are outliers. Team members who’ve given starkly different ratings are asked to share their views in the meeting to promote transparency and honesty.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiscussion in Treehouse’s retrospective meetings is centered around 3 questions common to most Agile retrospectives:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat worked well for us?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat didn’t work well for us?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat can we do to improve our process?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese questions are sometimes referred to as Start, Stop, Keep—what should we start doing, stop doing, and keep doing?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHonest conversation about each of these questions becomes easier with the cultivation of trust and plenty of practice running retrospective meetings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePostmortems\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen they should happen:\u003c/strong\u003e After a project has gone poorly\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should be there:\u003c/strong\u003e Everyone who worked on the project and an impartial facilitator\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow it helps:\u003c/strong\u003e Your team will learn from their mistakes and find a way forward\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot all projects go well. Some go horribly wrong, requiring all teams involved in the project to come together to consider and learn from the mistakes they made.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough projects rarely go awry at Etsy, they’ve established a strong process to guide them through those that do. Their process follows many of the recommendations set forth in the Agile methodology.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s how a typical postmortem is run:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBefore the meeting: \u003c/strong\u003eSend an email asking the team to identify key points in the project timeline. This will be used to construct a master timeline of events, which will be discussed in the meeting. By focusing on events, you’ll avoid negative finger pointing, which can derail the process.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eModerator: \u003c/strong\u003eChoose a moderator. This person, who wasn’t on the project and can be impartial, should be guiding the conversation from the whiteboard, taking notes for all to see.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGround rules:\u003c/strong\u003e The moderator should first point out that this is not a blame session. It’s a conversation about the shortcomings of the team’s process, not the people involved. It’s an opportunity to learn!\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFacts:\u003c/strong\u003e People recall events differently. The moderator can help the team agree upon what \u003ci\u003eactually\u003c/i\u003e happened so lessons can be extracted. Establishing a timeline of events can help pinpoint where things went wrong.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLessons and actions:\u003c/strong\u003e As key lessons are identified, they should be written on the whiteboard for all to see. The actions required to mitigate the problems stemming from the failed project also need to be identified, assigned an owner, and provided a clear deadline.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter the meeting:\u003c/strong\u003e The lessons learned from the postmortem should be emailed to the entire team, along with the action items that are to be completed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePostmortems can seem rough, but they’re far superior to repeating the same mistakes. They’re a powerful opportunity for your team to learn and improve your processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:556]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePutting show and tell into practice\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/dustin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYou know you have a healthy design culture when people are giving each other feedback.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/senos-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Dustin Senos\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDustin Senos\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformer head of design, Medium\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        You know you have a healthy design culture when people are giving each other feedback.    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI’ve mentored a number of talented designers seeking guidance on their career path. All tell me the same thing: “I just want to work somewhere where I can grow and learn.” As they visit various companies, interviewing for their next design post, they can \u003ci\u003esense\u003c/i\u003e right away if the environment will give them the growth opportunity they crave. How? They recognize the signs of a company with a culture of feedback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey see work on the walls. They see the messy signs of creative progress. Design critique is fluid and not limited to formal meetings. These are the signs of a healthy design team, fueled by feedback and always improving.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBuilding a culture of feedback takes time, but these simple steps will help you enact change:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRethink your design studio:\u003c/strong\u003e Create areas for work to be posted to foster spontaneous design discussion. It’s okay to be messy. Scribble on comps, add notes, post different versions of the same concept.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStay in sync:\u003c/strong\u003e Schedule short, daily standup meetings for your team to sync up on projects. It may be best to schedule them at the end of the day, so you don’t block the mornings when minds are most creative and ready to design.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMake time for feedback:\u003c/strong\u003e Schedule design reviews for every project. They should be frequent enough for designers to get the feedback they need to avoid going too far down the wrong path.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLearn and grow:\u003c/strong\u003e Schedule retrospectives after every project to capture lessons learned. When things go wrong, a postmortem meeting will help you learn from your mistakes without pointing fingers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHiring, coaching, and retaining great designers is made much easier when design and feedback are out in the open. Help your team show their work and tell you all about it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-user-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr DEMO\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSTART YOUR DEMO\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-2009 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-2009:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #2690ec;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eWhen it comes to feedback, there’s little room for polite reserve within a design team. Use design reviews, retrospectives, design standups, and careful space planning to facilitate a culture of feedback within your team—your designs and designers will benefit.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":16,"fields":{"book":["74"],"chapter_num":"04","sub_title":"Create a culture of feedback","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhen it comes to feedback, there’s little room for polite reserve within a design team. Use design reviews, retrospectives, design standups, and careful space planning to facilitate a culture of feedback within your team—your designs and designers will benefit.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292554868","related":[{"title":"Make Space: How to Set the Stage for Creative Walter","author_link":"\u003ca href=\"http://aarronwalter.com\" title=\"Visit Aarron Walter\u0026#8217;s website\" rel=\"author external\"\u003eAarron Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_showandtell.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Show and tell - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Creating a culture of feedback on your team helps designers tap into the chaos of creative thinking and learn from others.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"principles-of-product-design/show-and-tell"},{"id":454,"pid":0,"title":"Fast feedback","type":"chapter","date":"454","content":"\u003cp\u003eHave you ever \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tqGZKiOLsU8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ewatched a great chef at work\u003c/a\u003e—the kind of chef worthy of a coveted \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelin_Guide\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMichelin Star\u003c/a\u003e? Whether she’s in the kitchen, the field, or at the market, she’s always tasting the food. Her palette guides her to the right flavors, aromas, and textures that combine to create an unforgettable meal. The alchemy of great cooking can only happen when the chef gets feedback at each step of her process.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilarly, design teams that produce great products have something in common—\u003cstrong\u003ethey habitually test their designs\u003c/strong\u003e. Before a single line of code is written, they build high-fidelity prototypes and put them in the hands of colleagues and customers, collecting fast feedback and correcting course \u003cem\u003ebefore\u003c/em\u003e development.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese product design teams have a huge competitive advantage over those that get feedback only after their product ships: \u003cem\u003ethey learn faster\u003c/em\u003e. They spot problems quickly and fix them. They talk to customers early and align the product to their needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eLearning faster\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLearning faster means shipping more polished products that attract customers faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe software industry isn’t the first to grasp this principle. The animation industry was transformed by an underdog studio in Los Angeles that found a way to learn faster than the big New York studios by getting fast feedback.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLearn fast, leap forward\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the early 20th century, the boundaries of animation had been drawn and the industry was happily operating within them. The medium was crude—settings were flat, characters lacked personality, and the content was often limited to slapstick gags.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen Walt Disney Studios changed everything.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDisney’s faith in the medium as an artform pushed the studio to experiment with new ideas that lead to astounding technical achievements. In 1928, they introduced sound with the release of \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7NQyzcDnMdE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSteamboat Willie\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, and in 1932 they introduced full color with \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VTuIb7BIFqk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eFlowers and Trees\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. Each is an impressive achievement, but it was the studio’s contributions to \u003cem\u003eprocess\u003c/em\u003e that enabled animation to evolve into the rich medium we know today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 1931, seeking faster feedback on their drawings, Disney animators began making what they called “pencil tests:” rough drawings on inexpensive negative film that they fed into the \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moviola\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMoviola\u003c/a\u003e, a device with a small screen for viewing footage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/moviola_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. Les Clark, one of Walt Disney Studios’ first animators, viewing a quick pencil test through a Moviola.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis process let Disney animators meticulously refine their drawings immediately, not weeks or months later, and enabled them to learn the art of the medium faster than any other studio. Soon the animators began stringing together pencil tests to review entire scenes, the interaction of characters, and the delivery of the story.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Walt-Disney-Triumph-American-Imagination/dp/0679757473/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIn our little studios on Hyperion Street, every foot of rough animation was projected on the screen for analysis, and every foot was drawn and redrawn until we could say, ‘This is the best we can do.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/disney-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Walt Disney\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eWalt Disney\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDisney Studios\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “\u0026#8230;every foot of rough animation was\u0026#8230;drawn and redrawn until we could say, ‘This is the best we can do.’” -Walt Disney    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWalt Disney Studios’ prototyping method pushed the medium into new territory. While other studios produced silly gag films to make people laugh, Disney created art with emotionally complex characters that made audiences \u003cem\u003ecry\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy building \u003cstrong\u003efast feedback\u003c/strong\u003e into their creative process, Walt Disney Studios was able to make a huge leap. What worked for Disney can work for your design team too. Don’t worry, you won’t need to \u003ca href=\"http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40\u0026amp;_trksid=p2050601.m570.l1311.R1.TR11.TRC2.A0.H0.Xnelson+cl.TRS0\u0026amp;_nkw=Moviola\u0026amp;_sacat=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003etrack down a Moviola on eBay\u003c/a\u003e. All you need is a high-fidelity prototype.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:463]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Podcast-190x190-small_2x-760x760.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Podcast-190x190-small_2x-760x760.png\" alt=\"The DesignBetter.Co Podcast\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eThe DesignBetter.Co Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJoin the world’s best designers for product design insights\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/podcast\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1656 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"LISTEN AND LEARN\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eLISTEN AND LEARN\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1656 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1656:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tbackground: #002fc7;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePrototyping and tools\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrototypes let us present product concepts to colleagues and customers without diving into the production process. A good prototype is a balancing act—it feels like a real product, but doesn’t require a lot of time to build.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI used to create prototypes using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. It was a painful, time-consuming process that affected my judgement when testing. I’d spend a week or more producing a prototype that was vaguely realistic enough to show customers. When feedback called for big changes, I found myself reluctant to act, as the work seemed daunting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat process seems ridiculous today, as we’re in a golden age of product design tools. We can now create prototypes that are \u003cem\u003emuch\u003c/em\u003e higher fidelity in less time \u003cem\u003ewithout writing a single line of code\u003c/em\u003e. With less time invested, tweaks to a prototype come easy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are a number of prototyping tools on the market—more than we can cover here. Do some research to find the right fit for your needs. As you consider various prototyping tools, ask yourself these questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIs it easy to focus on product design problems, or will I be fiddling with the tool or code?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCan I deploy my prototype to various devices to create a realistic testing experience?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you’re working remotely, is it easy to share the prototype and conduct remote testing?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:569]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInVision and Sketch\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you might’ve guessed, we’re partial to prototyping with \u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision\u003c/a\u003e. Before joining InVision, my product design team at MailChimp used InVision to prototype new apps and explore feature concepts. It helped us move fast and get the feedback we needed. We shared InVision prototypes with the engineering team early to get feedback and keep everyone in sync.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany product designers have transitioned from Photoshop to \u003ca href=\"https://www.sketchapp.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSketch\u003c/a\u003e, which lets you work on multiple screens in a single file. You can save common UI elements like buttons and forms as shared symbols to build a screen quickly. There are \u003ca href=\"https://www.sketchapp.com/learn/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea number of great learning resources to guide you\u003c/a\u003e if you’ve yet to make the leap to Sketch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com/craft?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eCraft by InVision, a suite of free plugins for Sketch and Photoshop, creates a\u003c/a\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/craft\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e tight integration between Sketch and InVision\u003c/a\u003e, shortening the prototype design process. It lets you pull real data from an API, fetch content from a site, or grab elegant photos and drop them into your design file to make your UI more realistic. Craft even lets you build a prototype directly in Sketch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign tools today are doing for product design what Disney’s pencil tests and the Moviola did for animation—they’re shortening the learning process so the craft can evolve faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eKeynote\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKeynote, Apple’s popular presentation software, has become a go-to prototyping tool for many designers. It’s simple enough that almost anyone can prototype with it, and sophisticated enough to do elegant animations that make a series of images feel like a real app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://www.apple.com/ios/keynote/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInstall Keynote on your iPhone or iPad\u003c/a\u003e to run prototypes on the target device, making the testing experience more realistic. Design prototypes in Keynote faster with \u003ca href=\"http://keynotopia.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eKeynotopia’s\u003c/a\u003e UI templates for both \u003ca href=\"http://keynotopia.com/iphone-Prototyping/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eiOS\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"http://keynotopia.com/android-prototyping-templates/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAndroid\u003c/a\u003e. If you end up doing a lot of prototyping, you’ll probably want to take some time to create your own UI template library so you don’t have to continuously apply your brand’s colors and style to stock elements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUI kits\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse these free UI kits from InVision to make building a high-fidelity prototype fast and easy: \u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/now\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eNOW\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/chat?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eChat\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/do?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDo\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/relate?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eRelate\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/tethr?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eTethr\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFaster prototyping with a pattern library\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour product prototyping process can be accelerated exponentially when you work with a pattern library—a collection of standard elements that can be combined like LEGO blocks to create a new UI. Creating a pattern library is time consuming work, but it pays off with the design of each new product or feature.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/invision-design-system_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2. The InVision design team has built a pattern library that speeds up design and maintains consistency though the team is located around the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFacing UI fragmentation across many products and platforms, the design team at \u003ca href=\"http://www.nasdaq.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eNASDAQ\u003c/a\u003e revised their schedule to spend time creating a pattern library. The process was intense, but helped them unify the user experience across all of their products. There was an additional benefit they hadn’t initially anticipated—\u003cem\u003eprototyping with a pattern library helped them move very quickly\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSpending less time noodling on UI treatments means designers can focus more on aligning the product to customers’ needs. Companies like \u003ca href=\"https://developer.salesforce.com/lightning/design-system\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSalesforce\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://www.ibm.com/design/thinking/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIBM\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://design.atlassian.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAtlassian\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://ux.mailchimp.com/patterns\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMailChimp\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@hellostanley/design-doesnt-scale-4d81e12cbc3e#.m5whsgjvp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSpotify\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"https://gel.westpacgroup.com.au/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eWestpac\u003c/a\u003e have all developed detailed design systems that help them design new products quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:574]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/Freehand-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"Team collaboration—in real time\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTeam collaboration—in real time\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInVision Freehand is your team’s infinite space for fast, flexible collaboration\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/feature/freehand?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1965 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"TRY FREEHAND\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eTRY FREEHAND\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1965 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1965:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eGetting feedback on your prototype\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTesting internally\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith your prototype built, you can start collecting feedback. Before you put your prototype in front of customers, spend time talking with your design and engineering colleagues. They’ll help you look at the UI with fresh eyes, and reconnect with the key objectives of the project. Now’s a great time to conduct a design review.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeploy your prototype to the devices you’ll be targeting so everyone can get a feel for the real experience. It’s not uncommon for designers to walk around the building to grab a few colleagues for an impromptu test of a prototype. Great feedback can come from unexpected places, so look beyond the design and engineering teams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith feedback in hand, revise your prototype accordingly and get ready to test with real customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTesting with customers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’re going to learn a lot as you show your product prototype to your customers. Your ideas and assumptions will be put to the test, which may at times make you uncomfortable. It can be frustrating to watch users struggle with your design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYour instincts might lead you to help customers figure out how to use your app, but you’ll taint the feedback if you do. Instead, stick to your testing script or work with a moderator who can conduct the tests impartially.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/mmargolis\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMichael Margolis\u003c/a\u003e, UX Research Partner at \u003ca href=\"http://gv.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGV\u003c/a\u003e, follows \u003ca href=\"https://library.gv.com/how-to-test-prototypes-with-customers-the-five-act-interview-80305d98c407#.nxw4ffv0j\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea very simple process as he conducts tests with customers\u003c/a\u003e:\u003ca href=\"https://library.gv.com/how-to-test-prototypes-with-customers-the-five-act-interview-80305d98c407#.nxw4ffv0j\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e a welcome, an ice breaking period, the introduction of the prototype, the test, and a debrief.\u003c/a\u003e Michael’s script is wonderfully simple and easy to remember. Dive into his process in more detail in the book \u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Sprint-Solve-Problems-Test-Ideas/dp/150112174X/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSprint\u003c/a\u003e from \u003ca href=\"http://www.gv.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGV\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:476]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://www.nngroup.com/articles/why-you-only-need-to-test-with-5-users/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eElaborate usability tests are a waste of resources. The best results come from testing no more than 5 users and running as many small tests as you can afford.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/nielson-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Jakob Nielsen\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJakob Nielsen\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eNielsen Norman Group\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The best results come from testing no more than 5 users and running as many small tests as you can afford.”  @jakobnielsen @NNGroup    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to \u003ca href=\"https://www.nngroup.com/articles/why-you-only-need-to-test-with-5-users/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eresearch conducted by the Nielsen Norman Group\u003c/a\u003e, the majority of problems with your prototype will be identified after testing with just 5 customers. Instead of testing more customers, Jakob Nielsen recommends another small batch of tests after refinements have been made.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRecruiting customers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRunning the test is actually the easy part of the feedback process. Finding test subjects is the hard part. If you have an existing customer base, query your database to find power users. Devout customers are often excited to see new design concepts, and will likely give more informed feedback. This is their chance to influence the design process!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you’re testing a prototype for a brand new product, you’ll need to be more creative in how you recruit. Once again, \u003ca href=\"https://library.gv.com/how-to-find-great-participants-for-your-user-study-da20f98dad9e#.25tf6kb7v\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ethe GV team has a clever solution\u003c/a\u003e. They create \u003ca href=\"https://www.dropbox.com/s/fhr71njlj7yv7r1/recruiting-screener.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ea form to screen customers\u003c/a\u003e that asks a few carefully considered questions. \u003ca href=\"https://www.dropbox.com/s/5kmofdms00sbh84/Google-Ventures-Research-Sprint-Screener-Worksheet.pdf?dl=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eA worksheet guides them to create a screener\u003c/a\u003e that will target the right kinds of people. They post a link to their screener form on Craigslist, Twitter, Facebook, and send to an existing mailing list if available. Since you’ll only need about 5 test subjects, you don’t need a high response rate to the screener.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBe prepared to compensate your customers for their time—remember, they’re doing you a big favor by testing your prototype.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlternatively, you could hire a professional recruiter to find customers for you. The downside is it can be very expensive, and it won’t be a hands-off process. You’ll still need to give them enough information to target the right customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://mollynix.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhen we don’t have a live product built and we need to get feedback, we can send a prototype to researchers to have it tested. It allows us to get feedback not just from drivers in San Francisco but from all around the world.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/nix-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Molly Nix\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMolly Nix\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eUber\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        When we don’t have a live product built and we need to get feedback, we can send a prototype to researchers to have it tested. It allows us to get feedback not just from drivers in San Francisco but from all around the world.    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTesting remotely\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNot all the customers you recruit will live nearby. You’ll need to make plans to conduct tests remotely too. \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/greggcorp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGregg Bernstein\u003c/a\u003e, Senior User Researcher for \u003ca href=\"http://voxmedia.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eVox Media\u003c/a\u003e, has developed \u003ca href=\"http://product.voxmedia.com/2016/5/26/11787530/remote-user-testing-at-vox\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ean elegant system to conduct tests with users remotely\u003c/a\u003e using inexpensive, freely available software—a rig that runs just $99, a small price to pay for fast feedback!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s how he does it:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGregg shares a \u003ca href=\"https://calendly.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eCalendly\u003c/a\u003e link with a potential test participant, letting her select a convenient test time. Calendly also lets Gregg ask for permission to record the session, and lets him send details on what the test participant can expect.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe Vox design team posts a prototype to \u003ca href=\"http://invisionapp.com?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGregg invites the participant to an \u003ca href=\"http://blog.invisionapp.com/introducing-invision-liveshare-real-time-design-meetings-in-your-browser?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision LiveShare\u003c/a\u003e—a shared screen with voice chat where the customer can use the prototype while Gregg asks questions, observes, and takes notes.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe session is recorded using \u003ca href=\"https://www.telestream.net/screenflow/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eScreenFlow\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAfter the test session is complete, Gregg re-watches the video to fill in gaps in his notes. He then shares those notes and his insights with his Product team via Slack.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis process is simple and fast, yet effective. It lets Vox’s remote product team get feedback from users anywhere without hopping on a plane.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA service like \u003ca href=\"http://lookback.io\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLookback.io\u003c/a\u003e can also help you get fast feedback from both colleagues and customers remotely. \u003ca href=\"https://support.invisionapp.com/hc/en-us/articles/205503919-User-Testing-and-the-InVision-Viewer-app?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eInVision and Lookback integrate to let you test a mobile app prototype\u003c/a\u003e with customers. It records the customer’s screen, their interactions with your prototype, and even overlays a video of their face as they use your app, helping you read their emotional state.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen your app is built, \u003ca href=\"https://lookback.io/support/how-do-i-install-lookback-into-my-app\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eyour developers can integrate Lookback into your app\u003c/a\u003e so test sessions can be triggered any time. Users can shake their phone to reveal a secret button that triggers Lookback’s recording feature. All sessions are stored in a central dashboard for designers and developers to review and make revisions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/_lindseytron\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLindsey Campbell\u003c/a\u003e, UX researcher at InVision, has a unique approach to getting customer feedback remotely. She’s set up a Slack channel to share prototypes with devout customers to get early feedback and bring customers into the design process. The design team monitors the feedback and tweaks the product as needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRelated: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eGet stakeholder approval 46% faster\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eBetter, faster product prototyping and testing\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike a chef sampling her ingredients, designers need to get a taste of the user’s experience while designing, not just after the product ships. When you shorten the feedback loop, you can learn faster how to make a product that will appeal to your audience. Here’s some guidance to get you started.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen should I build a prototype?\u003c/strong\u003e After you’ve done initial research and worked through many ideas on paper.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow much of the app should I build in my prototype?\u003c/strong\u003e Don’t waste time prototyping the entire app. Focus instead on the parts about which you have the most questions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow real should my prototype be?\u003c/strong\u003e It should be real enough that customers won’t realize it’s just a prototype.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen should I show others my prototype?\u003c/strong\u003e Early and often. Don’t let yourself get too far down a single path before you start getting feedback from colleagues. Show your prototype to customers after you and your colleagues have ironed out the kinks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWho should I show it to?\u003c/strong\u003e Start with the people in your design or product team. Be sure to get an engineer’s perspective to ensure the design you\u0026#8217;re proposing is technically feasible.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow should I present my prototype?\u003c/strong\u003e It’s always best to show the prototype on the target device if possible. Frame the problem you’re trying to solve before you ask for feedback from others.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’re fortunate to know the importance of testing, and to have access to tools that make capturing feedback cheap and easy. Whether remote or in person, your team can build fast feedback into your process so you can build better products faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eBuilding great products requires an iterative process. The more your team tests their designs through prototyping, the faster you’ll discover needed course corrections or new possibilities. Through building blocks like pattern libraries and user feedback, teams can always design with fresh eyes.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":17,"fields":{"book":["74"],"chapter_num":"05","sub_title":"Product prototyping—accelerated","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eBuilding great products requires an iterative process. The more your team tests their designs through prototyping, the faster you’ll discover needed course corrections or new possibilities. Through building blocks like pattern libraries and user feedback, teams can always design with fresh eyes.\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292557314","related":[{"title":"Why You Only Need to Test
