rel=\"author external\"\u003eAarron Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_fastfeedback.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Fast feedback - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Testing early and often with prototyping and user testing accelerates your team’s ability to correct course and innovate.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"principles-of-product-design/fast-feedback"},{"id":489,"pid":0,"title":"Lateral design","type":"chapter","date":"489","content":"\u003cp\u003eTo design better, we need to look beyond the confines of our craft. Design is more than color and form; \u003cstrong\u003edesign is the act of planning with the intention to serve others\u003c/strong\u003e. Under this definition, the borders of design stretch beyond a single team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEngineers, product managers, and researchers all have an important part to play in the design of a product. Their work, like ours, shapes the user experience. But despite shared interests, teams are often siloed by discipline, which makes collaboration and communication difficult, even dysfunctional.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOrganizational design influences product design—\u003c/em\u003esignificantly\u003cem\u003e. \u003c/em\u003eIf the relationship between the people who make a product is broken, the product will be broken too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eBroken teams, broken product\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s a scenario that plays out in companies far too often: Courtney and her team spent weeks perfecting the design of a new product. They presented the final concepts to stakeholders, got immediate sign off, then handed off their design files to Everett and his engineering team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough the dashboard design was stunning, Everett’s team had to gut it because the data Courtney’s team wanted to display wasn’t actually available. They also had to throw out the account sign up design because the designers hadn’t included all the necessary fields.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs Everett’s team continued to build the app, the distance between the intentions of designers and the execution of engineers widened. When Courtney finally got a peek at the app, she was horrified and said, “This looks nothing like the design we created!”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShe walked across the building to engineering and stormed into Everett’s office to demand an explanation. Everett, frustrated that he and his team weren’t consulted earlier, curtly explained the design concept was ignorant of engineering requirements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe relationship between design and engineering was already rocky—this wasn’t the first time they’d felt out of sync. Now it had gone from bad to worse, and the product was a reflection of their animosity. It was a mess.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike an episode of \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V3jxWCJUPQQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eHBO’s Silicon Valley\u003c/a\u003e, this story may hit a little too close to home. Courtney and Everett are out of step, as their organization is operating with a handicap—they have a \u003cem\u003evertical\u003c/em\u003e relationship. Design, at the top of the process, passes work down to engineering to execute—engineers aren’t part of the problem solving phase. Subsequently, Courtney’s team missed key technical details and key parts of the design had to be scrapped.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVertical relationships also flow the other way—from engineering to design. Engineers rush to build a product’s infrastructure and pass it to designers for decoration afterwards. The results are equally disjointed, as buttons and type might look nice, but workflows built around database models instead of mental models leave users confused and frustrated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth scenarios are broken. Great products blend design and technology seamlessly. The \u003cem\u003efeel\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003efunction\u003c/em\u003e of a product are interconnected, and equally important—like the right and left hemispheres of our brain that pass information laterally to synthesize creative thinking and logic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe can take a cue from nature. When we bring teams together to work laterally—working on the product at the same time in the same place—we can reduce process entropy and create better products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-large full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: #782aa0;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Leadership-Book-large_2x-1450x1112.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-leadership-handbook\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/Design-Leadership-Book-large_2x-1450x1112.png\" alt=\"Build a first-class design team\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #ffffff\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-leadership-handbook\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eBuild a first-class design team\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eDesign Leadership Handbook\u003c/em\u003e is your guide to transitioning to design leadership and building strong teams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"/design-leadership-handbook\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1648 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"READ THE BOOK\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eREAD THE BOOK\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1648 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #782aa0;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #782aa0;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1648:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #782aa0;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #782aa0;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCross-functional teams\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCross-functional teams are a hallmark of \u003ca href=\"https://www.atlassian.com/agile\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ethe Agile process\u003c/a\u003e. They bring together engineers, designers, and a product manager to define a product’s purpose, function, and feel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/asset-68_700px.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. Airbnb is organized into small, cross-functional teams that bring together design, engineering, and product management.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/defining-product-design-a-dispatch-from-airbnbs-design-chief/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThree elements define a product: the business, the code and the pixels. Give each a voice in all product decisions.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/photo-alex-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Alex Schleifer\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAlex Schleifer\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAirbnb\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Three elements define a product: the business, the code and the pixels.” @alexoid @Airbnb    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCross-functional teams work laterally. \u003cem\u003eTogether\u003c/em\u003e product managers, designers, and engineers work to understand the problem and conceptualize solutions concurrently, not linearly, giving each team member a voice in key decisions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike the vertical workflow Courtney and Everett followed, cross-functional teams have no grand handoffs where communication falls apart and political battles erupt. No one is downstream. Pixels and code come together simultaneously around a clear business strategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eProduct managers\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe role of Product Manager (also called a Product Owner) can vary, but in most organizations they’re responsible for the product roadmap and achieving the business’ goals. They keep the team on schedule and clear any barriers to progress.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCross-functional teams have many benefits:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWorking closely, designers and engineers develop a strong understanding of their colleagues’ craft.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe rapport established within cross-functional teams fosters empathy and respect that make collaboration easier (and more \u003cem\u003efun\u003c/em\u003e).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCommunication is much faster; designers are immediately made aware of the technical challenges their decisions create, and engineers learn when function diminishes form.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDiverse perspectives each step of the way lead to better product solutions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eShared ownership dampens political fighting and builds trust.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough a team may disband after a feature launches, strong bonds remain (like friendships formed in summer camp). This can only strengthen the company culture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://www.jeffgothelf.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe benefit of small teams comes down to three words: communication, focus, and camaraderie. Smaller teams are easier to keep current on project status, changes, and new learning. Dedicating your team to one project keeps everyone on the team focused on the same priorities all the time. Having the team all in one place allows relationships to grow between colleagues.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/gothelf-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Jeff Gothelf\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJeff Gothelf\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eauthor of Lean UX\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The benefit of small teams comes down to three words: communication, focus, and camaraderie.” @jboogie    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eTeam size\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eKeep your cross-functional teams small—no more than 10 people to make communication easy. Any more and the team will have to spend time creating process documentation and scheduling meetings to keep everyone synced. Team collaboration and communicate happens more fluently when everyone in a shared space.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1548]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDipping a toe in the water\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo make sustainable improvements to the way your organization designs products, you may need to take a red pen to your organizational chart. These sorts of changes don’t come easy or quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut before doing anything drastic, you can test the waters with some small experiments. Small projects with tight deadlines are a great place to start experimenting with cross-functional teams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf time is tight, start by investing just 1 week in a Design Sprint.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDesign sprints\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA design sprint is a 5-day process developed by Google Ventures for answering critical business questions through design, prototyping, and testing ideas with customers. Because it takes just 1 week, it’s a low-risk way to try out a lateral design process in a cross-functional team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Google Ventures group goes into great detail in their \u003ca href=\"http://www.thesprintbook.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSprint book\u003c/a\u003e and its related websites, but in short, over 5 days a small team will go from understanding the problem space to validating a design solution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you survive the sprint and produce a great product idea, you’ll have set the stage for more cross-functional teamwork in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eWorking groups\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike design sprints, working groups assemble a cross-functional team to tackle a tough problem. But working groups stay together much longer than a week to produce a final product that’s actually shipped to customers. After the project is complete, everyone returns to their respective teams.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWorking groups have:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClearly defined objectives and metrics to measure success\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDesigners, engineers, a product manager, and maybe even a design researcher\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe autonomy to make key decisions about the product they’re building\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA deadline to ship\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMailChimp has a long history of assembling working groups to focus on hairy projects. One such team was created to design a new drag-and-drop email editor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA designer, a front-end developer, and 2 engineers—one of whom had a talent for prototyping—sequestered themselves behind closed door in a small MailChimp office to tackle the project. Sketching and debating, they looked at the problem from all angles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSketches turned into simple prototypes. The designer explored UI concepts and made refinements. Developers coded out the new design, tweaking interactions as they went. Back and forth they worked, always sharing progress with each other immediately and inviting debate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/mailchimp-editor_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. The MailChimp email editor is the product of lateral design in a working group.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEventually, the prototype had reached its limits. After testing with the whole company and select customers, the new editor, \u003ca href=\"https://blog.mailchimp.com/introducing-mailchimps-new-editor/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eNeapolitan, eventually shipped\u003c/a\u003e. This working group gave the company the opportunity to escape the gravitational pull of the product roadmap to go deep on an important feature that made working in MailChimp easier and faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEveryone on the working group returned to their respective teams with respect for their colleagues and their craft, and knowledge of what could be accomplished when designing laterally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eGoing further: Institutionalizing lateral design\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBig wins from working group projects can spark conversations about optimizing the rest of the company. The cross-functional team structure that enables lateral design can be scaled up by uniting engineering, product management, and design in an organizational structure commonly referred to as EPD.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlex Schleifer, VP of Design at Airbnb, describes EPD as a 3-legged stool that supports the organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/defining-product-design-a-dispatch-from-airbnbs-design-chief/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe team should resemble a three-legged stool, in which each leg represents one of the three areas that helps build a product. If it’s done from the start, each function can grow in parallel at proper ratio as the broader organization scales.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/schleifer-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Alex Schleifer\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAlex Schleifer\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eAirbnb\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The team should resemble a three-legged stool, in which each leg represents one of the three areas that helps build a product.” @alexoid @Airbnb\n    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/epd-stool_v3_700px.png\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 2. The EPD structure is like a 3-legged stool—engineering, product, and design need to be equal to achieve balance in product design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA stool with 1 leg shorter than the others causes instability and imbalance. Similarly, EPD organizations are unstable when a function of the troika is weaker or more powerful than the others. EPD’s strength comes from sharing power.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach function of EPD must be involved and aligned from a product’s inception to its launch. EPD teams are typically organized around product features by areas of the user experience:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFacebook organizes its teams by product feature like news feed, profile, or messenger.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAirbnb organizes teams around areas of the user experience like the guest or host experience.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike workgroups, each team is cross-functional, with representation from each leg of the EPD stool.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:581]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe success of EPD is directly connected to the health of the relationships among the 3 leaders of engineering, product management, and design. Dysfunction from the top will trickle down to the respective teams quickly. It’s imperative that these 3 leaders remain united in their leadership and communication to the company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"protip share-el\"\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBetter cross-function collaboration\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://firstround.com/review/defining-product-design-a-dispatch-from-airbnbs-design-chief/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eOn the FirstMark Capital blog\u003c/a\u003e Alex Schleifer describes how Airbnb unifies staffing and hierarchy across EPD to make collaboration and planning more efficient.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe challenges of cross-functional teams\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough cross-functional teams offer a number of advantages, they can be challenging. Workgroups, because they’re temporary, rarely surface significant issues. Instead, designers might feel like they’re on a vacation—they get to learn new things before returning to the comforts of home.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePermanent cross-functional teams are more like expatriating—designers will wrestle with their identity and struggle to adapt to a foreign land. Read on to learn how these problems, though common, are being solved at a lot of great companies. Going into an EPD structure with open eyes and a set of solutions will help you transition smoothly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIsolation\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs we saw in Show and Tell, designers need regular feedback from other designers. In a cross-functional team, it’s common for a designer to operate alone, which leaves them craving conversations with peers. Organizations like Slack, Twitter, and the BBC offer some interesting solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSlack: Paired design\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLateral design in cross-functional teams is a mainstay at Slack, but designers always work in pairs, with 1 acting as the lead designer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/uxdiogenes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePair design gives you a partner in crime to help you explore ideas more. It’s two people with similar or complementary skills riffing off each other. Plus when you have two people, it helps you get unstuck faster when you hit a roadblock.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/brito-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Diogenes Brito\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eDiogenes Brito\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eSlack\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Pair design gives you a partner in crime to help you explore ideas more.” @uxdiogenes @slackhq    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:1550]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can pair designers even if you’re short staffed. Pair a designer with a colleague from another team who can spend about 8 hours per week (or just a little over an hour per day) working in tandem on design problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTwitter: Design reviews\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn early 2014, Twitter transitioned from a centralized design team to embedding designers in cross-functional teams. In order to prevent designers from feeling isolated or unable to consistently learn from their colleagues, Mike Davidson, VP of Design, scheduled weekly design reviews and other activities in the design studio to bring everyone together as a team. Congregating regularly gave all designers the opportunity to discuss the overall design style of the company and keep everyone in sync.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBBC: Rotate teams\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe BBC, with more than 20,000 employees, lets employees work on a new team every year. This policy helps all employees, not just designers, form new relationships and broaden their understanding of the organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigners who want to rotate within the UX\u0026amp;D team speak to their manager to explore the idea. Approval is common if they’ve spent over a year on the same team. The resource manager facilitates the transfer, taking into account the designer’s skills, career goals, and current team availabilities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAligning style and values\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDecentralized design teams have to work a bit harder to make sure design remains consistent across features and products. The style of each UI and the values that guide design decisions can fall into disarray if teams are left without clear guidelines. Many large organizations are working hard to solve this problem, but few more than Spotify.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSpotify: Design systems and values\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a company scales, design consistency becomes more difficult to manage. Companies like \u003ca href=\"https://developer.salesforce.com/lightning/design-system\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSalesforce\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://www.ibm.com/design/thinking/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eIBM\u003c/a\u003e, the \u003ca href=\"http://www.bbc.co.uk/gel\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eBBC\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"https://design.atlassian.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAtlassian\u003c/a\u003e created a design system to solve UI consistency issues, but Spotify used their design system to solve an organizational problem too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/spotify-glue_v2a.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 3. Spotify’s GLUE design system helps all teams produce consistent UIs, and is managed by a central team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe team that manages Spotify’s design language—called GLUE (a Global Language for a Unified Experience)—is the center of the design universe in the company around which all other design work orbits. Designers regularly sync up with the GLUE team to get guidance on new UIs and suggest additions to the design language.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/nathanacurtis\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA system isn’t a project with an end, it’s the origin story of a living and evolving product that’ll serve other products.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/curtis-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Nathan Curtis\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eNathan Curtis\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eEightShapes\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “A system isn’t a project with an end, it’s the origin story of a living and evolving product that’ll serve other products.” @nathanacurtis    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://snook.ca/archives/opinion/staffing-design-systems-team\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eDesign systems, once thought of as an occasional side project, are playing a more central role in large organizations\u003c/a\u003e, making them a perfect place for designers to converge and find common solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGuilds\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigners in cross-functional teams throughout Spotify are joined together by a design guild—a community of interest where knowledge, tools, and best practices can be shared. Anyone, not just designers, is welcome to join discussions in the design guild. A guild coordinator is responsible for managing activities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://ucvox.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/113617905-scaling-agile-spotify-11.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eSpotify’s guild structure comes from the Agile practices developed by the engineering team\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eValues\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutnumbered as they often are in cross-functional teams, designers acquiesce to engineers who encourage smaller design iterations and a simpler approach. \u003cem\u003eDo we really need that animated transition? Does it add much value?\u003c/em\u003e It’s difficult to champion the necessity of small details when you’re the lone designer. Many simply give in and get back to work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/mikeindustries\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAs the only designer in a cross-functional team, you’re accountable to a different set of values than you would be if you were working with other designers.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/davidson-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Mike Davidson\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMike Davidson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformerly Twitter\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “As the only designer in a cross-functional team, you’re accountable to a different set of values…” @mikeindustries    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere’s nothing wrong with a little pushback between designers and engineers—it keeps both from becoming self-indulgent. But often, engineers push back on design simply because they don’t understand how to measure the success of a design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEngineers measure success quantitatively:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHow many lines of code were required?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDid this impact site performance?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eHow many bugs did we ship?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesigners measure success qualitatively:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDoes it look good?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIs it easy to use?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIs it delightful?\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust as an engineer’s work shouldn’t be measured by design metrics, a designer’s work shouldn’t be measured by those of an engineer. Instead, designers and engineers, working together, must form a shared understanding of what constitutes success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecognizing this need, Spotify articulated a series of design values—principles that communicate what’s most important when solving a design problem—and made them available to the whole company. Common values help designers articulate their design decisions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, a large image occupying key space in a UI may seem indulgent to an engineer—\u003cem\u003eIs this photo really necessary? We could fit more data here if we get rid of it\u003c/em\u003e. With the support of well defined design values in the vein of Spotify, a designer might respond, “Our design values state that a UI should ‘be alive’. This image creates movement, adds color, and brings an otherwise stagnate UI to life.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith a shared set of design values, priorities and how they’re communicated becomes clearer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/spotify-design-values_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 4. Spotify established design values to guide all teams as they work on disparate projects.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-small full-bg /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #111111\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" companies\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/enterprise/impact?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn REPORT\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eSEE THE REPORT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1957 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1957:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #002fc7;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLateral design in practice\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLateral design is not organizational dogma. Whether your company is Agile, Lean, or something in between, it creates a spirit of respect and empathy between domains to produce great products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOrganizational design influences product design\u003c/strong\u003e. Shared ownership, collaborative problem solving, and blended teams are key.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s your to-do list as you put lateral design into practice in your company:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eStarting small with a 1-week design sprint.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen you’ve had a taste of the benefits of cross-functional teams, create a \u003cstrong\u003eworking group\u003c/strong\u003e to tackle a project with a clear timeline and defined outcomes. You should have designers, developers, and a product manager on the team.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen your organization is ready to go further, organize teams in an EPD structure. Engineering, product, and design should share power, and report directly to the CEO or COO.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eYour org chart can greatly influence the design process at your company. Bridge gaps between design, engineering, research, product, and others with cross-functional teams, sprints, working groups, and other structural changes that enable better lateral design.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":18,"fields":{"book":["74"],"chapter_num":"06","sub_title":"We're better together","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eYour org chart can greatly influence the design process at your company. Bridge gaps between design, engineering, research, product, and others with cross-functional teams, sprints, working groups, and other structural changes that enable better lateral design.\u003c/p\u003e\n","soundcloud_id":"292574615","related":[{"title":"Org Design for Design Orgs","url":"https://orgdesignfordesignorgs.com/","target":{"_blank":"New Window"}},{"title":"Lean UX: Walter","author_link":"\u003ca href=\"http://aarronwalter.com\" title=\"Visit Aarron Walter\u0026#8217;s website\" rel=\"author external\"\u003eAarron Walter\u003c/a\u003e","images":{"thumbnail":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-150x150.png",150,150,true],"medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-300x169.png",300,169,true],"medium_large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-768x432.png",768,432,true],"large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-1024x576.png",1024,576,true],"avatar":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-75x75.png",75,75,true],"podcast":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-600x600.png",600,600,true],"masthead":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral-1920x1081.png",1920,1081,true],"banner-xlarge":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral.png",1920,1081,false],"banner-large":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral.png",1450,816,false],"banner-medium":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral.png",900,506,false],"banner-small":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral.png",760,428,false],"full":["https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/designbetter_website_book_assets_illustrations_principlesofproductdesign_lateral.png",3840,2161,false]},"seo":{"title":"Lateral design - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Your design is only as strong as your team. Take a cross-functional approach to your organization structure and work.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"principles-of-product-design/lateral-design"},{"id":521,"pid":0,"title":"Break the black box","type":"chapter","date":"521","content":"\u003cp\u003eTom felt lost. After 4 years of tremendous growth, his company was no longer the scrappy startup he’d originally joined. In those early years, Tom simply rolled his chair over to a colleague’s desk when he needed feedback on a design. The work was collaborative, feedback was immediate, his work was known and respected. It was fun! He was able to put on his headphones and devote all of his attention to design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen things changed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe product and company grew—fast. He built out his team, and so did his colleagues. The company moved to a bigger office to accommodate all the new people, and before he knew it, a physical and mental distance developed between his design team and the rest of the company. The designs his team produced weren’t always on the radar, and subsequently, stakeholders no longer understood the value of the team’s work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSound familiar? This scenario is common for most growing companies. Design—once transparent, and integrated into the product process—becomes a black box, isolated from engineers and stakeholders, and in the precarious position of being misunderstood or ignored.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen design isn’t visible, it’s no longer powerful\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://blog.invisionapp.com/inside-design-pocket/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eAt a small company\u003c/a\u003e, it’s easy to grasp the state of a project by asking a colleague for a peek at their designs. In large companies, spontaneous design conversations rarely happen; design is separated from executives and developers. Designs often remain guarded until a grand reveal brings stakeholders together. By that point, it’s too late for honest feedback—the stakes and repercussions are that much higher because so much energy and emotion have already been invested in what’s likely an off-the-mark design.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis is a dangerous place for product design. It sets the stage for spiked projects and designers searching for more fulfilling work. And of course, designers aren’t the only ones who suffer. Companies that don’t ship their best work run the risk of unrealized potential and less satisfied employees.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it doesn’t have to be this way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:586]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eConnecting design in a large organization\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs a company grows, everyone has to work harder—and smarter—at communicating. Designers who succeed in large organizations create social capital by developing a rapport with colleagues across the organization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll have to get in the habit of stepping away from your computer to create the social capital you need. Grab lunch with a developer who may build out your next design. No need for an agenda—just get to know each other. Spend time with researchers who have their finger on the pulse of your customers, sales people who hear frequent requests, product managers who understand schedules and scope, and customer service agents who know where users struggle the most. All have valuable context to offer you. Each influences the success of your work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/mopland\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eYour legs are your most effective design tool. Get out and connect with people.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/opland-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Mark Opland\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMark Opland\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFacebook\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Your legs are your most effective design tool. Get out and connect with people.” @mopland @facebook    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd don’t just network laterally—spend time with different stakeholders and executives to understand their roles and expectations. Ask questions about the broader strategy of the company. You’ll need to understand the big picture to design products that fit into the company vision.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure class=\"image share-el\"\u003e\n    \u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/bbc_v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" /\u003e\u003cfigcaption class=\"caption\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFigure 1. Designers at the BBC stay connected with other teams by scheduling informal time with colleagues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs you become connected to colleagues on other teams, not only will your designs be more informed, you’ll create inroads into your work, putting design on everyone’s radar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/helloryanpage\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWe see our greatest successes when we involve the right people along the way.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/page-75x75.png\"\n            alt=\"Ryan Page\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eRyan Page\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eCapital One\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “We see our greatest successes when we involve the right people along the way.” @helloryanpage @CapitalOne    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-medium full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: transparent;\n\t\tbackground-image: url(https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-medium-v1_2x-900x680.png);\n\t\"\n\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003e\t\u003cimg src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/08/InVision-Signup-non-user-medium-v1_2x-900x680.png\" alt=\"Power your design workflow\" /\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n\t\u003c/a\u003e\u003cfigcaption\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy\" style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"color: #000000\"\u003e\n\t\t\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\" pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003ePower your design workflow\u003c/a\u003e\t\t\t\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiscover seamless collaboration with InVision—the product design platform powering the world’s best teams\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\t\t\u003ca\n\t\t\thref=\"https://www.invisionapp.com/signup?source=designbetter\"\n\t\t\ttarget=\"_blank\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"btn cta-ad-1996 pistanos\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-num=\"17\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-info=\"View Promotion\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-content=\"GET STARTED NOW\"\n\t\t\tdata-pistanos-location=\"body\"\n\t\t\trel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\n\t\t\u003eGET STARTED NOW\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cstyle\u003e\n\t\t.btn.cta-ad-1996 {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ffffff;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t} .btn.cta-ad-1996:hover {\n\t\t\tcolor: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tborder-color: #ff3366;\n\t\t\tbackground: #ffffff;\n\t\t}\n\t\t\u003c/style\u003e\n\u003c/figcaption\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMaking design inroads\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:589]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt’s important to bring stakeholders into the design process early and often to get feedback and fresh perspectives. Sharing your work digitally makes it easy to gather feedback from specific people, but there’s value in setting the stage for unsolicited feedback, too. Surprising things happen when you print screens and post them in a space where passersby can catch a glimpse. Leave Post-it notes and pens nearby and see what happens—I’ve gotten incredible feedback from unexpected sources with this approach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike digital, print is persistent and casual. It invites spontaneous participation even when you’re not around, which is perhaps its greatest strength.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen design is accessible to all, the process feels inclusive. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProduct design is often protected—intentionally or not—from those who are perceived to be outside the process. That’s a shame, because often experts are excluded simply because they don’t move in the same social circles at work. Take note of who leaves useful feedback so you can include them when you share your next digital prototype.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRegularly scheduled design reviews can be a great way to not only keep your design team synced, but to forge connections with other teams. While at the health tech company \u003ca href=\"http://counsyl.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eCounsyl\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/martinibot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eLaura Martini\u003c/a\u003e made a habit of inviting engineers and execs to design reviews to get new perspectives for her team, but also to put design on people’s minds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/martinibot\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eI often invited influential people in the company to my team’s design reviews so our work remained visible. My team was a little nervous about showing their early work to company leaders, but I knew it was important to do.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/martini-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Laura Martini\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eLaura Martini\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eformerly Counsyl\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        I often invited influential people in the company to my team’s design reviews so our work remained visible. My team was a little nervous about showing their early work to company leaders, but I knew it was important to do.    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-soundcloud id=\u0026#8221;283067057\u0026#8243;]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTodd Dominey, Director of Design at \u003ca href=\"http://mailchimp.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003eMailChimp\u003c/a\u003e, found sharing digital prototypes crucial to creating inroads to his team’s work, but that face-to-face design reviews go further still to help the company see the big picture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tdominey\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDigital tools and devices are helpful, but nothing beats personal interaction. Schedule as much time as possible (without it becoming disruptive) for people to share work and be exposed to what’s happening outside their immediate purview.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/dominey-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Todd Dominey\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eTodd Dominey\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eMailChimp\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “Digital tools and devices are helpful, but nothing beats personal interaction.” @tdominey @Mailchimp    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[inv-video:592]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMaking a change\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDesign teams aren’t the only ones who struggle as a company scales. All teams do. The flat structure and fuzzy roles that once made communication easy in a startup must give way in an enterprise to a well defined org chart and domain experts for the train to stay on the tracks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThings have to change, and so do we.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou’ll need to be more than a pixel pusher. You’ll have to learn to communicate. Spend less time at your desk and more time talking to colleagues. You’ll need strong relationships to do high impact design work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"quote share-el\"\u003e\n\u003chr class=\"vert\" /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/joulee\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe graph of impact tends to correlate with how many people you need to work with effectively. Once I realized this, I started to see my interactions with other people differently. It was no longer about winning battles and proving that I was right, but about developing stronger collaborative relationships.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003ccite\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\n        \u003cimg\n            class=\"avatar\"\n            src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/06/zhuo-75x75.jpg\"\n            alt=\"Julie Zhuo\"\n        /\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eJulie Zhuo\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eFacebook\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e    \u003c/cite\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"tw-copy hide\"\u003e\n        “The graph of impact tends to correlate with how many people you need to work with effectively.” @joulee @facebook    \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe black box that alienates and disempowers design will sneak up on you. Don’t wait for it to take hold of your company. Build inroads into your work now if you want to elevate design and build better products. Here’s your to-do list:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eShare early and often\u003c/strong\u003e. Set Design Review days on your team’s calendar and invite anyone to participate.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNetwork and build social capital\u003c/strong\u003e. Your org chart is not a list of names; it’s a group of potential allies. Get to know them.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBe open and accessible\u003c/strong\u003e. Post your work in a public space. Present your work at company coffee hours. Talk about your work and answer questions in a company Slack channel.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSolicit feedback every step of the way\u003c/strong\u003e. This isn’t design by committee, but good ideas—and constructive criticism—can come from anywhere.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cfigure\n\tclass=\"banner-xlarge full-bg share-el\"\n\tstyle=\"\n\t\tborder-color: Content suggestions and our Daily iOS app [\u0026hellip;]","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?quote=buffe"},{"id":135,"pid":0,"title":"Erika Hall","type":"quote","date":"135","content":"\u003cp\u003eIf you’re going to solve a problem, you want sufficient information to solve it.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eIf you’re going to solve a problem, you want sufficient information to solve it.\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":65,"fields":{"photo":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/05/hall.jpg","name":"Erika Hall","company":"Mule Design","website":"//muledesign.com","tweet_copy":"“If you’re going to solve a problem, you want sufficient information to solve it.” @mulegirl"},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"dbco-admin","author_link":"dbco-admin","images":{"thumbnail":[""],"medium":[""],"medium_large":[""],"large":[""],"avatar":[""],"podcast":[""],"masthead":[""],"banner-xlarge":[""],"banner-large":[""],"banner-medium":[""],"banner-small":[""],"full":[""]},"seo":{"title":"Erika Hall - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"If you’re going to solve a problem, you want sufficient information to solve it.","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?quote=if-youre-going-to-solve-a-proble"},{"id":746,"pid":0,"title":"Brainstorm warm-up: 30 circles","type":"exercise","date":"746","content":"\u003cp\u003eIt’s always a good idea to have a warm-up session to get your brainstorming group into the right headspace. This exercise is borrowed from \u003ca href=\"http://www.creativeconfidence.com/\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eCreative Confidence\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e and was developed by Bob McKim, one of the founders of the design program at Stanford.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e30 Circles may be done alone or with any sized group. Each participant will need a piece of paper with 30 blank circles on it (you can print \u003ca href=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/30-circles-template.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ethis template\u003c/a\u003e or ask participants to draw their own) and a pen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are the instructions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eGive each participant a printed \u003ca href=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/designco-web-assets/uploads/2017/07/30-circles-template.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003e30 Circles template\u003c/a\u003e and a pen.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet a timer for 3 minutes. Tell the participants to turn the blank circles into as many recognizable objects as possible before time runs out.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExamine and discuss the results.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn going over the results, did anyone fill all 30 circles? How many got 10 or 15? The quantity speaks to the \u003cem\u003efluency\u003c/em\u003e of ideas. How about the diversity, or \u003cem\u003eflexibility, \u003c/em\u003eof ideas—are they all similar (e.g., faces), or divergent (a UFO, an eyeball, an apple)? Did anyone “break out of the circle” and connect several circles to form an object (an airplane, or a bulbous stick figure)?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe great thing about this exercise is that it illustrates the difference between the \u003cem\u003efluency\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eflexibility\u003c/em\u003e of ideas. In a good brainstorm, you’ll want a balance of both. It also shows how we often assume there are rules (stay in the circle!) even when they’re not given explicitly.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eIt’s always a good idea to have a warm-up session to get your brainstorming group into the right headspace. This exercise is borrowed from Creative Confidence and was developed by Bob McKim, one of the founders of the design program at Stanford. 30 Circles may be done alone or with any sized group. Each participant [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":0,"fields":{"sup_title":"3 minutes"},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":[""],"medium":[""],"medium_large":[""],"large":[""],"avatar":[""],"podcast":[""],"masthead":[""],"banner-xlarge":[""],"banner-large":[""],"banner-medium":[""],"banner-small":[""],"full":[""]},"seo":{"title":"Brainstorm warm-up: 30 circles - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"It’s always a good idea to have a warm-up session to get your brainstorming group into the right headspace. This exercise is borrowed from Creative Confidence and was developed by Bob McKim, one of the founders of the design program at Stanford. 30 Circles may be done alone or with any sized group. Each participant [\u0026hellip;]","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?exercise=brainstorm-warm-30-circle"},{"id":713,"pid":0,"title":"Camera studies \u0026#038; user permissions","type":"exercise","date":"713","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUser camera study\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRecruit users: \u003c/strong\u003eJust like the Minimum Viable Ethnography, you can use a tool like \u003ca href=\"http://ethn.io/\"\u003eethnio\u003c/a\u003e to recruit 3–4 users in a demographic that interests you, using Amazon gift cards as an incentive. Explain the purpose of the study, and make sure to get permission to use the images taken.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAsk users to document their environments: \u003c/strong\u003eDepending on the area(s) of interest, this could be their morning routines, the environment where they’re currently using your product, pictures of what’s most meaningful to them on their desks, etc. Make sure to frame the request more broadly than just your specific area of interest, as you can get great insights from the user\u0026#8217;s full environment.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAsk users to walk you through the images: \u003c/strong\u003eInterview them about what they share. Reserve the gift cards until they have shared with you.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDocument and synthesize: \u003c/strong\u003eTake careful notes, and if you have multiple team members observing the process, have them highlight particularly unexpected or interesting items on a sticky note. You can then throw these up on a whiteboard and pick out patterns.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePro tip: Camera studies and user permission\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBobby Hughes, principal at \u003ca href=\"http://www.aardvarkdesignlabs.com/\"\u003eAardvark Design Labs\u003c/a\u003e, says that a camera study can be “a great substitute for rapid empathy work.” However, he cautions that “getting buy-in from the participants to take photos of their lives is an essential, and not always easy, piece.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some quick tips from Bobby on recruiting willing participants:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild trust early:\u003c/strong\u003e Ask for participation in person if possible.  It’s otherwise too easy for them to pretend they didn’t get the e-mail or text. If you don’t know them, utilize someone who knows them well to communicate the need.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKeep the assignment short, focused, and triggered by an emotion if possible:\u003c/strong\u003e e.g. “Please capture a photo of your workspace just before or after lunch,” or  “Tomorrow, please capture a few photos of things at work that make you happy.”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eClarify how photos will be used to address concerns: \u003c/strong\u003e e.g. “The sharing session will be a fun experience to help us understand things that are important to you.  Everyone will bring in a few photos of their choosing (with sensitive material removed of course). We’ll only use these photos for the session and you can share as few or as many photos as you like. You’re in control.”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHelp participants see the value they are providing:\u003c/strong\u003e  Give an example of how a previous photo led to an insight that you wouldn’t have gleaned without seeing things first-hand.  e.g. “Photos were valuable in helping us understand in a previous project that showed some people treat their cubicle as more of a library than a work area … storing stuff but not working there.”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHelp participants see the value they’ll receive: \u003c/strong\u003eRemind them that this is all about improving the experience for them!\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eUser camera study Recruit users: Just like the Minimum Viable Ethnography, you can use a tool like ethnio to recruit 3–4 users in a demographic that interests you, using Amazon gift cards as an incentive. Explain the purpose of the study, and make sure to get permission to use the images taken. Ask users to [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":2,"fields":{"sup_title":""},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":[""],"medium":[""],"medium_large":[""],"large":[""],"avatar":[""],"podcast":[""],"masthead":[""],"banner-xlarge":[""],"banner-large":[""],"banner-medium":[""],"banner-small":[""],"full":[""]},"seo":{"title":"Camera studies \u0026#038; user permissions - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"User camera study Recruit users: Just like the Minimum Viable Ethnography, you can use a tool like ethnio to recruit 3–4 users in a demographic that interests you, using Amazon gift cards as an incentive. Ask users to [\u0026hellip;]","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?exercise=camera-studies-user-permission"},{"id":642,"pid":0,"title":"Design the ideal wallet","type":"exercise","date":"642","content":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe ideal wallet: design\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSet a timer for 3 minutes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse a piece of scratch paper to design the ideal wallet\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBe visual—make rough sketches thinking of each possible use case your wallet will need to address\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe ideal wallet: empathy\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGot it? Okay, now let’s see how effective your design is by talking to a few people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFind someone nearby and interview them about their own wallet—a colleague or friend will do. You can even talk with someone over video chat, though in-person is better.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpend at least 5 minutes\u003c/strong\u003e learning about how they use their wallet or purse.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsk the person to take it out and show you the contents. Your job is to design something meaningful for this person, so dig in and try to find out what is important for them. What are some of the emotionally charged objects they keep in their wallet—pictures of children or pets? Notes from a lover? What stands out as odd or interesting? Ask why a lot (and ask more than once; sometimes the \u003ca href=\"https://open.buffer.com/5-whys-process/\"\u003etechnique of 5 whys\u003c/a\u003e can yield great insights).  Ask open-ended questions and invite them to tell you stories about the things they hold.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, \u003cstrong\u003eset a timer for 5 minutes\u003c/strong\u003e, get another piece of scratch paper and try to come up with at least 5 solutions \u003cem\u003efor the person\u003c/em\u003e you’ve interviewed. (They don’t necessarily need to be wallets, if you think you can \u003ca href=\"http://#\"\u003ereframe\u003c/a\u003e the problem in a way that leads to a more interesting solution. For example, a student in one bootcamp at Stanford designed a high heeled shoe with a money compartment for her partner, who likes to go dancing unencumbered by a handheld purse.) Be visual, and don’t worry about evaluating the idea for feasibility. The goal is to explore.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow place your 2 sheets of paper side by side and compare the ideas. What do you notice? Were your ideas the second time around more interesting, funny, or even innovative? Was it easier to generate ideas and did they feel less contrived? Do the second set of ideas feel like they are more tailored to meet the needs of the person you talked to?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf so, you’ve experienced the power of empathy in action. With any luck you still got to see how designing a product with insights from user observation is a much more productive process than starting from scratch.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eThe ideal wallet: design Set a timer for 3 minutes Use a piece of scratch paper to design the ideal wallet Be visual—make rough sketches thinking of each possible use case your wallet will need to address The ideal wallet: empathy Got it? Okay, now let’s see how effective your design is by talking to [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":3,"fields":{"sup_title":"The wallet exercise"},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":[""],"medium":[""],"medium_large":[""],"large":[""],"avatar":[""],"podcast":[""],"masthead":[""],"banner-xlarge":[""],"banner-large":[""],"banner-medium":[""],"banner-small":[""],"full":[""]},"seo":{"title":"Design the ideal wallet - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"The ideal wallet: design Set a timer for 3 minutes Use a piece of scratch paper to design the ideal wallet Be visual—make rough sketches thinking of each possible use case your wallet will need to address The ideal wallet: empathy Got it? Okay, now let’s see how effective your design is by talking to [\u0026hellip;]","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?exercise=design-ideal-walle"},{"id":639,"pid":0,"title":"Using Madlibs to generate POVs","type":"exercise","date":"639","content":"\u003cp\u003eNow that you’ve seen the power of POVs in action, you may be looking for an opportunity to use them with your own team. Once again, the d.school has created a great resource for this from their Bootcamp Bootleg, called the \u003ca href=\"https://dschool-old.stanford.edu/groups/k12/wiki/22e39/POV_Madlibs.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003ePOV Madlib.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUse insights you’ve collected from your own users during the Camera Study exercise in the Empathize chapter of this series or any other current design problem you’re working on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe POV Madlib structure is very simple.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[USER] needs to [USER’S NEED] because [SURPRISING INSIGHT]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYou can also get a little fancier, like Doug did with his POV for the MRI redesign (“We met \u0026#8230; We were amazed to realize \u0026#8230; ). Remember to paint a detailed picture of the user and to use actionable insights.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow take 15 minutes to generate at least 5 POVs using the Madlib. Use the \u003ca href=\"https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScY-5fW8NK7zoWJWLB1lrB7ZSCw8hD1nZmodvDdm9y8kA66ew/viewform?c=0\u0026amp;w=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003echecklist\u003c/a\u003e from earlier in this article to see which of your POVs check off the most requirements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd remember, you’re going to iterate on this POV, just as you’ll iterate on your prototypes later in the process. Don’t get too attached to it.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eNow that you’ve seen the power of POVs in action, you may be looking for an opportunity to use them with your own team. Once again, the d.school has created a great resource for this from their Bootcamp Bootleg, called the POV Madlib. Use insights you’ve collected from your own users during the Camera Study [\u0026hellip;]\u003c/p\u003e\n","menu_order":4,"fields":{"sup_title":"15 minute exercise"},"template":"","is_home":false,"is_blog":false,"author":"Eli Woolery","author_link":"Eli Woolery","images":{"thumbnail":[""],"medium":[""],"medium_large":[""],"large":[""],"avatar":[""],"podcast":[""],"masthead":[""],"banner-xlarge":[""],"banner-large":[""],"banner-medium":[""],"banner-small":[""],"full":[""]},"seo":{"title":"Using Madlibs to generate POVs - DesignBetter.Co","desc":"Now that you’ve seen the power of POVs in action, you may be looking for an opportunity to use them with your own team. Once again, the d.school has created a great resource for this from their Bootcamp Bootleg, called the POV Madlib. Use insights you’ve collected from your own users during the Camera Study [\u0026hellip;]","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?exercise=using-madlibs-generate-povs-15-minute"},{"id":141,"pid":0,"title":"Design the ideal wallet","type":"exercise","date":"141","content":"\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSet a timer for 3 minutes\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse a piece of scratch paper to design the ideal wallet\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBe visual — make rough sketches thinking of each possible use case your wallet will need to address\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe Ideal Wallet: Empathy\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGot it? Ok, now let\u0026#8217;s see how effective your design is by talking to a few people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eFind someone nearby and interview them about their own wallet\u0026#8211;a work colleague or a friend will do. You can even talk with someone over video chat, though in-person is better.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSpend at least 5 minutes learning about how they use their wallet.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsk them to take it out and show you the contents. Your job is to design something meaningful for this person, so dig in and try to find out what is important for them. What are some of the emotionally charged objects they keep in their wallet—pictures of children or pets? Notes from a lover? What stands out as odd or interesting? Ask why a lot (and ask more than once; sometimes the technique of 5 why’s can yield great insights). Ask open ended questions and invite them to tell you stories about the things in their wallet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGreat, well done. Now, set a timer for 5 minutes again, get out another piece of scratch paper, and try to come up with at least 5 solutions for the person you’ve interviewed. (They don’t necessarily need to be wallets, if you think you can reframe the problem in a way that leads to a more interesting solution. For example, a student in one bootcamp at Stanford designed a high heeled shoe with a money compartment for her partner, who likes to go dancing unencumbered by a handheld purse.) Be visual, and don’t worry about evaluating the idea for feasibility. The goal is to explore many ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow place your two sheets of paper side by side, and compare the ideas. What do you notice? Were your ideas the second time around more interesting, or funny, or even innovative? Was it easier to generate ideas, and did they feel less contrived? Do the second set of ideas feel like they are more specific, and tailored to meet the needs of the person you talked with? If so, you’ve experienced the power of empathy in action. With any luck you still got to see how designing a product with insights from user observation is a much more productive process than starting from scratch.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eSet a timer for 3 minutes Use a piece of scratch paper to design the ideal wallet Be visual — make rough sketches thinking of each possible use case your wallet will need to address The Ideal Wallet: Empathy Got it? Ok, now let\u0026#8217;s see how effective your design is by talking to a few [\u0026hellip;]","keywords":"","fb-title":"","fb-desc":"","fb-img":"","twtr-title":"","twtr-desc":"","twtr-img":""},"slug":"?exercise=design-the-ideal-walle"},{"id":2212,"pid":0,"title":"Jake Knapp: beyond the sprint","type":"podcast","date":"2212","content":"\u003cp style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003eIf we asked you to name a recent book that’s really changed how product teams address sticky challenges, there’s a good chance Jake Knapp’s \u003cem\u003eSprint \u003c/em\u003ewould be at the top of your list. Since publishing and popularizing the process, design sprints have become a tool for teams at organizations as diverse as \u003ca href=\"https://sprintstories.com/\" target=\"”_blank”\"\u003ePrudential, the United Nations, and The British Museum\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003eGiven the impact of \u003cem\u003eSprint\u003c/em\u003e, we’re delighted to have Jake on the show to dig into questions we’ve been curious about since reading. In this episode, we discuss topics like the relationship between design thinking and the sprint process, how sprints can work in harmony with an agile development cycle, and when \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e to use design sprints.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003eGrab your copy of \u003cem\u003eSprint\u003c/em\u003e and get ready to learn from the guy who literally wrote the book on it. Keep your ears peeled—Jake shares a sneak peek of his next publication, too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJake\u0026#8217;s bio\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003eJake Knapp is the \u003cem\u003eNew York Times\u003c/em\u003e bestselling author of \u003cem\u003eSprint\u003c/em\u003e. He spent 10 years at Google and Google Ventures, where he created the Design Sprint process and ran it more than 150 times with companies like Nest, Slack, 23andMe, and Flatiron Health. Today, teams around the world—from Silicon Valley startups and Fortune 500s to schools and governments—are using Design Sprints to solve big problems and test new ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"text-align: left;\"\u003ePreviously, Jake helped build products like Gmail, Google Hangouts, and Microsoft Encarta. Nowadays, he\u0026#8217;s writing new books and hanging around IDEO as a Visiting Fellow.\u003c/p\u003e\n","excerpt":"\u003cp\u003eIf we asked you to name a recent book that’s really changed how product teams address sticky challenges, there’s a good chance Jake Knapp’s Sprint would be at the top of your list. In this episode, hear the story behind Sprint, and what Jake is up to now (hint: it involves another book \u0026#8230; or
